03 M inspection of Refuge 3 air handling unit

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job
2. (a) Refer to Maintenance Manual, ""Operating and Maintenance manual
for Mechanical
Services - MCL Tunnels"" M-STG-ME-27400.
(b) Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation
commissioning tests.
3. Access Refuge 3 via substation 2, at ground level in Swan Street,
then down the stairwell to
the tunnel level.
4. Ensure supply fan SF-SS2-1 situated on roof of Substation 2 is
operating and normal air
supply to the ventilation shaft and refuge area is being maintained.
5. Check the grill, supplying air to the refuge area, in the
ventilationshaft is clear of debris that
will restrict air flow. [_ _]
6. Ensure the door between the Burnley Tunnel and the Refuge area is
closed.
7. Prior to entering the refuge, have the traffic control room operator
check the CO and NO levels
and the temperature of the refuge. Record in the ""Work Done"" area
of the jobsheet if the
ambient conditions are within required safety standards. If the air
quality is below standards, arrange for the control
room to refresh the air in the refuge by operating the fan until
suitable air quality is
achieved. [_ _]
8. Inspection and checks of the Refuge and shaft area.
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN WORKING IN THE
VICINITYOF
THE OPERATING FAN.
(a) Check the
(i) exhaust vent on the duct [_ _]
(ii) the return air grill on the fan unit [_ _]
(iii) The fire damper and motorised damper exhaust grills in
the access shaft to
tunnel to ensure they are free of debris that would
restrict the free flow of
air. [___]
Note: The air damper on the fan return air grill is
non-functional.
(b) Check the fire damper for damage, loose linkages and premature
operation. [_ _]
(c) Arrange the traffic control room operator to operate the fan.
Check the operation of the fan
ensuring the air flow is from the duct outlet into the refuge.
[_ _]
(d) Note: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire brigade. It
will register on the local FIP
and CCCS as a local alarm.
Remove the smoke detector access cover and spray ""test
smoke"", from a smoke
generator, as specified on the container, onto the smoke
detector (on the inlet duct).
Check that an alarm actuates on the local fire indicator
panel. [_ _]
(e ) With the supply air fan SA-SD3-01 operating record the
differential pressure, if less than
50Pa in the ""Work Done area of the job sheet. Advise the
superintendent for further
investigation. [_ _]
(f) Arrange the refuge door catch to be non-functioning, then using a
spring balance,
measure the force required to open the door. Record the results
in the ""Work Done""
area of the job sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required,
advise the superintendent
for further investigation. [_ _]
(g) Chock the door open, then using an anemometer, measure the
velocity of air out of the
open door. The reading should be with the door fully open and
no obstructions.
Record the results in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet
ifa velocity is less than
1 metre per sec. Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
corrective actions
required. [_ _]
(h ) After closing the door, measure the time taken for the air
pressure to return to the static
reading. Record the results in the ""Work Done"" area of the
job sheet if the time taken is
greater than two minutes. Raise a new job sheet for any
outstanding corrective action
required. [_ _]
( i ) Check the fan and motor for undue noise and vibrations. [_ _]
( j ) Check the fan and motor bearings for noise. [_ _]
(k) Check the fan plenum for damage, corrosion, missing panel
fixings, as well as
checking unit fixings for security. [_ _]
( l ) Measure the motor current and compare with the rated current.
[_ _]
(m ) Check the filter elements for cleanliness and replace if
required. ( 4 off 600x600x100mm)
and ( 4 off 600x300x100mm) [_ _]
9. Ensure the action of opening the Refuge door;
(a) Generates an alarm at the TCR workstation.
(b) Causes the fan speed to vary to maintain a positive pressure in
the Refuge.
(c) To replicate the action of the smoke detector, temporarily
removethe relay ""Refuge
Supply Air Fan No 3"" mounted in the rear compartment of the
fire indicator panel. The
fan should stop after about two and a half minutes. Replace
the relay on
confirmation. [_ _] (A local alarm will register on the CCCS.
The fire brigade will not
be called)
10. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes, with the door in both the open
and the closed
position.
11. Clean the refuge:
Sweep the floor and remove accumulated webs from the walls. [___]
Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish. [_ _]
12. On completion of job record anything outside normal parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the refuge etc, in the
Work Done""
section of the job sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and
raise a new job for any repairs.
13. Request the traffic control room to shut the fan down and to turn
off the lighting after
leaving the Refuge, ensuring that the door to the tunnel is
14. Record anything outside normal parameters in the ""Work Done"" area
of the Job Sheet.
15. Ensure the door between the Refuge and the Burnley Tunnel is closed.
16. Notify the Control Room on completion of the job."

12 M Maint of Access. LUMS equipment

** COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK **
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane.
2. Set up short term emergency lane closure incorporating,
symbolic worker. lateral shift, vehicle arrow board and cones
as per Work Instruction, Traffic Control TMI-3012-OP 0002 and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 2, 13, 144 or 145.
3. Reference: Advance Lane Use Sign (ALUS), Size B, Clip In/Clip
Out Version, Operation and Maintenance Manual. Doc:
CSP-304-220-300.
4. At the system control cabinet, check the following:
(a) Internal and external condition of the cabinet for
vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of moisture and any
insect infestation, clean if necessary. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and check that the equipment mounted
in the cabinet is secure. [_ _]
(c) Check wiring for tightness and for any evidence of
overheating. [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner, clean the cabinet interior. [_ _]
5. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
6. Notify the control room prior to departure.
****Complete the following CityLink Asset Condition Rating****
ASSET CONDITION RATING
Rate the Condition of the Asset.
Note:
[ 1 ] - Excellent.
Asset is new or in as new condition
[ 2 ] - Good.
Asset is fully operational, well presented, performing
it's intended function.
[ 3 ] - Fair.
Asset is functional and operational but showing signs of
deterioration that will result is some intervention
works possibly within the next 12 months. May not be
performing it's intended function to the full degree.
[ 4 ] - Poor.
Asset is functional and operational but showing major
signs of deterioration that will require intervention
works within the next 3 months. Not performing it's
intended function.
CONDITION RATING SCORE [_ _]
If the condition of asset is 3 or 4, record your observations
in the Work Done area of the job sheet(photograph if possible).

12 M Inspect, change batteries PLC in Technical Shelters"

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this work
2. Notify the control room prior to entering technical shelter.
3. At the PLC installed
(a) Remove the old Memory backup battery and install a fresh
memory backup battery. [_ _]
(b) Check the PLC status and error indicators. Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged in
the work done area of the job sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error. [_ _]
(c) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw connections, for security. [_ _]
(d) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and module
security screws are not loose. [_ _]
(e) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
and debris. [_ _]
4 Record in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet any abnormal
parameters relating to the PLCs or components and require
further investigation. Raise a new job sheet for any
corrective actions required. Priority High P1.
5. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the job.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

12 M Test of Stick TMD function

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this job
2. Reference Vipac Report "Tuned Mass Damper Maintenance -
Western link Stick Wall"
Report Nos. 303562-1 (May 02) & 303699-1(August 02)
3. This Tuned Mass Damper testing is to be carried out by the
sub-contractor in the presence of the Civil Worker.
4. Where the job is scheduled at the following times, use the
following list to determine the choice of sticks to perform
the tests on.
Feb-2004 (1) Jan-2005 (2) Jan-2006 (3)
Jan-2007 (1) Jan-2008 (2) Jan-2009(3)
Jan-2010 (1) Jan-2011 (2) etc
Where the (n) is 1; then
N1, N2, N6, N11, N16, N17, N21, S12, S13, S14, S15, S16, S17
& S18
Where the (n) is 2 ; then
N3, N4, N5, N13, N14, N19,N20, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10 & S11
Where the (n) is 3; then
N7, N8, N9, N10, N12, N15, N18, S1, S2, S3, S4, S5 & S6,
On the occasion of February 2004 (only), perform tests on
Stick N13, N15, N16, N20 & N21 to confirm the on-going
integrity of previous repairs (N16 & N20 are included the
selected population).
4. Use an Elevated Work Platform to access the top of the stick
5. Attach an accelerometer (set up so that it outputs
displacement) near the middle of the top edge of the stick
6. Excite the stick by hand to get it swaying at its natural
frequency in a North South direction.
7. Keep exciting the stick until a higher displacement cannot be
achieved.
8. Let go of the stick and allow the movement to decay
9. Capture the initial part of the decay curve on an FFT
analyser
10. Download the data, use successive peaks and troughs to
calculate the natural frequency and the displacement at
which tuned damping ceases and natural damping takes over.
11. Repeat steps 6 to 10, exciting the stick in an East West
direction.
12. The sub-contractor is to supply a report setting out the
result of the tests as well as a detailed listing of minor
repairs carried out along with any works still outstanding.
13. Notify the Traffic Control room on completion of the job.

The forms setting out the lighting for inspection are:
Bolte Bridge Tower Feature Lighting - East Tower
TMF-3012-OP-0216
Bolte Bridge Tower Feature Lighting - West Tower
TMF-3012-OP-0217

Architectural Feature Lighting - Bolte Bridge Road (North

24 M L2 Inspect the HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor
under the supervision of an electrical/electronics
technician.
3. Refer to Manual Merlin Gerin Masterpact Instruction Notice
M-STG-EL-24030
4. Ensure that the Three monthly and twelve monthly HV electric
inspection have been carried out.
5. (Substation 1A, 1B, 2A, 2B, 3A, 3B, 4A, 4B, 5A, 5B and 6
Schneider Circuit breakers and Isolators)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Thoroughly, visually inspect the circuit breakers and
record and report any damaged or worn parts.
(b) Inspect metal and insulating parts, remove dust and dirt
and clean in accordance with the manufacturers
instructions.
(e) Clean the switchgear enclosure (cubicle)
(f) Carefully examine bushings and insulators for cracks,
chips or partial discharging.
(g) Visually check and ensure that control devices are free
of accumulated dust deposits by carefully cleaning.
(h) Check all un-insulated cable connections for correct
tension. Check and tighten un-insulated bolts on cable
connections where practical to do so.
(i) Check all earthing and cable connections including
control cubicle, inspecting for loose connections and
signs of broken strands. Tighten and or repair as
required.
(j) Visually inspect all auxiliary wiring, plugs and
terminations.
(k) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across primary
contacts.
(l) Check and record winding resistance of shunt trip and the
close coils. Compare with previous years findings.
(m) Confirm correct operation of spring charge motors and
interlock devices.
(n) Inspect, clean and lubricate all moving parts of the
switchgear operating mechanisms as described in the
Manufacturer's Maintenance Instructions.
(o) Clean the exterior of switchgear cubicles of dirt and
grime, record areas of damaged paintwork or areas that
are corroded.
(p) Examine and clean all control relays, contactors, fuses
etc, confirming connections and continuity of all wiring.
(q) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across cubicle
bus bar connections for all phases if the bus bar is
available.
(r) Perform insulation resistance tests with a 2500V
insulation tester for one minute per test:
(i) With the CB closed each phase to the other phases and
earth.
(ii) With the CB open, across the open contacts
This test shall be carried out after maintenance.
(s) Carry out a complete functional test on each circuit
breaker, including earth switches ,and ensure correct
operation including devices, flags, interlocks etc.
(t) Trip and close the circuit breaker at least five times.
(u) Reinstall all parts and ensure all switchgear is fully
operational on completion of the maintenance.
6. (Substation Protection)
DO NOT ATTEMPT SERVICE ON CURRENT TRANSFORMERS WHILE
ENERGISED.
Extremely high voltages can be generated across the secondary
terminal of the current transformer when OPEN circuited.
Current transformers should be short-circuited during
secondary injection testing. Jumper leads should be removed
when testing is complete.
(a) Carry out continuity test from current transformers to
relays by primary injection, functional test of trip,
close. Alarm and control circuits by operation of the
relay and physical inspection of all relays. ENSURE
APPROPRIATE ALARMS ARE GENERATED BACK TO THE TRAFFIC
CONTROL ROOM.
(b) Knee point / saturation test current transformers
recording five points across the magnetisation curve as
well as comparing results of each phase / class and
results of previous testing.
(c) Record the settings of all protections relays, verify and
record the pick up and drop out values, IDMT trip times
for two points of trip curve via primary injection or the
Nulec TTS.
(d) When testing is complete, carefully check that all
jumpers and test leads have been removed and that any
connections removed for testing purposes have been
reinstated.
7. (Cast Resin Dry Type Transformers)
(a) Carry out an insulation resistance test using a 2500V
insulation tester of HV-LV Frame. Record the results on
an appropriate Maintenance Provider Check Sheet.
8. (Insulation Resistance Testing of High Voltage Cables)
(a) Carry out an Insulation resistance test on all of the
insulated HV cables. The test shall be carried out using
a 2500V insulation tester and shall be tested:
(i) Between each and every phase conductor
(ii) Between each phase conductor and the earth conductor.
(b) Inspect each cable termination and seals for mechanical
damage, overheating, tracking and or ingress of moisture.
Record and report any damage.
9. (Substation 1A, 1B, 2A, 2B, 3A, 3B, 4A, 4B, 5A & 5B Low
Voltage Circuit breakers and Bus Ties)
(b) Record the number of operations for each circuit breaker.
(c) Inspect metal and insulating parts, remove dust and dirt
(d) Clean the switchgear enclosure (cubicle)
(e) Carefully examine LV bushings and insulators for cracks,
(f) Visually check and ensure that control devices are free
(g) Check all un-insulated cable connections for correct
(h) Check all earthing and cable connections including
(i) Visually inspect all auxiliary wiring, plugs and
terminations.
(j) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across primary
(k) Check and record winding resistance of shunt trip and the
(l) Confirm correct operation of spring charge motors and
(m) Inspect, clean and lubricate all moving parts of the
(n) Clean the exterior of switchgear cubicles of dirt and
(o) Examine and clean all control relays, contactors, fuses
(p) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across cubicle
(q) Perform insulation resistance tests with a 1000V
(i) With the CB closed each phase to the other phases and
earth.
(ii) With the CB open, across the open contacts
This test shall be carried out after maintenance.
(r) Carry out a complete functional test on each circuit
breaker and ensure correct operation including devices,
flags, interlocks etc.
(s) Trip and close the circuit breaker at least five times.
(t) Reinstall all parts and ensure all switchgear is fully
10. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions. Raise a new

12 M Tst batt backed emerg and exit lights SUB 5 & Environs

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 5 AND ENVIRONS
TMF-3012-OP-0247, only those fittings in which the tubes have
been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 5 AND ENVIRONS
TMF-3012-OP-0247, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 5 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0247,
only those light fittings that the battery charger operation
indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
SUBSTATION 5 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0247 for subsequent
replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

06 M Insp WL1 Technical Shelter emergency lighting

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are
required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Reference MGP Electrical Pty Ltd , Technical Shelter Main
Distribution Switchboard, Operation and Maintenance Manual
(M-MCL-ME-20016).
4. Carry out the maintenance in the electrical systems in the
following:
| | Date | Name |

12 M Joint Leakage Drain Inspections & Cleaning

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26.
In the work done area record:
a. Any deviations from the plan.
b. Lane closure start time.
c. Lane closure finish time.
d. Weather conditions.
3. Joint Leakage Drains (JLD) are located on the outside of the
left and right hand lanes of the tanked section of the Domain
Tunnel.
4. Inspect JLDrains for water flow, blockages, deposits and
conditions. Record the details for each drain on form Domain
Tunnel Joint Leakage Drain TMF-3012-OP-0276
5. The JLDs are inspected via an inspection point which is a
square Gatic plate with a hinged lid. This lid is held secure
in position by a Philips head screw.
6. Access both ends of drain by unscrewing covers in both the
LHL and the RHL.
(a) To inspect the drain sets, shine the torch down one open
cover, then at the corresponding open cover, using the
extendable mirror, look for the lighted torch.
(b) Record the condition of the pipe e.g. the cleanliness
and / or blockage of the drain on form Domain Tunnel
Joint Leakage Drain TMF-3012-OP-0276
(c) Record the condition of each drain e.g. build-up of
calcite, slim, silt etc and whether or not there is a
flow of water present.
**Use Condition Words : WET, DRY, CLEAR, OBSTRUCTED and if
obstructed record the action that was taken to clear the
obstruction ( ie: hydrant flushed or Jet flushed).
7. If there is water flow present, then at the dirty water pit,
inspect the Dirty Water pit where the flow enters (If it does
enter into a pit). Measure and record the flow and elapsed
time for on form Domain Tunnel Joint Leakage Drain
TMF-3012-OP-0276.
8. Record all details on the inspection sheet, as all the
information is important.
9. Ensure all the pit covers and Gatic covers are closed and
secured on completion of each inspection.
10. Ensure a completed copy of the forms Domain Tunnel Joint
Leakage Drain TMF-3012-OP-0276 are forwarded to the Civil
Team Leader or representative on completion of the job and
prior to end of shift. Civil Team Leader or representative
is to record and sign off each form and raise any actions
(job sheets) for further inspection or cleaning

12 M Clean silt out of lake

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Coordinate the planning and completion of other jobs that can be
carriedout whilst the lake is empty.
1. Organise front end loader and tip trucks for handling and
removal of silt and debris from the site.
2. Arrange for the collection of soil samples and the disposal
of the silt and debris to a suitable waste disposal site.
3. Notify the Control room prior to commencing this job.
4. Refer to Work Instruction ORNAMENTAL LAKE MAINTENANCE,
TMI-3012-OP-0024.
WARNING: BE AWARE OF SHARPS AND OTHER HAZARDOUS MATERIALS
THROUGHOUT WORK SITE.
5. Check and monitor the water table level in pits 1, 2, 3 & 4
(Lake can only be drained when the water table is below
200mm) over two consecutive days. Record the results on
form GROUND WATER LEVEL MONITOR - TMF-3012-OP-0249.
If the readings are over 200mm do not proceed with draining
the lake, only proceed to draining the lake when the levels
less than 200mm are obtained over two consecutive days.
6. Check the weep holes, at the base of concrete batters, of
creek lining upstream of lake for indication of ground water
flows.
7. Diversion of Creek
(a) Open flap valve, to the Ornamental Lake By-pass
Diversion (Removal of silt and debris may be required).
(b) Place stop log (entry) across entry to the lake.
(c) Check the water of the diversion at the diversion
outflow into the Moonee Ponds Creek. Ensure the water
flow is unrestricted.
(d) Check to look at the downstream end to ensure water ,,
backflow considered and can be controlled. Contact ,, ,,
Melbourne water for assistance as required.
8. Draining the Lake
(a) Thoroughly clean the outflow area of algae prior to
accessing the stop logs (Outflow).
(b) Unbolt and remove the stop logs (outflow) of lake to
allow the lake to drain.
(c) Allow the silt to sufficiently drain, so as to not cause
a dust problem. During the cleaning process monitor (at
least daily) the Ground Water in Pits 1, 2, 3 & 4 for
any increase of the ground water level. If there is any
increase in the water level, either the job should be
postponed and the lake allowed to refill or measures put
in place to maintain the water level at a suitable level
below 200mm.
9. Remove all the silt and debris using a front end loader
fitted with rubber tyres.
10. Ensure the silt is disposed of within regulations.
11. Ensure pits 1, 2, 3 & 4 are cleaned of all silt and debris.
12. Refill the Lake
(a) On completion of all cleaning, replace stop logs
(outflow) and bolt into position.
(b) Remove stop log (entry) to allow the water to flow into
the lake.
(c) Close flap valve leading to the diversion pipe.
13. Clean all other litter and debris from around lake area.
14. Record anything outside normal parameters in the area of
the Job Sheet below.
15. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Calibrate and test tunnel PA system

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Reference manuals:
PA-RRB Field Equipment - System Manual
Vol 1 O&M - M-MCL-TL-100053
S-STG-CO-22017 Rev 07 - CML Southern Link Comms Services
PA System Spec.
Drawing - PA Physical Fibre Path - PAS01-EL-100001.
3. Apparatus required:
a. CML's - WG OMK-6 Optical test Kit - Optical Power Meter
set at 850nm.
b. CML's - Tektronix TDS-3012 Digital Oscilloscope and
isolation transformer - including appropriate test leads
and a BNC "T" junction.
c. Transfield's - Sound Meter
d. RRB-PA / CCCS - 1KHz test tone message = "ZZ_1_KHz_Tone
(137)".
e. hearing protection - manadatory during Tunnel Level
testing.
WARNING: THE LIGHT EMITTED FROM A FIBRE OPTIC CABLE MAY BE
EITHER VISIBLE OR INVISIBLE, DIRECTING THE FIBRE OPTIC CABLE
TOWARDS THE EYE OR LOOKING DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF A FIBRE
OPTIC CABLE WHICH IS EMITTING LIGHT, WILL CAUSE IRREVERSABLE
DAMAGE TO THE EYE.
4. The following needs to be performed at each Tunnel TOA PA
Amplifier, which are located in the Tunnel Equipment Rooms.
5. Measure and record the fibre received signal level. This can
be done by disconnecting the multimode fibre from the OSD363
fibre receiver and connecting it into the Optical Power Meter
set at 850nm. Record the dB level and then connect the fibre
back into the OSD363 fibre receiver. The level is expected to
be between -18 to -30 dB, dependant on the distance of the
Equipment Room from Technical Shelter 8. Levels greater than
-40dB indicate a possible fibre fault and should be
investigated before proceeding.
6. Measure and record the 20KHz tone audio level between the
OSD363 Fibre receiver and the TOA PA Amplifier. This can be
done by connecting a BNC "T" connector inline between the
OSD363 Fibre receiver and the TOA PA Amplifier and then
connect the Digital Oscilloscope. Record the signal level in
milivolts. The level is expected to be 500mV P-P (peak to
peak).
Before making any adjustment to the output level of the
OSD363, move the slider controls for the PA Amplifier Pre-Amp
and Master Volume down to 1. It may be possible to adjust the
output level of the OSD363 Fibre receiver to produce the
expected output. Remove the BNC "T" connector and reconnect
the OSD363 directly to the TOA PA Amplifier.
7. Adjust the PA Amplifier sliders to produce two green bars on
the PA Amplifier signal level indicator. Set the Pre-Amp
Control (V-1054B) to 8, and then adjust up the Master Volume
Control to obtain the two bars of level indication. The
Master level is generally 2 to 4 below the Pre-Amp level, if
Pre-Amp is 8, the Master is expected to be between 4 to 6.
8. Request the TCR, from the CCCS, play a normal
message into the Tunnel, for example "Left Lane Closed", like
for the Domain Tunnel = "DT : Left Lane - D28 Maintenance
(79)"
for the Burnley Tunnel = "BT : Left Lane - D59 Maintenance
(155)"
Request that it ONLY be played to the Tunnel PA System.
9. The next test is performed in the Tunnel using the Transfield
Sound Meter.
WARNING: Hearing Protection must be worn during the following
test.
Position the sound meter in the centre of the centre running
lane, 1500mm above the roadway. Request the TCR, from the
CCCS play for 4 to 5 seconds the 1KHz test tone name
"ZZ_1_KHz_Tone (137)" ONLY to the Tunnel PA and
preferably only the zone being tested. Measure and record the
result on form TMF-3012-OP-0391. The expected level is 94
dB(A).
10.Repeat the above test for each of the Tunnel PA Zones.
11.On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet. Raise
a new job sheet for any works that require further attention.
12.Notify the control room on completion of the inspection.

03 M Inspect of Liebert AC units accessed via the EE Tunnel.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work. [_ _]
2. Access is via the Emergency Egress Tunnel from the entry
adjacent to the Burnley Vent Station stack.
(a) Arrange for the control room to start Supply Air fan
ESFP01. ESFP01 is the Supply Air for the Emergency Egress
Tunnel.
(b) Arrange for the control room to switch on the Emergency
Egress Tunnel lighting prior to entering the tunnel.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer. Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting. [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that temperature
shown on unit is consistent with new setpoint and
verify temperature is consistent with ambient
(+ or - 1 deg) using portable thermometer. [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting. [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer. [_ _]
NOTE: LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm. [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary. Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation.
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation. [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running. [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch. [_ _]
5.4. Inspect for loose connections or leaking coils. [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator. [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit. [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits. [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage
problems. Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish. [_ _]
7.0 Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record the
results on form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347.
Ensure the form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347
is returned to the Electrical Electronics Supervisor or his
representative. Raise a new job for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Supervisor or his representative and raise a
new job for any outstanding repairs.
9.0 Notify the control room on completion of the job and arrange
for the control room to switch off the emergeny egress
tunnel lighting as well as the supply air fan.

12 M Routine Maint. of Swan St Vent Station Fans

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
WARNING:
1. CHECKS SHOULD NOT BE CARRIED OUT IF MORE THAN 1 FAN IS OPERATING
IN THE
SWAN ST SHAFT VENT STATION.
2. NO PERSON SHALL ENTER THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM ALONE.
TWO OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT AT ALL TIMES WHEN WORK IS BEING
CARRIED OUT IN ANY CHAMBER OF THE VENT STATION
3. TAKE HEED OF NOTICES ON THE AIRLOCK DOORS.
1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 2, the Swan Street
ventilation rooms and to
interrupt operations.
2. Inform the control room prior to commencing work. Maintain radio
contact at all times.
3. Reference manual: ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual
(M-STG-VE-26058)
4. Carry out the monthly checks on the PMCS in the Traffic Control Room.
5. Access to the ventilation fan is via ladders in the Swan Street Shaftlift
well and Substation 2
is accessed from Swan Street.
6.(a) On the MCC in Substation No 2, select ONE axial fan to be
operational while
the maintenance is being carried out on other fans. Switch
the nominated
AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch to the MANUAL position and the
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switch to the REMOTE postion, then press the START
pushbutton.
(b) Switch ALL non-operational axial fans OFF, by switching the
AUTO/OFF/MAN selector
switches to the OFF position. All electrical isolation
procedures are to be in
accordance to Work Instruction TMI -3012-SA -0103, Low
VoltageIsolation Procedures.
7. In Substation No 2
(a) Measure the insulation resistance of the motor stator windings
and record in the ""Work
Done"" section of the Job Sheet. [_ _]
(b) Measure the current of the anti-condensation heater and compare
with the rated current.
(c) Inspect the motor control panel both internally and externally
for damage, corrosion,
evidence of overheating, ingress of moisture, dust and grime
(clean or repair if required).
8. (a) The fan rooms which are on levels 4, 5 & 6 are accessed from the
Note: HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN IN ANY
VENTILATION
FAN CHAMBER.
(b) Measure the CO levels in the fan rooms, through the doorway,
prior to entering the fan
room, then at regular intervals during the fan checks.
(c) WARNING: DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN
1 METRE OF AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD.
Airflow velocity nears 35 km/h.
9. Static Fan Check.
(a) Ensure that the fan selected for maintenance is electrically
isolated, press the START
pushbutton on the local push button station at Level 5. The
fan should not start.
(b) On level 5 open fan blade inspection hatch.
(c) Examine the impeller for
(i) Dirt and foreign matter on the blades (clean if required)
[_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade tips [_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade leading edges [_ _]
(iv) Loose bolts and or blade fixings at the hub [_ _]
(d) Examine the electrical cable for security of fixings, damage dueto
fraying, scuffing or
similar and for damage at locations where the cables
penetratepanels or
housings. [_ _]
(e) Check any grease discharged from the motor bearings, since the
last lubrication is not
excessive. [_ _]
(f ) Examine the discharged grease for any noticable colour change.
Ensure that the grease
nipples are clean. [_ _]
(g) Inspect the cable connections to the motor for evidence of
overheating. [_ _]
(h) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motorwindings and the
winding heater bridge. Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth. Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
each phase winding and earth. Record results in the Work
Done area of the
Job sheet.
(vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(x) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works. Include the Job Number of the new job in the
Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate. Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.
(i) On leaving the fan inlet cowl grill hatch, replace the hatch
cover immediately. [_ _]
(j) Manually check the operation of the Rotork actuator and
associated linkages that
operate the exit dampers, use the local control panel switch.
(k ) Remove any mechanical interlocks blocking the fan operation.
[_ _]
10. Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION: ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) When the Static Fan Checks are complete, return to substation
3and remove the
safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then removethe
fan motor isolation
at the MCC.
Note: Ensure that all non-operational fans are isolated, in
accordance
TMI-3012-SA-0103, and that the only fan not
isolated, is the fan to be maintained.
(b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF position
to the MANUAL
position, then switch the REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch
from the REMOTE
position to the LOCAL position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room and start the fan, that is
beingmaintained, by releasing
the Local STOP pushbutton, then pressing the START
Note: The motor must not be started more that four times in
an hour.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
(e) Lubricate the motor bearings with fresh grease, while the motor
running.
DE = 100 gr / NDE - 120 gr Use Shell Stamina RL2 grease or
equivalent only.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the bearings
using the retrieval
system. Examine the grease for changes of colour. [_ _]
(g) Monitor the fan and motor for abnormal noises. [_ _]
(h) Stop the fan motor using Local EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
11. On completion, collect all materials and leave the fan room after
equalizing the
differential pressures.
12. In Substation No 2
(a) Remove all safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103,
then remove the
motor isolation for all the fans at the MCC. Return all
theREMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switches to the REMOTE position, and the
AUTO/OFF/MAN fan selector
switches to the AUTO position.
(b) Check that one fan is operational and no alarms are present
13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done' sectionof
the Job Sheet.
14. Notify the control room on the completion of the job.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident
hasoccured requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
1. Immediately leave the fan chambers on Level 4 and Level 6 and ensure
the doors to the lift
shaft are secured.
2. Notify TCR Operator when Level 4 and level 6 have been evacuated so
that smoke
extraction can commence.
3. If the fan being checked is running, advise TCR that it is
currentlyrunning under LOCAL
control and will be returned to AUTO control. Stop the fan using
the Emergency STOP
pushbutton on Level 5.
4. Release the STOP pushbutton and leave Level 5 ensuring that the door
to the lift shaft is
secured
5. If the fan is isolated or not running, vacate all fan chambers
immediately and secure doors.
6. Notify TCR when all personnel have left the fan chambers, the doors
secured and all the
personnel are accounted for and in the lift shaft.
7. Only if a fan was running and operational - In Substation 2 switch
the
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch to the REMOTE position, as well
switch the
AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch to the AUTO position.
8. Stop the operational fan then return the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector
switchto the AUTO
position and restart the fan.
9. Notify TCR Operators that they have control.

03 M Inspect & Test YC Pump Station pumps

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Control room prior to commencing this work.
2. Reference manual Operation and Maintenance Manual for
Melbourne Citylink Project - Yarra Crossing Groundwater
Pumping Station Upgrade R-YPS-CO-100000.
3. WARNING: BOTH THE WET WELLS AND THE VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED
CONFINED SPACES AND MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED
SPACE CONDITIONS.
Refer to Work Instruction, Confined Space Entry
TMI-3012-SA-0015.
4. At the Local Control Panel A1
(a) Check the switchboard, situated in switchroom above the
pump station, for local alarm conditions. [_ _]
(b) Carry out visual inspections both internally and
externally of the control panels for damage, corrosion,
evidence of insect infestation, ingress of moisture, dust
and grime (clean as required). [_ _]
(c) Check the cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating and inspect electrical the control equipment
for evidence of overheating. [_ _]
(d) Check control panel indicators for operation, repair as
necessary. [_ _]
(e) Check control switches are left in the Auto
position. [_ _]
(f) Record the readings of the hour run meters, for each
pump, in the Work Done area of job sheet. [_ _]
5. Repeat step 4 for Control Panel A2. [_ _]
6. Repeat step 4 for Control Panel A3. [_ _]
7. Repeat step 4 for Control Panel B1. [_ _]
8. Repeat step 4 for Control Panel B2. [_ _]
9. Inspect the pump wet wells and the valve pit.
(a) Inspect the wet wells through the access ladder hatch for
general cleanliness and any accumulated debris, inspect
for any evidence of leakage. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external conditions of the pipework and the
valves for corrosion (Rust). Minor corrosion (rust) is
to be removed with a wire brush and the cleaned surface
painted with Coldgal. [_ _]
(c) Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet evidence of
leaks and any corrective works that are outstanding.
Raise a new jobsheet for any corrective works
outstanding. [_ _]
(d) Lubricate Isolating Valves with Loctite Silver Grade Anti ,,
Seize Lubricant or Equivalent. [_ _]
(e) Operate all pump manual isolating valves through AT LEAST
THREE (3) OPEN/CLOSED cycles to confirm valve
operationally. Ensure the valves are left in the fully
open position on completion. [_ _]
10. Test the function of the Hydrocarbon detector, to test use a
small LPG bottle and release a small amount of gas in the
vicinity of the detector. Check with the control room that
an alarm was received. [_ _]
11. Dirty Water Pumps
(a) Check the inlet tundish for any blockage or accumulated
debris. Clean if necessary [_ _]
(b) Check the triple interceptor trap for evidence of oil on
the surface, turbidity and the correct operation of the
discharge valve. [_ _]
12. Switch the pump PSYCDWP1 AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to
the MANUAL position. [_ _]
(a) Check and note the position of pump non-return valve
counterweight before starting the pump. [_ _]
(b) Check the cabling to the pump for damage and that it is
clear from possible damage. [_ _]
CAUTION: Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low level
alarm point as lack of submergence may cause pumpset damage
13. Start the pump PSYCDWP1 by pressing the START push
button. [_ _]
(a) Measure the operating current of the pump in the Work
Done area of the job sheet. If the current drawn is
greater than FLC 55A then record in the Work Done
area of the Jobsheet . [_ _]
(b) Observe pump operation for smooth running, vibration and
abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Observe pump discharge rate is sufficient to draw down
level of water in sump. [_ _]
(d) Visually check piping for leaks, damage and corrosion,
clean corrosion and repair with Cold Gal. If leaks or
damage is apparent, record in the Work Done area of the
job sheet and raise a new job sheet for the corrective
maintenance. Ensure the Team Leader or his
representative is notified. [_ _]
(e) Observe the level controller readout for variations,
with respect to the pump operations. [_ _]
(f) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton. Check
the operation of the non-return valve (NRV), as the
water flow stops.
(i) The NRV should close with a sharp audible metallic
sound,
(ii) Backflow through the pump should cease within 30
seconds.
(iii) If a faulty closure is suspected, the pump should be
re-started then be monitored again.
(iv) If a faulty valve closure is still suspected, record
in the Work Done area of the job sheet and raise a
new job sheet for the corrective maintenance. [_ _]
14. Repeat steps 12 and 13 for PSYCDWP2. [_ _]
15. Repeat steps 12 and 13 for PSYCDWP3. [_ _]
16. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position. [_ _]
17. Check the operation of the float switches by manually
operating the floats. The floats are situated in the corner
of the wet well and are accessible from the ladder with the
use of a special hook to reach the cables. Lift the
High/High float and invert it 90 deg to trigger alarm. Lift
the Low/Low float and invert through 90 deg, checking that
the alarms are received at the Traffic Control Room. [_ _]
18. When this job falls in either December, March, June or
September. Lift the level controller sensor out of the
protective conduit, then carefully, clean the recess in the
sensor base of all dirt or debris. [_ _]
19. Check the operation of each of the isolating valves, by
partially closing then fully opening again. [_ _]
20. Work plan for the Ground Water Pumps
21. Switch pump PSSWGWP1 AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the
MANUAL position. [_ _]
(a) Check the cabling to the pump for damage and that it is
alarm point as lack of submergence may cause pumpset damage
22. Start the pump PSYCGWP1 by pressing the START
pushbutton. [_ _]
(a) Record the operating current of the pump in the Work
Done area of the job sheet if the current drawn is
greater than. (FLC 40A.). [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
and/or abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Observe that pump discharge rate is sufficient to draw
down water level in sump [___]
(d) Observe the level controller readout for variations,
with respect to the pump operations. [_ _]
(e) Shut off the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton.
Check the operation of the non-return valve (NRV). The
NRV is constructed of PVC. The NRV should close once
flow, through the pump, has ceased. If a flow
continues, then the pump should be re-started and run
for 2 minutes and the non-return valve monitored again.
If a faulty closure is still suspected, record in the
Work Done area of the job sheet and raise a new job
sheet for the outstanding corrective works. [_ _]
23. Repeat steps 20 to 22 for pump PSYCGWP2. [_ _]
24. Repeat steps 20 to 22 for pump PSYCGWP3 ONLY IF A PUMP IS CONNECTED.
[_ _]
25. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to AUTO
position. [_ _]
26. Check the operation of the float switches by manually
27. When this job falls in either January, March, June or
September. Lift level controller sensor out of the
protective conduit, then carefully, clean recess in
the sensor base of all dirt or debris. [_ _]
28. Check the operation of the isolating valves by partially
closing then opening fully again. [_ _].
29. Check that the wet well ventilation system fan is
operational and sucking air. [_ _]
30. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
31. A Confined Space Entry permit is required prior to entering
the sump
32. At the pump motor control panel, switch the pumps from
Automatic Mode to Manual Mode.
Caution DO NOT OPERATE THE PUMPS WITHOUT WATER COVERAGE. THE
PUMPS NEED TO BE SUBMERGED TO OBTAIN ADEQUATE COOLING
OTHERWISE DAMAGE WILL OCCUR.
33. At the pump sump
(a) Inspect the triple interceptor for debris, silt deposits
and foreign objects, remove and clean if required.
(b) Inspect the pump sump for debris, silt deposits and
foreign objects, remove and clean if required.
34. Ensure the Triple Interceptor bypass valve is OPEN.
35. This test is to record the flow rate in litres per second
for each pump. It is only necessary to operate the pumps,
in each case, for a time sufficient to allow the readings to
stabilise. Record all results on form TMF-3012-OP-0272 -
Domain Tunnel Groundwater Pump Calibration.
(a) Close valve Pump 2
(b) Start Pump 1 using the On/Off Push Buttons
(c) Allow sufficient time for readings to settle
(d) Record the flow rate (Lt/Sec) from the 2 Magflow flow
meters (Large digits).
(e)Turn pump 1 OFF.
36. Close Pump 1 valve and Open Pump 2 valve. Repeat step 35
for pump 2.
37. Ensure the combined flowrate is between 15 and 16 litres per
second for each pump. Adjust the flowrate, if required, by
adjusting the butterfly valve on the 100mm and 80mm
lines. [_ _]
38. Once the test is complete, ensure both pump valves are fully
open, pump isolators are switched ON and the float switches
are free to operate. [_ _]
39. At the pump motor control panel, switch the pumps from
Manual mode to Automatic Mode.
40. Record in the Work Done area of the Job sheet any
outstanding works that require further work. Raise a new
job sheet for any outstanding work that is required.
41. Record the hours run for each pump in the Work Done area of
the Job Sheet. The hour run meters are on the panel door.
42. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the pump station and
equipment etc, in the Work Done section of the job
sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
43. Notify the traffic control room on completion of the job.
44. Ensure the completed from TMF-3012-OP-0272 Domain Tunnel

-80dbm.

result for each of the carriers.

antennato the RX input
filter [_ _].

equipment downlink amplifier
VHF monitor test point.

12 M Test of battery backed emergency and exit lights

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive end
blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST MEZZANINE
FLOOR LEVEL TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those fittings in which
the tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL
TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL
TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those light fittings that the battery
charger operation indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
GRANT ST MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL TMF-3012-OP-0241 for
subsequent replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M inspect of Liebert A/C units accessed via the tunnel

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Set up the traffic control measures as per Work Instruction,
Traffic Control, MI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 20
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer. Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting. [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that temperature
shown on unit is consistent with new setpoint and
verify temperature is consistent with ambient
(+ or - 1 deg) using portable thermometer. [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting. [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when the new
setpoint is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer. [_ _]
NOTE: LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm.. [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary. - Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation.
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation. [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running. [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch. [_ _]
5.4. Inspect for loose connections or leaking coils. [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator. [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit. [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits. [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]

06 W Inspect EET Ground Water Drainage pits and pipes.

work.

(a) Work Instruction Burnley Tunnel Drainage TMI-3012-OP-0032
(b) Operation & Maintenance Manual - Tunnel Drainage Stage 2
Design Report R-STG-EN-006 Rev 1.
3. Entry to EET is via the emergency stairwell at the Burnley
Stack. Traffic management as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plan 22, 25 if required to access from the tunnel.

(a) Select groundwater pits to be inspected on form Burnley

Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0301. Selection should be

selection including examination of previous inspections.

inspections.

Egress Tunnel - Groundwater Pit Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0301
is returned to the civil Team Leader or his representative to
record and sign off, and raise any actions (job sheets) for
further inspection or cleaning.

connection reads in litres, with the rotation of rightmost digit
(wheel) equal to 10 litres and therefore each graduation on the
rightmost red wheel being equal to o ne litre.
e.g. with a reading, showing all twos, the reading would
represent 222,222,222 litres.

Drawing Nos. STG-CI-2109 and 2110. The bays are approx. 50
mts long. For layout of the testing inlet and outlet pipes
refer to TMI-3012-OP-0036.

Pipes]

DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316. [_ _]

(e) Inject water into collector pipe UC and monitor for
Record the results on form BURNLEY TUNNEL LONGITUDINAL

(e) Turn on the water supply, monitor and record the response

PAVEMENT DRAIN FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316. [_ _]
(f ) Turn off the water supply. [_ _]
7. Replace caps on Outlet pipes D1 and D2 at the CW pit. [_ _]

integrity]

(b) Monitor

FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0316. [_ _]

06 M Clean of the in pavement expansion joints (WL 1)

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
A Job Start as a minimum must be completed in consultation with
all participating employees to identify, assess and control the
hazards prior to work commencing.
The job start should take into account the following hazards as a
minimum:
Traffic
Manual Handling
Sharps & other foreign objects
Slips, Trips & Falls
Noise
UV radiation
Inclement weather
Other hazards particular to the location or conditions should be
identified, assessed, controlled and noted on the Job Start form prior
to the work commencing.
1. Inspect and clean the in-pavement expansion joint systems in
the following WL 1 sectors:
S1/N7 Tollway Bulla Road to Bell St
S2/N6 Tollway Bell Street to Moreland Road
S3/N5 Tollway Moreland Road to Brunswick St
S4/N4 Tollway Brunswick St to Flemington Road
2. Notify control room prior to commencing work.
3. Use flashing amber beacon light on vehicles and wear
fluorescent vest when on foot.
4. Inspect the expansion joints
(a) for an accumulation of debris (Nuts, bolts and hard
debris) that may cause the expansion joint to not
function correctly
(b) for an accumulation of debris that may cause a blockage
and stop any waterflow.
(c) for an accumulation of debris that is greater than 20mm
deep that will support
vegetation growth.
5. Clean the expansion joint of debris and blockages that have
built up.
6. Check the expansion joints for structural damage and loose or
missing components including nuts, bolts and surrounds.
7. Record in the Work Done Area of the job sheet any outstanding
on-going corrective actions and the location of the expansion
joint.
8. Raise a job sheet for any outstanding corrective actions on
any expansion joints.
06 M Clean of the in pavement expansion joints (WL 2)
the following WL 2 sectors:
S5/N3 Tollway Flemington Road to Dynon Road
S6/N2 Tollway Dynon Road to Footscray Road and
S7/N1 Tollway Footscray Road to West Gate Freeway.

12 M Tst batt backed emerg and exit lights SUB 3 & Environs

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS
TMF-3012-OP-0245, only those fittings in which the tubes have
been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS
TMF-3012-OP-0245, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0245,
only those light fittings that the battery charger operation
indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0245 for subsequent
replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Major inspection of ADS

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to accessing the advisory sign
and the controller box.
2. Access to ADS is by Extension ladder access to both the
controller and the sign.
3. Caution when working close to traffic ensure equipment and or
tools do not fall on passing vehicles.
4. Carry out visual inspection externally and internally of the
cabinets, sign, external cables and conduits for vandalism,
mechanical damage, water ingress, condensation or insect
infestation. Also check inside cabinets for tripped circuit
breakers, disconnected wires, burn marks from excessive
heat. [_ _]
5. Visually check for looseor missing nuts and bolts, and for
rusted areas, rusted nuts or bolts. Cleans with wire brush
and spray with Cold Gal or equivalent. This shold be
done with care and to avoid overspray. [_ _]
6. Carry out preventative maintenance as per Cegelec Securite &
Signalisation O & M manual Volume 4 Maintenance Manual,
ED/BC/MCC/O&M/04, Section 8 [M-MCL-TM-1551].
(a) Carry out Luminance test. Traffic Control Room assistance
required (Section 8.2.4.2.) [_ _]
(b) Test interior lights (Section 8.2.5.) [_ _]
(c) Check pilot light (Section 8.2.7.) [_ _]
(d) Test heater (Section 8.2.8.) [_ _]
(e) Test ground fault circuit breaker (Section 8.2.9.) [_ _]
(f) Check lightning arrestor fuses
(Section 8.2.10.) [_ _]
(g) Clean CD501/CD502 board transformers with brush or
portable vacuum/blower [_ _]
(h) Test AC voltages (Section 8.2.11.) [_ _]
(i) Clean controller cabinet with vacuum/ blower. [_ _]
(j) Clean external window with Windex or equivalent and
clean rags. Inspect internal window of lens of dust and
clean if required. [_ _]
(k) Test (push button) character board and check if all pixel
arrays are operational. [_ _]
8. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the Job Sheet and
raise corrective Job Sheet if required.
9. Notify control room prior to departure."

12 M Inspection of Cast Resin HV Transformers

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
All work on High Voltage equipment must be carried out in
accordance with Transfield's procedure number TMI-3012-SA-0102
High Voltage Safety Work Instructions.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. (Cast Resin Dry Type Transformers 1A, 1B, 2A,2B, 3A, 3B, 4A,
4B, 5A & 5B)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Examine and clean all bushings, insulators, terminals,
cable connections, for partial discharge, ingress of
moisture or damage.
(b) Inspect Operation of the Winding temperature sensor.
Carry out functional testing to ensure correct Alarming
and trip operation via the PMCS to the Traffic Control
Room.
(c) Check tightness (Torque test) of all earthing and cable
connections (MEN, Bushings and tank) and inspect for
evidence of overheating of broken strands. Tighten
connections where necessary.
(d) Inspect transformer coils, core and frame, for evidence
of corrosion, dirt, or foreign material buildup. Clean
coils , core and frame and treat and recoat any surface
rust spots.
3. Record in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions. Raise a new
Job Sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative. Include in the Releated Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job. [_ _]

require refinement.

Portal.
AID 604 is located on the on the Westgate looking westbound at
the Kingsway exit..
AID 605 is on a pole mounted in the central median strip looking
westbound.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the lane to
service the camera..
2. Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(b) Position 0 and 1.
(c) Lane closure: LHS & RHS Lanes.
(d) Electrical cabinet location: Tollway.
3. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plans 1, 2, 3.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and check that the equipment mounted
in the cabinet is secure. [_ _]
(c) Check the cables and terminations for signs of
degradation, re-terminate if necessary.
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and securely fastened
to the PT140 and the LED is green, if the LED is red
there is no signal from the camera.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF THE FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE, AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT. [_ _]

lit, if not record the fact, for later
replacement. [_ _]

the signal from the camera using the WFM 90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly to the lead from the camera)
. Ensure the co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT140
module and is secure. [_ _]

7. Camera and Camera Housing;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, external
evidence of moisture and any insect infestation. Surface
insect spray may be applied if necessary to the housing
exterior but must not be applied to the interior of the
housing or to the housing glass.
If there is evidence of insect infestation or moisture,
then open camera housing and carry out steps 7. (d) and
(e) [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X cleaning fluid. [_ _]
(d) Check that the camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN. [_ _].
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Jell pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Jell pack.
8. Re-instate the 240V power supply to the camera
heaters. [_ _]
9. Check with the control centre that the AID camera is
functioning correctly and that the MASK is aligned. [_ _]
10. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion.

03 M Maint of Gantry Tolling Equipment

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Carry out the three monthly planned maintenance defined in
the CML RSE Users Manual maintenance schedule, document no.
M-MCL-ET-1225.
2. Perimeter access gate at technical shelter key required.
3. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment
and or tools do not fall from the gantry. Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry. Adhere to safety
instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 "Working on Gantry Structures
4. Notify Control Room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
5. Complete CML RSE Maintenance Plan PL-MCL-ET-100001.
Preventative Maintenance No.0301
When carrying out the cleaning of VDC sensors (in 0301),
inspect the area around the connectors for evidence of
corrosion.
If corrosion is evident, then clean the area as described
below.
Where cleaning is to be also carried out, use extreme care
to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter any
connectors.
The Fibre Optic Connector is to be only removed on the
12 Monthly Cycle (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
Prior to removing any connector or cover socket, clean
surface corrosion and deposits from around connectors,
socket covers and the surrounding surfaces use a tooth
brush to assist if necessary.
Remove the three socket covers (remove only if possible
using fingers) and apply a light spray of silicon to
the three (3) socket covers, replacing and exercising
the threads.
With all caps and plugs re-installed apply a light spray of
silicon to the area around the plugs and caps.
Check for silicon overspray on the VDC sensor window and
clean if necessary.
Where connectors or socket covers cannot be easily removed,
record details in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and
report the fact to the Team Leader or his representative.
0301: Check image quality and
,,,, alignment with CML Clean glass regardless of image.
,,,, Lubrication of mounting bracket carried out on removal
,,,, only. Lightly spray with lubricant.
0302: Clean external glass of front and rear VR sensors.
Inspect mounting brackets and lubricate as required.
Ensure pins are cleaned and lubricated using silicon
spray prior to installing.
0303: Check VR Illuminator that there are less than 10%
defective IR LEDs,Advice CML if suspect below 10%
0304: Clean front surface of TRX, inspect mtg bracket and
lubricate as required
0305: Clean outside of glass cover of VDC, Replace failed
lamps, Lubricate arms as required.
Inspect VDC arm locating pins and chains. Record any
works required and report any equipment that needs
repair.
0306: Road Markers: Inspect for clarity & Cleanliness.( High ,,
,, contrast between marker & road). (If road markers need ,,,, to
be changed, inform the Team Leader.)
0307: Clean the glass of VSS sensor
0308: Inspect Distribution Cabinet for loose or damaged ,,
cables. Clean cabinet for insects or moisture.
6. Record in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet any
outstanding works requiring further attention. Create a
new Job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative of the outstanding works.
Record the New job number in the "Work Done" area of this
job sheet and in the "Related Job" field of both jobs.
7. Notify Control Room prior to departing from the Technical
Shelter."
