01 M Check of Burnley Vent Station Primary Axial Fans

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Works to carried out at non-peak times.
2. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 3, the
ventilation rooms and to interrupt operations.
3. Inform the control room prior to commencing the work and
brief TCRO's on interruptions and expected alarms. Maintain
radio contact at all times.
4. Reference manual: ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual (M-STG-VE-26058)
5. At the PMCS in the control room.
(a) Check the motor balance vibration readings on the PMCS
for all fans. If any reading is in excess of 6.5mm/s<(>,<)>
record the result in the "Work Done" area of the job
sheet for further action. [_ _]
(b) Check the trend log for the last month, looking for
abnormal events. Any events and or trends that are
abnormal are to be recorded in the work done area of the
Jobsheets and a new job sheet raised to investigate and
correct the abnormality. [_ _]
(c) Check the running current and record in the "Work Done"
area if greater than Primary fans FLC 349A Secondary
fans FLC 310A.
(d) Check the drive and non drive end bearing temperatures
for the operating fan motor. Record the details for
those bearings with a temperature greater then 80?C in
the "Work Done" area of the job sheet for further
action [_ _]
(e) Record Hours run in Work Done. [_ _]
6. Access to the Burnley ventilation station is through the
locked airlock on stairway adjacent to the south west corner
of the Burnley vent stack. Access to substation 3 is via
external doors adjacent to the Burnley Portal.
WARNING:
DO NOT CARRY OUT THESE CHECK WHENEVER MORE THAN 2 FANS ARE
OPERATIONAL
DO NOT ENTER THE ACCESS AIRLOCK TO THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM
ALONE. TWO OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT WHENEVER WORK IS
BEING CARRIED OUT IN THIS AREA. OBSERVE ALL NOTICES ON THE
AIRLOCK DOORS.
7. In substation 3;
(a) Switch the Main Isolator for EFE 01 OFF. (NOTE:- The
order of fan selection is dependant on fan requirements.
A minimum of one fan must be running at any time). Open
the starter cubicle & inspect the cubicle & wiring
connections. Upon completion close the door, and return
the Main Isolator to the ON position. [_ _]
(b) Switch the Main Isolators for all the other non
operational axial fans, one at a time EFE 02 thru to
EFE10 to the OFF position, then inspect the starter
cubicles. Once the inspections are complete, ensure the
cabinet doors are closed and the isolators are returned
to the ON positions. [_ _]
8.1 Fan Room Access
(a) Enter the fan room from the entry stairway after
equalizing differential pressure in the airlock.
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
CHAMBER.
DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1 METRE OF
AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD, AS THE AIR IS FLOWING AT APPROX
35kmh .
8.2 Static Checks
(a) Press the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton adjacent to the
motor.
(b) Check the condition of anti-vibration mountings and
ensure that the rubber bushing is moved freely, adjust if
required. [_ _]
(c) Examine the grease that has been discharged from the
motor bearings for any noticeable colour changes. [_ _]
(d) Open the local electrical junction box, inspect the
electrical wiring and connections, inspect all glands for
tightness. [_ _]
(e) Visually inspect the motor for evidence of condensation<(>,<)>
white powder or similar. Record in the "Work Done" area
of the Job Sheet any evidence of condensation, powder and
the like and notify the Team Leader or his
representative. [_ _]
(f) Carry out the following insulation/resistance test of the
motor and heater windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has
been isolated and is to remain isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motor windings and the winding heater bridge. Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out an Insulation resistance
test between this common bridge and earth. Record
the result in the "Work Done" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) If the heater was connected on arrival, then
re-instate the heater connections, otherwise leave the
motor winding heater terminations isolated.
(vii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(viii) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than
2 megohm, then Record in the "Work Done"area of the
Job Sheet and raise a new job for the outstanding
works. Include the Job Number of the new job in the
"Related Job" field as well as in the alternate.
Notify the Team Leader or his representative of any
outstanding works.
8.3 Running Checks.
(a) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton and contact the TCR
to start the fan. [_ _]
(b) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(c) Check the fan for any abnormal noise or vibrations. _ _]
(d) Check the flexible connections for wear and leakage of
air. [_ _]
(e) Check anti-vibration mountings for operation and
structural soundness [_ _]
(f ) Check the operation of the local vibration
monitor. [_ _]
(g) Record any abnormalities in the "Work Done" area of the
Job Sheet for further action. [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the Local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
8.4 Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION: ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) On completion of the Static Fan Checks, return to
substation 3, then remove the safety tags, in accordance
with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then remove the fan motor
isolation at the MCC.
Note: Ensure that only one non-operational fan is
isolated at any one time.
(b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF
position to the MANUAL and the REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switch from the REMOTE position to the LOCAL
position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room; there start the fan<(>,<)>
that is being maintained, by releasing the local STOP
pushbutton at the fan and then pressing START
pushbutton.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(e) Add Shell Stamina RL2 grease or equivalent, to the
bearings, only while the fan is running. Ten pumps per
bearing.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the
bearings, using the retrieval system. Examine the
grease for changes of colour. [_ _]
(g) Check the fan for any abnormal noises or
vibrations. [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the local EMERGENCY STOP
(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
9. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 02. [_ _]
10. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 03. [_ _]
11. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 04. [_ _]
12. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 05. [_ _]
13. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 06. [_ _]
14. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 07. [_ _]
15. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 08. [_ _]
16. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 09. [_ _]
17. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 10. [_ _]
18. (a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are
disengaged. [_ _]
(b) Collect all tools and materials, leave the fan room<(>,<)>
again equalise the corridor and the fan room pressures.
19. (a) Check the lighting within the fan chamber for
operation. [_ _]
(b) Repair any light found to be not operating or raise a
new jobsheet for the repair of the fan chamber lighting.
20. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done'
section of the Job Sheet.
21. Notify the control room on completion of work.
22. Return to the control room and ensure all fans are
operational.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident has
occurred requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
Note: Depending on the position of an event, Substation 1 may be
inaccessible.
1. If Substation 3 is not accessible
(a). If a fan that is being checked is running, advise the
traffic control room that the fan is running under
LOCAL control. Unless advice is received, from the
control room, that fan should remain under LOCAL
control.
(b). Vacate the ventilation fan chamber, ensuring the sliding
door to the airlock is closed and sealed.
(c). Advise the traffic control room when all personnel are
in or have left the air lock.
2. Substation 3 is accessible
(a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are disengaged
(b) Return to substation 3 and switch all the fan
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switches to the REMOTE position
and switch all the fan AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switches to
the AUTO position.
(c) Notify the traffic control room operators that they have
control of the fans.

12 M Inspection & calibration of WIM & TCS Systems

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Access keys for the WIM/TCS controller cabinets are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to accessing the WIM/TCS
equipment.

symbolic worker, lateral shift, vehicle arrow board and cones
as per Work Instruction , Traffic Control TMI-3012-OP 00002
and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
4. Reference Transfield Procedures TMI -3012-OP-0045 WIMS -
Speed Calibration and TMI-3012-OP-0046 Weigh in Motion
Calibration.
5. Re-calibrate the weigh sensor, using both a 6 axle
articulated vehicle and the Transfield Services street
sweeper vehicle.
6. Re-calibrate speeds using a hand held laser gun. Use the
average of ten runs per lane for each calibration vehicle.
7. At the counting sites, re-calibrate the speed using a hand
held laser gun. Use the average of ten runs per lane for
each calibration vehicle.
8. The results of test are to be recorded on forms WIMS Speed
Calibration TMF-3012-OP-0361 and Weigh in Motion
Calibration TMF-OP-3012-0362. A copy of the results are to
forwarded to the Electrical Electronics Team Leader on
completion of the job.

parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet. [_ _]
10.Notify the control room prior to departure from the WIM/TCS
site.

12 M Inspection of Merlin Gerin UPS system

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Involve the Transfield Maintenance Staff in the UPS Switching to
maintain UPS switching
knowledge and awareness.
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work
2. The Galaxy UPS system 12 monthly inspection shall be carried out by
the sub-contractor in
the presence of the electrical / electronic technician.
3. Refer to MGE UPS Systems Manual, Galaxy User Manual E-6739380XT/FA,
M-STG-EL-24009, and Schnieder Electric Tunnel Electrical Services
Training Notes,
M-STG-EL-24001, Section 9.
4. Record measurments on form 12 M MGE Uninterruptible Power Supply
Inspection and Test
TMF-3012-OP-0200.
5. Check all the indicators on the hidden control panel. Record any
alarm conditions in
the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet and raise a Job sheet to havethe
alarm condition
attended to. [_ _]
6. Inspect the UPS and the batteries cleanliness, cracks, corrosion etc.
[_ _]
7. Measure and record the DC voltage of each battery. (Use Maintenance
application)
8. Measure and record (Use Maintenance application)
UPS input voltage
UPS output voltage
Battery voltage
Check the balance of each output phase and ensure the UPS is not
overloaded.
Check for correct UPS calibration. Maintenance Program required.
Peak and RMS loading.
Output current and voltage wave shapes.
AC capacitor current balance.
9. Isolate the UPS by switching to Maintenance Bypass. [_ _]
10. Measure and record the temperature of the AC and DC filter
capacitors. [_ _]
11. Measure and record the current flowing in various branches of the
battery circuits. Ensure
each path is providing an equal or representitive portion of the
load.
12. Using an optical thermometer, measure the temperature of current
carrying connections,
during or following a current carrying period. Terminals or
connections found with a
temperature which is greater than ""room temperature plus 5
degrees) should be
investigated. Repair any connections found to be faulty and
record in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet any repairs carried out.. [_ _]
13. Open the Battery Circuit Breaker and using a DC voltmeter, measure
the leakage
voltage between battery terminal positive and earth then between
battery terminal negative
and earth to ensure that there is no electrical leakage from the
batteries to earth.
THE BATTERY BANK IS ENERGISED EVEN WHEN THE RECTIFIER / CHARGER AND
INVERTER HAVE BEEN STOPPED AND THE BATTERY CIRCUIT BREAKER OPENED.
BATTERY MAINTENANCE SHOULD BE PERFORMED BY QUALIFIED TRADESPERSONS
IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE SAFETY REGULATIONS. INSULATED TOOLS,
GLOVES AND SAFETY GLASSES SHOULD BE USED. WITH THE BATTERY
CIRCUIT
BREAKER CLOSED, THE BATTERY TERMINALS HAVE A RELATIONSHIP TO EARTH.
14. Measure and record the string DC voltages. If the voltage differs
by ? 5% from the
expected voltage, carry out a discharge / cycling test.
15. Visually check the UPS circuit boards and components for conditions
that will lead to
failure of the UPS.
e.g. Security of PCB's and Ribbon cables
Cables and connections
Capacitors (Premature swelling, leakage)
Evidence of overheating.
Fuses are secured
General cleanliness of the UPS.
Replace or correct any fault found, Record in the Work Done Area
ofthe Job Sheet any
repairs carried out
16. Return the UPS to normal operation. FOLLOW THE CORRECT SWITCHING
SEQUENCE.
17. Check the UPS readout and program software for correct operation.
(Using Maintenance
application)
18. Simulate a power failure, Open Mains 1 Isolator (Q1), the UPS
operation will change to
the batteries.
19. Measure and record (Using Maintenance application) the battery
voltage, at 5 sec
intervals, for a 15 minute period. Plot results to obtain a
Discharge Characteristics Curve.
Compare curve with previous curves for evidence of battery
failure. Record in the
Work Done Area of the Job Sheet any descrepancies and raise a Job
sheet for the
descrepancy to be attended to. [_ _]
20. Return the UPS system to its normal operational state. [_ _]
21. Notify the control room on completion of the job. [_ _]"

(b) Switch the fan OFF using the circuit breaker in cabinet

05 Y Inspect the welds of the South Sticks

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference: Melbourne City Link - The Stick Wall Periodic
Non-Destructive Testing - Scope. Report No. 4199/002
Provided by Intico.
3. Refer to Report No. 4199/007.
Item 1.1
External
Examine the external features from the stick to foundation
interface up to a minimum of 2 metres above the baseplate for
evidence of metal and or paint cracking as well as evidence
of corrosion setting in.
(a) Visually examine the welds connecting the vertical
stiffeners to the skin plates.
(b) Visually examine the welds connecting the upper base plate
to the vertical elements (Stiffeners and skin plates).
Internal
Examine the all internal features, using the access door,
from the upper base plate up to a minimum height of 500 mm
for evidence of metal and or paint cracking as well as
evidence of corrosion setting in. A torch and mirror is
required.
(c) Visually examine the welds connecting the vertical
stiffeners to the skin plates
(d) Visually examine the welds connecting the upper base plate
(e) Examine the general internal cavity for visible degradation
as well as any evidence of moisture of water deposits.
(f) Record all details of any cracks in the metal or welds or
paint surfaces along with any evidence of water residues as
well as any corrosion and or degradation. Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
Item 1.2
(a) Visually examine the protective "Denso Tape" wrap on each of
the fixing nuts. Examine for signs of deterioration and for
any evidence of corrosion of the nut or stud.
(b) Record details of any deterioration of the protective wrap
and or corrosion. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
works.
Item 1.3
(a) Visually inspect the external surface of the welds joining
the two box sections of the stick, at splice level.
Particular attention should be paid to detecting paint
cracking that may occur at the joint line. Use an elevated
work platform to access and inspect the joint in each face,
where EWP access is not possible use binoculars.
(b) Visually inspect the external faces for visible degradation
and or corrosion.
(c) Record details of any evidence of cracks in paint or the
metal (welds) as well as any surface degradation. Raise a
new jobsheet for any outstanding works.
Item 2.1
(a) Carry out a NDT Test on the "vertical stiffener to skin
plate welds" and the "upper base plate to skin plate and
stiffener welds". Test all welds up to a height of +500mm
from the upper base plate
(b) Provide a written report of the result of each test.
Item 4.1 (First Inspection 2008)
(a) Carry out a NDT examination of the "Upper base plate -
underside surfaces in the upper baseplate to lower baseplate
stiffener welds". Carry out the examination via the access
door. Examine all accessible areas for discontinuity of the
plate-weld joint and for crack
indications in the upper baseplate.
4. Notify the Traffic Control room on completion of the job.

02 M Record Extensometer Readings of the BT slabs

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control prior to commencing the work.
2. Lane closures to access the Burnley tunnel shall be as per
Work Instruction, Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 * Plan 39. ( 60kph ).
3. Reference documents:
(a) Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0031.
(b) Melbourne CityLink Project, Southern Link, Operations and
Maintenance Manual Tunnel Drainage Stage 2. R-STG-EN-006
and Transfield Obayashi JV,
(c) Operations & Maintenance Tanked Tunnel Drainage Works
Report PSM407.R34 December 2000 R-SDG-TU-134.
(d) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture, Burnley Tunnel Long
Term Monitoring of Twin Anchored Slabs. Report PSM407.R30
September 2000, R-SDG-TU-130.
(f) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture, Burnley Tunnel
Extensometer and Piezometer Reading Procedures. Report
PSM500.R11 June 2001, R-SDG-TU-211.
4. Location:
Twenty-eight extensometers are located along the length of
the twin anchor zone of the tanked section of the Burnley
Tunnel, roughly in the centre of the middle lane.
5. Purpose:
The extensometers monitor any movement of the invert (floor)
slab. Small variations in the extensometer tips can be
measured and assessed to indicate whether a slab has moved
and whether the twin anchors have become overloaded
(Ref. R-SDG-TU 130 Rev B) due to the slab movement.
6. Carry out Extensometer measurement.
6.1 (a) Clean the base of the extensometer probe with a clean
rag. (Note: Ensure extra battery is in pouch) prior to
performing readings.
(b) Plug the lead for the extensometer probe into readout
unit, switch the extensometer on using the right button,
select channel 1 with the knob.
(c) With the probe vertical and the base clear of any
obstructions, ensure the digital readout reads approx.
11.5mm. This represents the djusted zero value.
(d) Ensure the extensometer probe is kept free of grit at
all times.
6.2 (a) Locate the cast iron cover over the extensometer tip in
road surface. Spray the bolts liberally with CRC.
(b) Using the socket, slowly and carefully remove the
stainless steel bolts. If the bolt(s) are excessively
tight, apply more CRC and allow sufficient time for the
CRC to penetrate down the thread.
(c) Lift the cast iron cap off and place to one side.
6.3 (a) Remove the plastic cap covering the brass bush and pin.
Do not loose the plastic cap.
(b) If the recess housing the bush or pin, contains water,
then remove the water using the wet/dry vacuum
(Ensure you take a Generator & leads).
Wipe the brass bush and pin surface areas are thoroughly
cleaned of all dirt and grit.
(c) Both the bush and pin must be clean and remain clean
during reading (i.e. no grit shall be allowed to wash
back onto the bush or pin surfaces).
6.4 (a) Place the extensometer probe over the brass pin and hold
the probe perpendicular to the surface of the bush
(i.e. generally vertical).
(b) Apply a firm downwards pressure to the probe and allow
10 seconds for the reading to be established.
6.5 Record the readings on form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL - SLAB
MOVEMENT TMF-3012-OP-0259. Compare with previous reading,
and if the difference is 0.2mm or more, check for
cleanliness of the extensometer surface and repeat the
reading.
6.6 (a) Replace the plastic cap, and cast iron cover.
(b) Apply grease to thread of the bolts, and screw the bolts
back into their holes using the socket, until they are a
snug tight fit. Report in the Work Done area of Job
sheet any covers with bolts missing, Replace missing
bolts during inspection.
7. Repeat step 6 for each extensometer test point along the
tunnel.
8. Notify the Control room on completion of the Job.
9. Ensure a copy of the completed form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL -
SLAB MOVEMENT TMF-3012-OP-0259 is forwarded to the Civil Team
Leader or his representative for evaluation on completion of
the job.

03 M Inspect and maintain Substation 5 Escape Stair Fan

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job as well
as prior to entering the stairwell.
2. (a) Refer to Maintenance Manual, Operating and Maintenance
manual for Mechanical Services - MCL Tunnels
M-STG-ME-27400.
(b) Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and
methodology of stair pressurisation commissioning tests.
3. Check the exhaust grill in the wall of the stairwell to
ensure it is free of debris that would restrict the flow of
air. [_ _]
4. Ensure that the door between the Domain Tunnel and the
stairwell is closed.
5. Request the traffic control operator to start the
Olympic Park supply fan SF-SS5-2 (ESP P04) from the TCR.
Ensure the fan starts. Check that the airflow direction is
into the stairwell. [_ _]
6. Check and inspect the Stairwell area.
(a) Ensure that the door between the Domain Tunnel and the
stairwell area is closed.
(b) Check each door for damage, as well check the rollers,
runners, hinges, handles, catches and counter-weights
for efficient operation. [_ _]
(c) With the supply air fan (SS-SS5-2) operating, record the
differential air pressure within the stairwell. Record
readings less than 50Pa in the Work Done area of the Job
sheet. Raise a new job sheet for repairs that require
further action. [_ _]
(d) At each door, starting from the tunnel and then the door
at the head of the stairs.
Arrange the door catch to be non-functioning, then using
a spring balance, measure the force required to open the
door. Record the results in the Work Done area of the
Job sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required, as
well advise the maintenance superintendent for further
investigation. [_ _]
(e) Check the time taken for the air pressure to return to
the static reading. Record in the Work Done area of the
job sheet if time is greater than 2 minutes. Notify the
superintendent for further investigation.
(f) Chock each door open, then using an anemometer, measure
the velocity of air out of the open door. The reading is
to be with the door fully open and with no obstructions.
Record the results in the Work Done area of the Job sheet
if the air flow is less than 1 meter /sec. Raise a new
job sheet for repairs that require further action. [_ _]
(g) Check the fan and motor for undue noise and
vibrations. [_ _]
(h) Check the fan bearings for noise. [_ _]
(i ) Check the fan unit for damage, corrosion, missing
panel fixings, as well as checking the fixings of the
unit for security. [_ _]
7. Ensure the action of opening a stairwell door;
(a) Generates an alarm at the TCR workstation.
(b) Causes the fan speed to vary to maintain a positive
pressure in the stairwell.
8. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes, with the door in both
the open and the closed position then advise the traffic
control room to shut the fan down and to turn OFF the
lighting after leaving the stairwell, ensuring that the door
to the tunnel is closed.
9. Ensure the stairwell is clean and all rubbish and debris is
removed from the stairwell. [_ _]
10. Ensure the door between the stairwell and the Domain Tunnel
is closed.
11. Notify the Control Room on completion of the job.
12. Raise a new job sheet for repairs that require further
action.

06 M BT Lighting Levels Measurement

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Carry out the six monthly Burnley tunnel lighting levels
inspection.
2. This job is to be carried out during a tunnel closure.
3. Check calibration date on light meter and spare battery,
thermometer and marker strips prior to carrying out lighting
levels measurement.
4. Location nominated for carrying out lighting measurement
includes the following fire box locations:
B9, B14, B19, B24, B30, B35, B41, B45, B49
To assist with identifying the exact points of measurement,
eight (8) marker strips should be laid out at 4m interval at
the location being measured. At each location, the 4m
intervals have been marked on site with studs embedded into
line marking on edge of the carriageway. The marker strips
should be placed adjacent to the studs.
5. Measurement area should be bollarded off.
6. At each measurement location:
a. Measure ambient temperature
b. Check for the following external factor prior to taking
measurements:
i. Car Headlights - should be at least 120m (2 fire boxes)
from measurement location.
ii. Headlights and flashing beacons on the work vehicle
should be switched off when taking measurement.
iii. Illuminated arrow sign boards should be used on work
vehicles and should be facing away from measurement
location.
iv. Shadowing from people - no persons to be within 20m of
measurement point, except person taking measurement,
who should be in crouched position.
c. Measure Lighting Levels and record values on Form
TMF-3012-OP-0392.

operations. TLO Maintenance Manager to sign Work Permit and the works

out only within times specified on the Work permit..

and expected alarms. Maintain radio contact at all times.

(M-STG-VE-26060).
5. At the PMCS in the control room.

action. [_ _]

abnormalities in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job sheet.
report any events and or trends
to the Maintenance Superintendant that may suggest some
abnormal function. [_ _]

if greater than FLC 403A.

operating fan motor.

greater then 80?C in the ""Work
Done"" area of the job sheet for further action. [_ _]

the PMCS screen in
control room and ensure less than 30 ppm prior to commencing

6. Access to the Swan St. ventilation station is through double locked
doors at rear
of Substation 2 and then by a ladder down the shaft.

(b) The fan motor is accessed from level 5,
(c) The fan damper is accessed from level 6.

OPERATIONAL

OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT WHENEVER WORK IS BEING CARRIED OUT IN

WORKIN

TIMES.

starter cubicle & inspect the cubicle & wiring connections.

OPERATING
FAN INLET GUARD, AS THE AIR IS FLOWING AT APPROX 35kmh.
8.2 Static Checks
(a) Press the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton adjacent to the motor.
(b) Check the condition of anti-vibration mountings and ensure that
the rubber bushing
is moved freely, adjust if required. [_ _]
(c) Examine the grease that has been discharged from the motor
bearings for any noticeable
colour changes. [_ _]
(d) Open the local electrical junction box, inspect the electrical
wiring and connections,
inspect all glands for tightness. [_ _]
(e) Visually inspect the motor for evidence of condensation,
whitepowder or similar.
Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any
evidence of condensation,
powder and the like and notify the Team Leader or his
representative. [_ _]
(f) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and
heater windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motorwindings and the
winding heater bridge. Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth. Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
theheater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(vii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(viii) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works. Include the Job Number of the new job in the
Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate. Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.

(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
8.4 Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION: ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.

at the MCC.

system. Examine the grease for changes of colour. [_ _]
(g) Check the fan for any abnormal noises or vibrations. [_
_]

(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.

01 M Inspection & test running of the generator

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
Supply to ensure it is operating in the normal
standby-back-up mode. [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
MODE.
4. General inspection. Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
(a) Check that the generator was left in "" AUTO "" [_ _]
(b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuels and water. [_ _]
(c) Check oil level. [_ _]
(d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates. [_ _]
(e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ). [_ _]
(f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts [_ _]
(g) Record the battery voltage in the Work Done area of the
job sheet. [_ _]
(h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
Physically open the cap,as gauge could be
misleading. [_ _]
(j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
with the last entry. [_ _]
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch on the generator DC
panel to RUN let the engine run for at least 5 minutes,
then turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch back to AUTO
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from AUTOMATIC CONTROL to EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST run the
generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared, and
that there are no unusual noises or vibrations. [_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature. [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back to
AUTOMATIC CONTROL, the generator will continune to run
for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
6. Record the hours run for the generator (from the hour run
meter) and update the Plant Usage in Mainpac from Plant
RHMouse click select Open then Meter Readings in edit mode
add Usage [_________hrs].
7. (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises. [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet. [_ _]
8. Fill in the Generator Log Book and record anything outside
normal parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
Raise a new job for any works requiring further repairs.
Priority High P1.
9. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

(i) The NRV should close with a sharp audible metallic
sound
(ii) The counterweight returning to it's pre-start

(iii) backflow through pump should cease within 30 seconds.

operation of the NRV monitored again. [_ _]
If a faulty closure is still suspected, report the fault
for corrective maintenance.
(e) Re-grease Motor bearings and Pump main bearing using
general multi purpose grease.
(f) Clean bottom of pump housing where drain water is
collected.

05 Y inspection of Smoke Duct and Exhaust Fan Bolts

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Inspection to be carried out during tunnel shuts.
2. This work is to be carried out by a sub-contractor, all
necessary Work Permits and HSE documentation to be submitted
prior to commencement of work.
3. Inspect the bolts anchoring the smoke duct and the jet fans
throughout the Tunnel as set out in INTICO leter dated
8 September 2004 and Visual Inspection Report 01135_VT.001A
dated 19-07-2004.
4. Submit report following completion of the works.
******************************************************
Recommendations for inspection and testing of the smoke
duct anchor bolts
There are two particular circumstances that suggest that the anchors
supporting the smoke duct should be
subject to testing and inspection at a higher level than for general
civil engineering construction:
1. The anchors are critical to keeping the precast concrete segments of
the smoke duct in place, and if one
of these segments fell, the consequences would be very severe.
2. The anchors are drilled-in to the concrete tunnel lining which has
developed cracking over the time since
construction. If a crack in the tunnel lining passes through an anchor
bolt hole, it will reduce the load
carrying capacity of the anchor.
With these circumstances in mind, the following inspection and testing
program is recommended:
Every five years undertake a visual inspection of the exposed end of
every anchor bolt that supports the smoke
duct. Check the following (responses indicating no defects are shown in
brackets):
1. Is there any corrosion of the anchor bolt assembly? (NO)
2. Are the nut and anchor bolt tight (check for finger tight only)?
(YES)
3. Is there at least one full thread exposed beyond the nut? (YES)
4. Is there any cracking in the tunnel concrete lining that appears to
pass through the anchor bolt hole?
(NO)
5. Is there any evidence of movement (since construction) in the gap
between the precast segment of the
smoke duct and the tunnel concrete lining? (NO)
In addition to checking these five points, it is necessary to check the
length of embedment of the anchor bolt. To
do this, measure the gap between the precast segment of the smoke duct
and the tunnel concrete lining, and add
to this distance the length of anchor bolt that is exposed beyond the
nut. The sum of the two
lengths should be no more than 60mm.
If the visual inspection indicates that the bolt installation may be
defective, take photographs of the defect for
review and assessment of remedial measures. If defects are found, the
inspection frequency will need to be
reviewed.
For further details of inspections refer
G:\TFM\Operations\Structures Level 2 Inspections\Smoke Duct Anchor
bolts- Recommendation fo inspection & Testing (Diagram in Page 3, 10
February 2010)

03 M Inspection of SL TSH UPS - Fentons systems

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to entering each Technical
Shelter.
2. Three Month Service Plan Reference : Fenton Users
Manual - Uninterruptible Power Supplies"" On-Line Series
UME V. 5.2 4kVA, 6kVA, 8kVA, 10kVA.
3. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
charged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037. [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 13.5
and 13.6 volts: A voltage above 13.8 volts will
indicate a battery fault. ]
4. (a) Press the ""Control"" button on the UPS, followed by the
"Down Arrow"" button until the message CONTROL BYPASS MODE
appears.
(b) Press the "Control" button and "Enter" button
simultaneously, the UPS will transfer into the bypass
mode.
,, **If at anytime during load transfer the UPS ,,,,,,
malfunctions, notify TCR prior to continuing.**
c) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions. The
"Bypass O/P" indicator should be illuminated. [_ _]
(d) Contact the Traffic Control Room to confirm receipt of
alarm condition. [_ _]
(e) Scroll through menu using the "Display" button followed
by the "Down Arrow"
(f) Remove side covers from the UPS. WARNING THE UPS IS
STILL ALIVE.
(g) Visually inspect the interior of the UPS for accumulated
dust, connections or other components that may show
obvious distress. [_ _]
(h) Check that both the front and rear fans are operating
(The front fan is thermostatically controlled). [_ _]
(i) Press the "Control" button, then press the "Down Arrow"
until the message "CONTROL INVERTOR MODE" appears. [_ _]
(j) Press the "Control" button and the "Enter" button
simultaneously, wait approx 10 seconds until the UPS
reverts back to its normal operation. [_ _]
5. (a) Contact TCR prior to isolating.
,, Switch to the OFF position the wall mounted isolator or
CB1, on the rear of the UPS to transfer the load to the
batteries. Check with TCR once load has been transferred
to batteries that a power failure has not occurred.
,, **Do not turn isolator back on for 20 seconds as this may
cause damage to the equipment.**
NOTE: Ensure that the Circuit breaker (C/B2) on the rear of
the UPS is not accidentally turned off at this stage
as CB2 isolates the batteries.
(b) Continue with the UPS supplying the load from the
batteries for at least 10 minutes.
(c) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037. [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 13.5
and 13.6 volts: A voltage above 13.8 volts will
indicate a battery fault. ]
(d) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions. The
"On Battery " indicator should be illuminated. [_ _]
(e) Scroll through menu using the "Display" button followed
by the "Down Arrow". Record the voltage and current
details on form UPS Battery Test Sheet
TMF-3012-OP-0037 [_ _].
(f) Switch to the ON position the wall mounted isolator or
normal supply.
6. Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
Batteries.
(b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on side
panel door, is in the upright position and is not
tripped. [_ _]
(c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
CB ( nominally 217V. ) [_ _]
7. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the " Work
Done " area of the job sheet.
8. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
9. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

03 M inspect of LIEBERT AC units mounted within Mezz Lvl

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Access to the Mobile telephone rooms, RRB room, ERE 00 and
ERE01 is via the Grant Street Stairwell. The rooms are
located on the mezzanine floor adjacent to ERE01.
The Air Conditioners and the condensers are separate units.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Unit
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer. Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the
thermostat setting. [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with
new setpoint and verify temperature is consistent
with ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer. [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting. [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer. [_ _]
NOTE: LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm. [_ _]
4.4. Check the filters and replace if necessary
(a) RRB Room and ERE 01 - Filter type Liebert size
650x590x75 mm. [_ _]
(b) ERE 00 - Filter type Liebert size 500 x 450 x
50mm. [_ _]
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm drain line is
clear. [_ _]
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation. [_ _]
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation. [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running. [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFFusing the local isolating switch. [_ _]
5.4. Inspect for loose connections or leaking coils. [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the fan isolating switch. [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit. [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits. [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish. [_ _]
7.0. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record
the results on form Equipment Room Inspections
TMF-3012-OP-0347. Ensure the form Equipment Room
Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347 is returned to the Electrical
Electronics Supervisor or his representative. Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Team Leader or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Minor inspect & test run of the SL TSH generators

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The generator minor service ""TYPE A"" , as set out in the
Cummins Maintenance Report, shall be carried out by the
sub-contractor on the generator.
2. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
3. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
4. Minor Service TYPE A Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's
Manual 960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012].
The sub-contractor shall carry out the service as per items
listed on the maintenance report column A and test as per
paragraph 5.
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch on the generator DC
panel to RUN let the engine run for at least 5 minutes,
then turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch back to AUTO
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from AUTOMATIC CONTROL to EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST run the
generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations. [_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature. [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switch board back
to AUTOMATIC CONTROL the generator will continue to run
for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
6. Record the hours run for each generator (from the hour run
meter) and record in the Mainpac Hours Run system for the
appropriate machine on the Plant Usage Tab.
7. Fill in the Generator Log Book

03 M Inspect and maintain Yarra Crossing Escape Stair Fan

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job as well as prior
to entering the stairwell.
2. (a) Refer to Maintenance Manual, ""Operating and Maintenance manual
for Mechanical
Services - MCL Tunnels"" M-STG-ME-27400.
(b) Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation
commissioning tests.
3. Check the exhaust grill in the wall of the stairwell to ensure it is
free of debris that would
restrict the flow of air. [_ _]
4. Ensure that the door between the Domain Tunnel and the stairwell is
closed.
5. Check that the door in the link walkway, isolating the stairwell
fromthe sub-station is closed.
6. Check that both the inlet and exhaust silencers are free from debris
(Use a torch from the
inlet)
7. Request the traffic control operator to start the fan SA-YPS-01
(ESF-P06) from the TCR.
Ensure the fan starts. Check that the airflow direction is into the
stairwell. [_ _]
8. NOTE: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire brigade. It
will register on the local FIP
and CCCS as a local alarm.
Remove the access cover over the smoke detector, direct ""test
smoke"" from a smoke
generator, as specified on the container, onto the smoke detector
(on the inlet duct). Check
that an alarm actuates on the local fire indicator panel. The
smoke detector must be in
fault for approx 2? mins for the fan to stop and for an alarm to
generate on the CCCS. [_ _]
9. Check and inspect the Stairwell area.
(a) Check the inlet grill to the substation, to ensure that it is
notdamaged and is free of debris
that would restrict the free flow of air. [___]
(b) Ensure that the door between the Domain Tunnel and the stairwell
area is closed.
(c) Check each door for damage, as well check the rollers, runners,
hinges, handles,
catches, and counter-weights for efficient operation. [_ _]
(d) With the supply air fan SA-YPS-01 ( ESF-P06) operating, record
the differential air
pressure within the stairwell and at substation level. Record
readings less than 50Pa in
the ""Work Done' area of the Job sheet. Notify the
superintendent for further
investigation. [_ _]
(e) At each of the doors, starting from the tunnel and working
towards the fan.
Arrange the door catch to be non-functioning, then using a
spring balance, measure the
force required to open the door. Record the results in the
Work Done"" area of the Job
sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required, as well advise
the maintenance
superintendent for further investigation. [_ _]
(f ) Check the time taken for the air pressure to return to the
static reading. Record in the
""Work Done"" area of the job sheet if time is greater than 2
minutes. Notify the
superintendent for further investigation.
(g) Chock each door open, then using an anemometer, measure the
velocity of air out of the
open door. The reading is to be with the door fully open and
with no obstructions.
Record the results in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job sheet
if the air flow is less
than 1 meter /sec as well advise the maintenance
investigation. [_ _]
(h) Check the fan and motor for undue noise and vibrations. [_ _]
(i ) Check the fan bearings for noise. [_ _]
(j ) Check the fan unit for damage, corrosion, missing panel
fixings, as well as checking
the fixings of the unit for security. [_ _]
10. Ensure the action of opening a stairwell door;
(a) Generates an alarm at the TCR workstation.
(b) Causes the fan speed to vary to maintain a positive pressure
inthe stairwell.
(c) To replicate the action of the smoke detector, remove the
YARRACROSSING EGRESS
STAIR FAN RELAY (mounted in the rear compartment of the
localFIP) for at least two and
a half minutes to ensure the fan stops. Replace the relay
once the action is
confirmed [_ _] (A local alarm will register on the CCCS.
The fire brigade
will not be called)
11. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes, with the door in both the open
and the closed position
then advise the traffic control room to shut the fan down and to
turn OFF the lighting after
leaving the stairwell, ensuring that the door to the tunnel is
12. Ensure the stairwell is clean and all rubbish and debris is removed
from the stairwell. [_ _]
13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the ""Work Done"" area
of the Job Sheet.
14. Ensure the door between the stairwell and the Domain Tunnel is
15. Notify the Control Room on completion of the job.

03 M Measure & report on DT GW TNL Bay flows in drainage sys
The frequency of this job can be adjusted as history of
groundwater flows are established.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 25 & 26.
3. For detail of Job, refer to Work Instruction, DOMAIN TUNNEL
DRAINAGE TMI-3012-OP-0025
4. At each groundwater pit:record the Volume/time water flow
from each agi-pipe into each groundwater pit (and it's
direction of flow).
At each groundwater pit, to obtain readings;
(a) Readings are carried out by collecting the water, from
the agi-pipe, in a calibrated measuring container for 5
to 10 seconds.
e.g. 800 mls/10 secs
450 mls/10 secs
1 litre /8 secs.
Record the details on the Form DOMAIN TUNNEL - BAY FLOW
MONITORING TMF-3012-OP-0205.
5. Inspect the pits and pipes using a torch and mirror and or by
observation, looking for Calcite deposits or debris that
could restrict water flow. Record the details on the Form
DOMAIN TUNNEL - BAY FLOW MONITORING TMF-3012-OP-0205.
6. Ensure the completed copy of the form DOMAIN TUNNEL - BAY
FLOW MONITORING TMF-3012-OP-0205 is forwarded to the Civil
Team Leader for evaluation on completion of the job.
Increased flows could indicate a new or increased source of
groundwater entering the tunnel, and would need to be
investigated.
6. Record anything outside normal parameters in the Work Done
area of the job sheet.
7. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

ASSET CONDITION RATING
Rate the Condition of the Asset.
Note:
[ 1 ] - Excellent.
Asset is new or in as new condition
[ 2 ] - Good.
Asset is fully operational, well presented, performing

[ 3 ] - Fair.

deterioration that will result is some intervention
works possibly within the next 12 months. May not be
performing it's intended function to the full degree.

signs of deterioration that will require intervention
works within the next 3 months. Not performing it's
intended function.

of Refuges 1, 2 and 3.

use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events. [_ _]

1. Check the interior and external lighting (e.g. strobe etc)
for operation, including the operational tube within EXIT
signs, replace or repair any faulty lighting fixture. [_ _]
2. Visually inspect the fire alarm panel external surfaces for
general operation. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions and notify the Electrical Electrical team leader or
his representative of any outstanding works required. [_ _]
3. Clean lighting diffusers (including emergency and Exit
lighting) and lens of accumulated dust and debris. [_ _]
4. Check operation of phone and clean of accumulated dust.
Record anything abnormal in the Work Done area of the Job
Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his representative
of outstanding actions. [_ _]

operation and security. Check with the Traffic Control Room
Operator to confirm the receipt of an alarm. Repair faulty
of defective switches. Record details of outstanding defects
in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet. [_ _]
6. Check and clean cable trays for accumulated debris. Record
anything abnormal in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his representative of
outstanding actions. Include in the Related Job field of
the new and this job, the job number of the alternate
job. [_ _]
C Refuge Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture
ingress. Inspect for source of any water. Record any
details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform the
Team Leader or his representative. [_ _]
2. Check that all area(s) of the refuges are not obstructed by
furnishings and or stored items. Remove any
obstruction. [_ _]
3. Check the doors for damage and operation, lubricate and
repair as required and record in the Work Done area of the
Job Sheet. Inform the Team Leader or his representative
of any outstanding works. [_ _]
4. Clean exterior surfaces of cabinets where necessary. [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets and
ceilings. [_ _]
6. Remove from site all accumulated rubbish and debris. [_ _]
7. Sweep and vacuum all floor surfaces as well as
stairways. [_ _]
8. Clean hand rails (if applicable) of dust and dirt. [_ _]
9. Visually inspect the metal upstands (external aids assisting
access from tunnel to platform) for damage or corrosion.
Repair and or remove corrosion and clean then cover with Cold
Gal. [_ _]
10. Prior to leaving the refuge arrange with the traffic Control
room to ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service

(b) All Lighting turned OFF [_ _] and ensure
(c) All Enclosures are closed and locked. [_ _]

Mechanical
Services - MCL Tunnels"" M-STG-ME-27400.

and alignment. [_ _]
9. Work plan for SF-YPS-1

AS3000. [_ _]

anti-condensation heater. Record
any results in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet that
does not meet specifications
set out in AS3000. [_ _]

11. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal parameters
in the ""Work Done""
area of the job Sheet. [_ _]

12 M Tst of batt emerg and exit lights SUB 2 & Swan St Shaft

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 2 & SWAN ST SHAFT
TMF-3012-OP-0243, only those fittings in which the tubes have
been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 2 & SWAN ST SHAFT
TMF-3012-OP-0243, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 2 & SWAN ST SHAFT TMF-3012-OP-0243, only
those light fittings that the battery charger operation
indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or
damaged diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE
TEST - SUB 2 & SWAN ST SHAFT TMF-3012-OP-0243 for subsequent
replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Inspection of VMS unit

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane.
2. Set up slane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12 or 13.
4. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment and
or tools do not fall from the gantry. Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry. Adhere to safety
instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 Working on Gantry Structures.
5. Visually check for loose or missing nuts and bolts and for
rusted areas nuts or bolts.
Clean with wire brush and spray with ""cold gal"" or
equivalent. This shold be done with care and to avoid
overspray. [_ _]
6. Carry out preventative maintenance as per Cegelec Securite &
Signalisation O & M manual Volume 4 Maintenance Manual,
ED/BC/MCC/O&M/04, Section 8 [M-MCL-TM-1551].
(a) Carry out Luminance test. Traffic Contro Room assistance
required (Section 8.2.4.2.) [_ _]
(b) Test interior lights (Section 8.2.5.) [_ _]
(c) Check pilot light (Section 8.2.7.) [_ _]
(d) Test heater (Section 8.2.8.) [_ _]
(e) Test ground fault circuit breaker (Section 8.2.9.) [_ _]
(f) Check lightning arrestor fuses (Section 8.2.10.)
[_ _]
(g) Clean CD501/CD502 board transformers with brush or
portable vacuum/blower [_ _]
(h) Test AC voltages (Section 8.2.11.) [_ _]
(i) Clean controller cabinet with vacuum/ blower. [_ _]
(j) Clean external face of lenses for each pixel with
""Windex"" or equivalent and clean rags. Inspect internal
face of lens for accumulation of dust and clean with
brush or vacuum/blower if required. [_ _]
(k) Test (push button) on all character boards and check if
all pixel arrays are operational. [_ _]
7. On completion record anything outside normal parameters in
the ""Work Done"" section of the Job Sheet and raise new
corrective action Job Sheet is required.
8. Notify control room on departure.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

Tunnel Axial Fans
& Associated Attenuators Maintenance Manual"" M-EET-VE-26250.

structure 20m
south-west of the Burnley Vent Station and down the stairwell to
Emergency Egress
Tunnel entry door. SF-EET-001 (CPF P11) is accessed via a hatch in
the stairwell wall.

debris that would restrict the
airflow. [_ _]
6. On entering the stairwell, actuate the lights using the manual
switchinside the doorway.

by the TCR
operators, once they are notified that all personnel are
clear of both the tunnel and
the stairwell.

a torch from either
end of fan unit). Silencers consist of aerofoils mounted in the
outer shell. Check that the
aerofoil attachments are secure. [_ _]
8. Ensure that the door at the base of the stairwell is closed, as well
there are another

to start the fan sequence. [_ _]

direction is into
the stairwell and EET (as marked on the fan), and that there

stairwell air pressure
at a minimum of 50 Pa. Record the result in the ""Work

if the reading is less than 50 Pa. Compare the traffic
control room reading too. [_ _]
(c) Arrange the door catches of the external exit door (at
ground level) to be
non-functioning then using a spring balance, measure the

the door. Record the result in the ""Work Done"" area of

greater than 11kg is required. Raise a Corrective job
sheet to repair any door
requiring repair. [_ _]

runners, hinges, handles,
catches, counter-weights and or door-closers for
efficient operation. [_ _]

06 W Meas, report on BT V-Ntch flow, GW & DW Pits, Bore Lvl
** Prior to commencement Maintenance Crew to be issued white
disposable overalls to be worn whilst carrying out Tunnel
Drainage tasks.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 21, 22, 25, 26
3. Reference:
(a) Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0031.
(b) Operation & Maintenance Manual - Tunnel Drainage Stage 2
Design Report R-STG-EN-006 Rev 1.
4. Civil Team Leader or representative is to:
(a) Select groundwater and dirty water pits to be inspected
on forms BURNLEY TUNNEL GROUND WATER INSPECTIONS
TMF-3012-OP-0232 and
BURNLEY TUNNEL DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTIONS
TMF-3012-OP-0253 respectively. Selection should be with
the knowledge of past results and a random selection
including examination of previous inspections carried out
as part of the V Notch and Bay Flow inspections
(b) Previous inspection forms are to be issued to the
maintenance crew to compare results when carrying out
inspections.
(c) V-Notch Pits 14A, 66, 204 & 237 shall be inspected on
each occasion.
5. (a) Inspect the groundwater pits circled on BURNLEY TUNNEL
GROUNDWATER PIT INSPECTION"" TMF-3012-OP-0232.
(i) Use a torch to inspect each pipe and associated pits
for cleanliness and the accumulation of calcites.
(ii) Record the build up of calcites in the pipes and pits
in Millimetres (mm). When a build up of 50mm occurs
in a 200mm pipe or a 25mm in a 100mm pipe. Cleaning
is required.
(iii) Record a description of the calcite. e.g. slimy,
milky or hard etc.
(iv) Record the results on form BURNLEY TUNNEL GROUNDWATER
PIT INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0232.
(b) Inspect the Dirtywater pits circled on BURNLEY TUNNEL
DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0253. Use a torch
to inspect each pipe and associated pits for cleanliness
and the accumulation of debris. Record the related
details regarding accumulation of silts, debris, and
other foreign materials within pits on the form.
(c) Ensure pit covers are replaced and seated correctly after
each pit inspection.
6. V-Notch Readings
(a) Prior to taking readings of dirty water (Right hand side
of tunnel) pit numbers 14A & 66 and Ground water (Left
hand side of tunnel) pit numbers 204 & 237, ensure the
V-notch weir is clear of calcites and debris. Clean
thoroughly if required.
(b) Use a measuring stick obtain the depth of the V-notch
flow by
(i) Place the stick in the cup
(ii) Remove the stick and measure the height of the water
mark on the stick.
(c) Record the depth of water flowing over the V-Notch weir
in mm on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT
FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & RATE OF RISE
TMF-3012-OP-0234.
(d) If readings differ markedly from previous readings, then
take measurement again to confirm results.
(e) Note that inspection V-Notch pits is to be carried out
as per step 5.
7. Swan Street Groundwater Pit Inflow Readings
(a) Once V-Notch 221has been read, then proceed to the Swan
Street Pumping Station to take the rate of inflow
reading.
(b) Proceed to the Pump Control centre
(c) Notify the TCR that all pumps are to be switched OFF.
(d) Switch OFF all pumps (Have an electrician perform this
duty).
(e) Return back to the sump pumping room and close all three
gate valves.
(f) Return to the pump control centre and start by recording
the sump level, then 10 minutes later take another
reading of the sump level.
(g) Record the sump start and finish level, in millimetres,
on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS,
GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & RATE OF RISE TMF-3012-OP-0234.
(h) Record on the inspection sheet any thing out of the
ordinary.
(i) Return all gate valves to their normal OPEN condition and
switch the pumps back to automatic operation. Then
proceed with the rest of the readings and inspections.
8. Burnley Tunnel Groundwater Bore Level (located between fire
cabinets B45 & B46 RHS).
(a) Remove the BT bore-hole cover, then lower a string with a
weight attached into the bore-hole until the weight
touches the bottom of the bore-hole.
(b) Mark the string with a marker or pen, ensuring that the
weight is just touching the bottom and that there is no
undue slack in the string.
(c) Measure and record the total length of the string (Total
depth of bore-hole in millimetres)
(d) Measure and record the total length of the string that
was submerged in the bore-hole water (Depth of
groundwater in bore-hole in millimetres).
(e) Record the details on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE -
SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & RATE OF RISE
TMF-3012-OP-0234.
(f ) Ensure the cover is replaced and seated correctly.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
10. Ensure a completed copy of the forms BURNLEY TUNNEL
GROUNDWATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0232, BURNLEY
TUNNEL DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0253 and
BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE
LEVELS & RATE OF RISE TMF-3012-OP-0234 are forwarded to the
Civil Team Leader or representative on completion of the job
and prior to end of shift. Civil Team Leader or
representative is to record and sign off each form and raise
any actions (job sheets) for further inspection or cleaning
Increases in the flows measured in groundwater pits 204 &
237 should be followed up with a piezometer measurement for
the Burnley Tunnel.

24 M L2 Inspect the SUB 6 HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor under the
supervision of an
electrical/electronics technician.
3. Refer to Manual ""Merlin Gerin Masterpact Instruction Notice""
M-STG-EL-24030
4. Ensure that the Three monthly and twelve monthly HV electric
inspection has been
carried out.
5. (Substation 1A, 1B, 2A, 2B, 3A, 3B, 4A, 4B, 5A, 5B and 6 Schneider
Circuit breakers
and Isolators)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to be
recorded and reported
to the Electrical/electronics team leader or his representative.
(a) Thoroughly, visually inspect the circuit breakers and record andreport
any damaged
or worn parts.
(b) Inspect metal and insulating parts, remove dust and dirt and
clean in accordance
with the manufacturers instructions.
(e) Clean the switchgear enclosure (cubicle)
(f) Carefully examine bushings and insulators for cracks, chips or
partial discharging.
(g) Visually check and ensure that control devices are free of
accumulated dust deposits
by carefully cleaning.
(h)Check all un-insulated cable connections for correct tension.
Check and tighten
un-insulated bolts on cable connections where practical to do so.
(i) Check all earthing and cable connections including control
cubicle, inspecting for
loose connections and signs of broken strands. Tighten and or
repair as required.
(j) Visually inspect all auxiliary wiring, plugs and terminations.
(k) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across primary contacts.
(l) Check and record winding resistance of shunt trip and the close
coils. Compare
with previous years findings.
(m) Confirm correct operation of spring charge motors and interlock
devices.
(n) Inspect, clean and lubricate all moving parts of the switchgear
operating mechanisms
as described in the Manufacturer's Maintenance Instructions.
(o) Clean the exterior of switchgear cubicles of dirt and grime,
record areas of damaged
paintwork or areas that are corroded.
(p) Examine and clean all control relays, contactors, fuses etc,
confirming connections
and continuity of all wiring.
(q) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across cubicle bus bar
connections for all
phases if the bus bar is available.
(r) Perform insulation resistance tests with a 2500V insulation tester
for one minute
per test:
(i) With the CB closed each phase to the other phases and earth.
(ii) With the CB open, across the open contacts
This test shall be carried out after maintenance.
(s) Carry out a complete functional test on each circuit breaker,
including earth
switches ,and ensure correct operation including devices,
flags, interlocks etc.
(t) Trip and close the circuit breaker at least five times.
(u) Reinstall all parts and ensure all switchgear is fully
operational on completion of
the maintenance.
6. (Substation Protection)
DO NOT ATTEMPT SERVICE ON CURRENT TRANSFORMERS WHILE ENERGISED.
Extremely high voltages can be generated across the secondary
terminal of the current
transformer when OPEN circuited. Current transformers should be
short-circuited
during secondary injection testing. Jumper leads should be removed
when testing is
complete.
(a) Carry out continuity test from current transformers to relays by
primary injection,
functional test of trip, close. Alarm and control circuits by
operation of the relay and
physical inspection of all relays. ENSURE APPROPRIATE ALARMS
ARE
GENERATED BACK TO THE TRAFFIC CONTROL ROOM.
(b) Knee point / saturation test current transformers recording five
points across the
magnetisation curve as well as comparing results of each phase
/class and results
of previous testing.
(c) Record the settings of all protections relays, verify and record
the pick up and drop out
values, IDMT trip times for two points of trip curve via primary
injection or the Nulec TTS.
(d) When testing is complete, carefully check that all jumpers and
test leads have been
removed and that any connections removed for testing purposes
have been reinstated.
7. (Oil Filled Transformers Sub 6)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to be
(a) Draw sufficient sample of oil from each transformer for the
following tests to be carried
out: Diagnostic Gas Analysis, oil screening for moisture,
Resistivity, Interfacial tension
and acidity content. Arrange for the above tests to be carried
out by a suitably qualified
laboratory.
8. (Insulation Resistance Testing of High Voltage Cables)
(a) Carry out an Insulation resistance test on all of the insulated HVcables.
The test
shall be carried out using a 2500V insulation tester and shall
be tested:
(i) Between each and every phase conductor
(ii) Between each phase conductor and the earth conductor.
(b) Inspect each cable termination and seals for mechanical damage,
overheating,
tracking and or ingress of moisture. Record and report any
damage.
9. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet, inspection resultsrequiring
further corrective actions. Raise a new job sheet for any
outstanding works and
notify the Team Leader or his representative. Include in the
Related Job"" field
of the new and this job, the job number of the alternate Job. [_
_]
10. At each substation fill-in the log book. [_ _]

06 M Test batt backed emerg and exit lights SUB 6 & OMB

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 6 AND
OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE BUILDING TMF-3012-OP-0248, only
those fittings in which the tubes have been replaced.
EM/WP - 2 x 18w tube
EMG - 2 x 18w tube
EMG 1 - 1 x 10w Tungston Halogen
EMG 2 - 1 x 18w tube
EMG E - 1 x 10w tube
EX 1 - 2 x 10w tube
EM 2 - 2 x 26w tube
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 6 AND OPERATIONS AND
MAINTENANCE BUILDING TMF-3012-OP-0248, only those lights
which does not provide suitable area lighting for the
required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 6 AND OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE
BUILDING TMF-3012-OP-0248, only those light fittings that the
battery charger operation indicator does not function
correctly.
8. Remove any excess debris from within lighting diffusers.
9. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
10. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

06 M Jet Fan maintenance and lubrication.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Works to be carried out on one jet fan at a time so as to
not affect the operation of total tunnel ventilation
2. Notify control room prior to commencing work.
3. Set up lane closure as per Work Instruction TMI-3012-OP-0002
and Translink Operations Procedure PR-RS-OP-IR-020 Plan 27
or 28.
4. Reference Manual; Witt & Sohn, Operations and Maintenance
Manual , Certificate 18. (M-STG-VE-29047 )
5. In associated equipment room switch jet fan AUTO/OFF/MAN
selector switch to MAN and REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL switch to LOCAL
to enable control adjacent to jet fan. [_ _]
6. Running visual inspection
WARNING: DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF BODY IN INLET OR OUTLET
AIR STREAM WHEN FAN IS RUNNING.
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN.
(a) Start fan locally by pressing the START button on the
panel adjacent to the fan. [_ _]
(b) Check for any abnormal noise or movement from the
fan. [_ _]
(c) Check the fan unit vibration mountings and safety rods
for loose nuts and bolts. [_ _]
(d) Stop fan locally with the EMERGENCY STOP button. [_ _]
(e) If any non-conforming items are found, investigate
further in the static fan inspection. [_ _]
7. Static fan inspection
(a) Ensure the local EMERGENCY STOP button is engaged. [_ _]
(b) Conduct a thorough visual inspection for damage and
corrosion of the silencers, impeller, inlet cone, cable
connections, mounting frame and vibration attenuators.
Any cracks identified in the vicinity must be noted in
the "Work done" area of the job sheet for
further investigation. [_ _] Photo of Cracks found
will be required.
Any damage, especially to surface protection, must be
noted in the "Work done" area of the job sheet for
further investigation. [_ _]
(c) Carry out careful inspection of all supporting hardware
and screw connections, including the eight vibration bracket
installations and the four safety rod brackets. Using a
torque wrench, ensure that the accessible supporting screw
connections are secured and fixed with the correct torque
settings. [_ _]
NOTE: Torque Settings
M10 = 37Nm
M12 = 65Nm
M16 = 150Nm
M20 = 300Nm as per reference manual
in step 4
Bolts with Nylon washers should only be checked for
tightness. Do not torque as nylon washer get damaged
Do not torque anchor bolts in tunnel roof. Check for
tightness only.
(d) If any non-conforming items are found, record in the
"Work Done" area of the job sheet and rectify immediately
where possible to the requirements of the Witt & Sohn ,
Operations and Maintenance Manual , Certificate 18.
(M-STG-VE-29047). This inspection is carried out
externally via the inlet and exhaust ends using a
torch. [_ _]
(e) Remove cover to motor junction box and check the cable
connections visually for tightness and evidence of
overheating.
8. Lubrication
(a) Release the key operated EMERGENCY STOP button, restart
fan locally.
(b) Regrease bearings using grease gun on nipples onside of
fan with Mobilith SHC220 (TF000021) grease, 10 pumps of
hand grease gun per grease nipple.
Note: Lubrication should be carried out between 3,000
and 4,000 hours running time when access is available.
Do not over grease. [_ _]
(c) Stop fan using local EMERGENCY STOP button
(d) Release the EMERGENCY STOP button using a Key. (Remove
the key) [_ _]
9. Equipment Room Control Panel.
(a) Switch fan REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch to REMOTE to
enable control at panel
(b) Carry out visual internal and external inspection of the
control panel for damage evidence of insect infestation,
ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as
required). [_ _]
(c) Check cable connections visually for tightness and signs
of overheating and inspect electrical control
equipment [_ _]
(d) Start fan with START pushbutton on panel and leave
running for approximately 5 minutes
(e) Check ammeter at electrical panel to verify fan is
operating within current limits FLC 100A. [_ _]
(f ) Using an infra red thermometer check the temperature of
the connections and power cables to the motor. Record in
the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet if the temperature
recorded is more that 10? to 15? C above ambient. [_ _]
(g) Record the "hours run" from the Jet Fan hour run meter
on the panel door in the "Work Done"" area of the job
sheet. [_ _]
Note: Hour run meters are on the control panels for
non-reversing fans only.
Reversing fans hour run readings are obtainable
from the PMCS screens in the control room
10. Return the LOCAL/OFF/REMOTE switch to the OFF position and
the AUTO/OFF/MAN fan selector switch to the AUTO
position. [_ _]
11. Advise the Traffic control room operator that control of the
fan is returned to the control room. [_ _]
12. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable,
Leaky Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipework,
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and bring to the attention
of the Team Leader Electrical or his representative.
13. Notify control room on completion of work.
14. Enter the hours run for the jet fan into the Plant item
screen, then select the usage tab.
