06 W Inspect, Meas, Report on DT GW drn pits, V-Notch-pipes
** Prior to commencement Maintenance Crew to be issued white
disposable overalls to be worn whilst carrying out Tunnel
Drainage tasks.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 21, 22, 25, 26
3. Reference:
(a) Work Instruction, DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0025.
(b) Operation & Maintenance Manual - Tunnel Drainage Stage 2
Design Report R-STG-EN-006 Rev 1.
4. Civil Team Leader or representative is to:
(a) Select groundwater and dirty water pits to be inspected
on forms DOMAIN TUNNEL GROUND WATER PIT INSPECTIONS
TMF-3012-OP-0231 and DOMAIN TUNNEL DIRTY WATER PIT
INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0255 respectively. Selection
should be with the knowledge of past results and a random
selection including examination of previous inspections
carried out as part of the V Notch and Bay Flow
inspections
(b) Previous inspection forms are to be issued to the
maintenance crew to compare results when carrying out
inspections.
(c) V-Notch Pits 14A, 66, 204 & 237 shall be inspected on
each occasion.
5. (a) Inspect the groundwater pits circled on DOMAIN TUNNEL
GROUNDWATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0231.
(i) Use a torch to inspect each pipe and associated pits
for cleanliness and the accumulation of calcites.
(ii) Record the build up of calcites in the pipes and pits
in Millimetres (mm). When a build up of 50mm occurs
in a 200mm pipe or a 25mm in a 100mm pipe cleaning is
required.
(iii) Record a description of the calcite. e.g. slimy,
milky or hard etc.
(iv) Record the results on form DOMAIN TUNNEL GROUNDWATER
PIT INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0231.
(b) Inspect the Dirtywater pits circled on DOMAIN TUNNEL
DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0255.
Use a torch to inspect each pipe and associated pits for
cleanliness and the accumulation of debris. Record the
related details regarding accumulation of silts, debris,
and other foreign materials within pits on the form.
(c) Ensure pit covers are replaced and seated correctly after
each pit inspection.
6. V-Notch Readings
(a) Prior to taking readings of ground water (Right hand side
of tunnel) pit numbers 325, 323, 321 & 316 and the dirty
water (Left hand side of tunnel) pit numbers 142, 139,
137 & 124, ensure the V-notch weir is clear of calcites
and debris. Clean thoroughly if required.
(b) Use a measuring stick obtain the depth of the V-notch
flow by
(i) Place the stick in the cup
(ii) Remove the stick and measure the height of the water
mark on the stick.
(c) Record the depth of water flowing over the V-Notch weir
in mm on the form DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS,
GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & YARRA CROSSING GROUNDWATER PIT
INFLOW TMF-3012-OP-0204.
(d) If readings differ markedly from previous readings, then
take measurement again to confirm results.
(e) Note that inspection V-Notch pits is to be carried out
as per step 5.
7. (a) Once V-Notch 323 has been read, then proceed to the sump
pumping room to take a water inflow reading.
(b) Proceed up the exit stairs to the pump control room
(c) Notify the control room that all pumps are to be switched
OFF.
(d) Switch OFF all the pumps (Have an electrician perform
this duty).
(e) Return back down to the sump pumping room and close all
three gate valves
(f) Return back up stairs to the pump control room and start
by recording the sump level, then 10 minutes later take
another reading of the sump level.
(g) Record the sump start and finish level, in millimetres,
on the form DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS,
(h) Record on the inspection sheet anything out of the
ordinary.
(i) Return all gate valves to their normal OPEN condition
and switch the pumps back to automatic operation. Then
proceed with the rest of the readings and inspections.
8. Domain Tunnel Groundwater Bore Level (located between fire
cabinets D16 & D17 LHS).
(a) Remove the DT bore-hole cover, then lower a string with a
weight attached into the bore-hole until the weight
touches the bottom of the bore-hole.
(b) Mark the string with a marker or pen, ensuring that the
weight is just touching the bottom and that there is no
undue slack in the string.
(c) Measure and record the total length of the string (Total
depth of bore-hole in millimetres)
(d) Measure and record the total length of the string that
was submerged in the bore-hole water (Depth of
groundwater in bore-hole in millimetres).
(e) Record the details on the form DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE -
SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & YARRA CROSSING
GROUNDWATER PIT INFLOW TMF-3012-OP-0204..
(f ) Ensure the cover is replaced and seated correctly.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
10. Ensure a completed copy of the forms
DOMAIN TUNNEL GROUNDWATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0231,
DOMAIN TUNNEL DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0255
and DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE
LEVELS & YARRA CROSSING GROUNDWATER PIT INFLOW
TMF-3012-OP-0204. are forwarded to the Civil Team Leader or
his representative on completion of the job and prior to end
of shift. Civil Team Leader or representative is to record
and sign off each form and raise any actions (job sheets)
for further inspection or cleaning

03 M Inspect, Test & Clean Burnley Pump Station

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths,
lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting,
Brooms, Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders, Silicon
Lubricant Spray, Rodent Bait Station
A INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the pumps, Pump
station, Pump Station electrical installation as well the
cleaning, inspections and maintenance of the related controls.
B PUMPS AND PUMP STATION OPERATION
1. Notify control room before entry.
2. Access to wet well and valve pit is via gatic covers in the
pathway on south side of Burnley Portal.
WARNING: THE WET WELL AND VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED CONFINED
SPACES AND MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED SPACE
CONDITIONS.
3. Inspect Local Control Panel
(a) Check switchboard, situated in Sub-station 3, for
local alarm conditions.
(b) Carry out visual internal and external inspection of the
control panel for damage, evidence of insect infestation,
ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as required)
(c) Check cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating and inspect electrical control
equipment. [_ _]
(d) Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet the hours
run from the meter on the switchboard. [_ _]
4. Inspection of pump wet well and valve pit.
(a) Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the
valve pit, inspect both the wet well and the valve pit
for general cleanliness and debris. Clean if
required. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external condition of the pipework and
valves for evidence corrosion and leaks. [_ _]
5. Check the operation of pump PSBLYP1 (A1 Starter) by switching
the pump AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position and starting the pump by pressing the
START/STOP/RESET button.
(a) Measure the operating current and compare with the rated
current. (FLC 22A.). Record in the Work Done area of the
job sheet if results are outside normal limits. [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running or
vibration and abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Check that the cabling to the pump for damage and that it
is clear from possible damage. [_ _]
CAUTION: Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low
level alarm point as lack of submergence may cause
pumpset damage
6. Check non-return valve operation on shutting off pump by
pressing START/ STOP/RESET button. Full valve closure will
be indicated by;
(a) closing with an audible sharp metallic sound.
(b) backflow through pump should cease within 30 seconds
Valve closing with a duller sound or excessive backflow
(longer than 30 seconds) occuring may indicate debris
jammed in valve preventing full closure. Pump should be
re-started, run for 2 minutes and non-return valve
operation check repeated.
If faulty closure is still suspected, report for
corrective maintenance. [_ _]
Return AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to AUTO
position. [_ _]
7. Repeat steps 5 and 6 for pump PSBLYP2 (B1 Starter). [_ _]
8. Check operation of float switches, manually tripping floats
from ground level by lifting up High/High float and Low/Low
floats respectively and checking alarms are received at O&M
Control Room. [_ _]
9. (a) Check operation of level controller by pumping until pump
stops. Compare actual level with capacity meter on
switchboard. Wet well pump stop level is 4.6 m. below
top deck which equals 31% capacity. [_ _]
(b) Lift level controller sensor out of conduit and
carefully and gently clean recess in base.
10. Test operation of isolating valves by partial opening and
closing only. [_ _]
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Pump stations and
equipment etc,
in the Work Done section of the job sheet and report to
the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
12. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
13. Notify control room that inspection is completed.
C ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. On entering pump station, temporarily switch OFF ventilation
fans, if operating. [_ _]
2. On accessing the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere,
use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events. [_ _]
3. Check the interior lighting for operation, replace faulty
lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture. [_ _]
4. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within control panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor. Temperatures of ambient
plus 10?C should be considered abnormal and must be noted in
the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the abnormality.
Raise a new job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
5. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and components for evidence of burn
marks, unusual odours and overheating. Record anything
abnormal in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new jobsheet for any corrective action. Ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc. [_ _]
7. Visually inspect the enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required. Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
8. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage. [_ _]
9. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for
dust, grime and condensation, clean enclosures of any
accumulated dust, dirt and debris. [_ _]
10. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.
Clean or replace filters as required. [_ _]
11. Inspect systems, mounted within the control panel(s), for
faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged switches and
buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
12. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators. Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged
in the work done area of the job sheet and a new job
sheet raised to investigate and correct the
error. [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw connections, for security. [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose. [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
and debris. [_ _]
13. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.
14. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader
or his representative of any corrective actions. [_ _]
D. Building Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the control panel interior for evidence of moisture

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Work shall be carried out in designated times approved by

2. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the RHL lane
3. Access to this camera group is:

(b) Position 0 and 1.

6. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and the equipment mounted in the
cabinet is secure. [_ _]
(c) Check cables and terminations for signs of degradation,
re-terminate if necessary. [_ _]
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and are securely
fastened to the PT300.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.

not record the fact, for later replacement. [_ _]

inspecting the camera housing. This will prevent movement
of the PTZ . [_ _]
8. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation. Surface insect
spray may be applied if necessary to the housing exterior
but must not be applied to the interior of the housing or
to the housing glass. If ingress of moisture or insect
infestation is evident then carry out steps (d)
and (e). [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X cleaning fluid. [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater thermostat
(HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the operation of
the heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.
9. Reconnect the PTZ control cable to the PTZ controller and
re-instate the 240V power supply to the PTZ
controller. [_ _]
10. Notify the control room on completion and check the PTZ for
full movement and pre-programmed positions. If camera fails
to respond press the reset button on the PT 300 and wait
2 minutes then check again. [_ _]
11. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable,
Leaky Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipework,
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and bring to the
attention of the Team Leader Electrical or his
representative.

parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.

Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.

rectify any degraded operation. [_ _]

found. [_ _]

service at the condenser.

(b) Check the cooling fan(s) operation for efficiency and
rectifying any degraded operation. [_ _]
(c) Check the condenser for leaks, repair any faults
found. [_ _]

service at the humidifier (where fitted).

blockage. [_ _]

03 M Inspection of Smoke Exhaust Fans Olympic Park
WARNING:
ELECTRIC MOTORS CAN OPERATE AT A TEMPERATURE WHICH MAY CAUSE BURNS.
EXERCISE CAUTION WHEN ABOUT TO TOUCH MACHINERY WHICH MAY BE HOT.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to ventilation rooms and to
interrupt operations.
2. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
3. Reference manual, Fantech Pty Ltd. Olympic Park Portal Centrifugal
Fans. Operations and
Maintenance Manual. M-STG-VE-26200.
4. Check the fan outlet stacks and the protective mesh for accumulated
debris that may restrict
outlet damper operation. Use an extension ladder. (3m. wall) in
accordance with work instruction TM1-3012-SA-0121 Ladders- Safe use
to remove any debris. [_ _]
3. Fan Operation
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
CHAMBER.
CAUTION: DO NOT RUN MORE THAN 2 FANS AT ANY TIME.
Request the control room to open at least four tunnel smoke inlet
dampers.
CAUTION: A MINIMUM OF 4 INLET DAMPERS MUST BE OPEN BEFORE
OPERATING
THE FANS.
(a) Switch the fan AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position and start
the fan using the START/STOP/RESET pushbutton. Run the fan
for 30 minutes.
(b) Check that the outlet damper opens fully. [_ _]
The following checks shall be made using touch, sight and hearing.
Perceived problems
will be further investigated using instrumentation.
(a) Check the fan bearings for uneven rumbling or hammering noise.
[_ _]
(b) Check the fan bearings for overheating by using hand held
infrared temperature sensor. [_ _]
(c) Check the fans for excessive vibration (surging or beating
sound) shuddering on start
up or run down. [_ _]
(d) Check the safety guards and other safety features for safe
operating condition. [_ _]
(e) Check the flexible connection of ducting, for leaks, tearing
andfraying. [_ _]
(f ) Check the drive belts for condition. [_ _]
4. Motor Operation
(a) Check the motor bearings for noisy running and excessive
vibration. [_ _]
(b) Check the motor and the bearings for excessive heating. [_ _]
(c) Check that external ventilation airways are clear. [_ _]
5. On completion of all checks switch the fan OFF using the
START/STOP/RESET pushbutton.
Check that the outlet damper closes fully on shutdown. [_ _]
6. Record ""Hours Run"" for fan in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job
Sheet.
7. Request the control room to close the inlet smoke dampers. [_ _]
8. Ensure the fan AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switches are set to the AUTO
position. [_ _]
9. Ensure the fan station is clean and remove all accumulated debris andrubbish.
10. Record anything outside normal parameters, in the ""Work Done""
areaof the job
sheet. [_ _]
11. On the completion of the job notify the control room. [_ _]
12. On completion of the job, the ""Hours Run"" detail, for each fan is
to be entered into the

03 M Inspect of Liebert A/C units at Substation 2.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Access to the Air Conditioning units in the Substation 2
building is via external doors into the SS02 building in Swan
Street. The condenser units are located on the roof of the
building.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer. Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting. [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with new
setpoint and verify temperature is consistent with
ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer. [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting. [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer. [_ _]
NOTE: LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm. [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary. Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm. [_ _]
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear. [_ _]
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation. [_ _]
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation. [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running. [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch. [_ _]
5.4. Inspect for loose connections or leaking coils. [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean the condenser coils, if required using compressed
air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator. [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit. [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits. [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish. [_ _]
7.0. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Equipment room and
equipment etc, in the Work Done section of the job sheet
and report to the Team Leader or his representative and
raise a new job for any repairs.
8. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

06 M Test of batt backed emerg and exit lights SUB 1

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 1, ERE 01, 03, ERW 05
& ERW 06 TMF-3012-OP-0242, only those fittings in which the
tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 1, ERE 01, 03, ERW 05 & ERW 06
TMF-3012-OP-0242, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 1, ERE 01, 03, ERW 05 & ERW 06
TMF-3012-OP-0242, only those light fittings that the battery
charger operation indicator does not function correctly.
8. Remove any excess debris from within lighting diffusers.
9. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
10. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Flush and clean BT EET Bay No-Fines as specified.
Please Note: The water meter, mounted on the special hydrant
connection reads in litres, with each digit on the rightmost red
wheel being equal to one litre.
e.g. with a reading, showing all twos, the reading would
represent 22,222,222 litres.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Ensure tunnel closure permits are arranged.
2. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
3. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 25 & 26.
4. Cleaning of the no-fines is to be carried out in accordance
with procedure TMI-3012-OP-0025. Reference Manual, Southern
Link Operations and Maintenance Manual, Tunnel Drainage,
Stage 2 R-STG-EN-006. Drainage bays are defined in Drawing
Nos. STG-CI-2150 to 2154. The bays are approx. 60 mts apart.
5. (a) Locate the two (2) injection points (approx 1 mt apart)
(b) Locate and open both the upstream and downstream pits of
the groundwater system.
(c) Open the upstream dirty water pit and remove the cap from
the 100 dia pipe and check if a flow is present. Any
flows in the upstream dirty water pit may be a sign that
the no-fines is not functioning correctly.
6. Using the special hydrant to flushing point pipe and metering
system, connect the water from the hydrant to the injection
points and inject water at the rate and maximum pressure
shown in the table below.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Bay | Specified Flow rate | Max Flow Pressure
| (litres/s) | kPa (psi)
----------------------------------------------------------------
Bay 1 | 0.5 (20s for 10lt) | 100 (15)
Bay 11 | 0.5 (bucket) | 100 (15)
All other bays in | |
Eastbound Tunnel | 1.2 (8s for 10lt)| 100 (15)
Westbound Tunnel | 1.2 (bucket) | 100 (15)
EET Bays | 0.5 | 100 (15)
7. (a) Observe and record the flow rates (using a graduated
measuring bucket and timing) before, during and after
flushing in the pits for each bay. Record the results on
BURNLEY EE TUNNEL NO-FINES FLUSHING DETAIL
TMF-3012-OP-0238.
(b) Increased flowrate and water quality should be observed
for any milkyness in flushed water (which indicates
removal of calcite) will indicate signs of satisfactory
flushing..
(c) Flushing shall be continuous for a minimum of 1 hour for
each bay.
8. Determine pH of water from each bay before, during and after
flushing. Use Indicator paper and compare with colour chart
for result. Record results on form BURNLEY EE TUNNEL
NO-FINES FLUSHING DETAIL TMF-3012-OP-0238.
9. Replace all covers on completing each bay, prior to moving to
the next.
10. Ensure the completed job sheet and the attached form
TMF-3012-OP-0238 is forwarded to the Civil Team Leader on
completion of the job.
11. Record anything outside normal parameters in the Work Done"
area of the Job sheet.
12. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

A INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the
electrical installations of Technical Shelters, as well the
cleaning, inspections and maintenance of the relevant
areas.
B ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
( Technical Shelters TSH1-6, TSH10-14 )
1. Notify the TCRO prior to entering the relevant Technical
shelters.
2. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere,
use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events. [_ _]
3. At Technical shelters, fill-in the log-book [_ _]
4. Check the interior and external lighting for operation,
including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace
faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture. [_ _]
5. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor. Temperatures of
ambient plus 10?C should be considered abnormal and must be
noted in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and
ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of
the abnormality. Raise a new job sheet for any corrective
action [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all
cables, terminals, equipment and components for evidence
of burn marks, unusual odours and overheating. Record
anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job
Sheet and raise a new jobsheet for any corrective action.
the abnormality. [_ _]
7. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc. [_ _]
8. Inspect the surges diverters where applicable, and either
replace spent surge diverters when less than 80% or raise a
new Job Sheet for works to be carried out. [_ _]
9. At Technical Shelters, visually inspect external Lightning
Protection System connections for damage and or corrosion.
Record anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the
Job Sheet and raise a new jobsheet for any corrective
action. Ensure the Team Leader or his representative is
informed of the abnormality. [_ _]
10.Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and
general operation, lubricate as required. Carry out
any required repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any
outstanding actions. [_ _]
11.Inspect single line drawings for legibility. Record
details of drawings requiring replacement in the ""Work
Done"" area and report to the Team leader or his
representative.
12.Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage. [_ _]
13.Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally
for dust, grime and condensation, clean enclosures of any
accumulated dust, dirt and debris. [_ _]
14.Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of
obstructions. Clean or replace filters as required. [_ _]
15.Inspect systems, mounted within the building or room(s),
for faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged switches and
buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
16.PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.
Indicators found to indicate abnormal conditions are
to be logged in the ""Work Done"" of the Job Sheet and
a new job sheet raised to invetigate and correct the
error. [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g.
plug connections, screw connections for security.
[_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose. [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush, ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated
dust and debris. [_ _]
17.Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.
18.Inspect the door alarm switches at all external doors for
operation and security. Check with the Traffic Control
Room Operator to confirm the receipt of an alarm. Repair
faulty of defective switches. Record details of
outstanding defects in the Work Done area of the Job
Sheet. [_ _]
19.Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team
Leader or his representative of any corrective actions.
Include in the Related Job field of the new and this
job, the job number number of the alternate Job. [_ _]
C. Building Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of
moisture ingress. Inspect for source of any water. Record
any details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and
inform the Team Leader or his representative. [_ _]
2. Check that the room(s) are not obstructed by furnishings
and or stored items. Remove any obstruction. [_ _]
3. Inspect the area of the generator in Tech Shelters and air
conditioning unit, for leaks of fuel, coolants or
lubricants. Clean any spillage and if any leaks are
evident record in the ""Work Done "" area and raise a new
jobsheet for any corrective action required. Inform the
Team Leader or his representative of these required
actions. [_ _]
5. Remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of cabinets,
ledges, cable trays, cables, etc. Note: Dust will settle
on all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops of cabinets, tops
of cabinet doors, tops of meter escutcheons etc. [_ _].
6. Clean all exterior surfaces of cabinets using approved
cleaning materials . [_ _]
7. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets, light
fittings, cable trays and ceilings. [_ _]
8. Remove any accumulated rubbish and debris. [_ _]
9. Sweep and vacuum all floor surfaces. [_ _]
10.Carry out Exterior Checks of Technical Shelters.
(a) Visually inspect the exterior surfaces of the
building (if applicable) for damage, erosion,
graffiti. [_ _]
(b) Visually inspect the building (if applicable) walls,
roof, guttering and and downpipes for damage, leaks
and or blockages, remove any debris or materials
that could cause a blockage. [_ _]
(c) Inspect (if applicable) the general area surrounding
the building for erosion and damage to surfaces,
fences, gates, pavements [_ _]
11.Visually inspect rodent bait station for bait. replace
bait station if bait is near exhausted. [_ _]
12.Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of
the job sheet. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
corrective actions. [_ _]
13.Remove any accumulated debris from the building surrounds.
[_ _]
14.Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service
e.g. Fans, Air Conditioners. [_ _]
(b) All Enclosures are closed and locked. [_ _]
(c) All Lighting turned OFF [_ _]
(d) Generators in Tech Shelters to be left in a state of
readiness for operation. [_ _]
(e) UPS in Tech Shelters to be left in state of readiness
for operation. [_ _]
15.Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team
Include in the ""Related Job"" field of the new and this
16.Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to departing.

12 M Inspection of SL Thytec UPS systems

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The sub-contractor shall carry out the service in the
presence of the electrical / electronic technician.
2. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
3. Notify the control room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
4. Refer to the reference manual Thytec 30KVA UPS 12 Pulse
[ M-MCL-ME20000/20011 ]
5. The following maintenance is to be carried out on the UPS
units in the following:
TSH 14
6. TSH 14 - UPS Unit.
(a) Do not operate the EMERGENCY STOP push button, on the
front of the UPS Panel, unless in an extreme emergency, as
damage to the UPS electrical equipment can occur.
(b) Check operation, settings and calibration of all
controls. [_ _]
(c) Record from the data display, the input, inverter, load
and battery data. [_ _]
(d) Check for signs of over heating. [_ _]
(e) Check system safety controls. (Bypass operations) [_ _]
(f ) Clean the inside of the UPS. (Vacuum out) [_ _]
(g) Clean the filter on the inside of the door panel. [_ _]
7. TSH 14 - Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
Batteries.
(b) Remove any metal jewellery being worn
(c) Battery discharge test. [_ _]
Using the discharge tester, measure and record the
individual standby and discharge
voltages on the "" individual battery check "" sheet.
(Cell voltage variation limit + / - 0.05% volts per cell
from average of all cells in (1) one
battery bank. Any variation in excess of this limit
should be investigated immediately.)
Using the ""Mains failure simulation"" sheet, perform
test and record voltages & currents.
(d) Check terminals for corrosion. [_ _]
(e) Check connections for tightness . [_ _]
8. Record the sub-contractors job sheet no. for technical
shelter:
TSH 14 [_________]
9. Record Sub-contractors inspection Report No in the "" Work
Done "" area of the job sheet.
10.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
11.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

03 M Inspect of ERW06 & ERE02 Liebert wall mounted AC unit

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Access to equipments rooms ERE02 and ERW06 is via the Grant
Street Stairwell. The equipment rooms are located on the
mezzanine floor. The Air Conditioner and the Condenser are
mounted in one integral unit.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Check for unusual noise or vibration while the unit is
running. [_ _]
5. Shut the unit down using the ON/OFF switch, and open the
front access panel. [_ _]
6. Check the filters and replace if required. Filter size
21 x 36.25 x 2 (1 reqd) [_ _]
7. Check the blower for debris and dust buildup and clean as
required. Check that the blower is tightly mounted on the
shaft, and it rotates freely without rubbing. [_ _]
8. Check the refrigeration capillaries and supports to ensure
they cannot rub together through vibration. Check for
leaks. [_ _]
9. Check temperature settings by lowering the thermostat setting
and check equipment room temperature with a portable
thermometer. [_ _]
10. Condenser
a. Clean the condenser coil when filter is replaced. [_ _]
b. Check lines for leaks. [_ _]
c. Check the coils for damage. [_ _]
11. Switch the unit ON using the ON/OFF switch. [_ _]
12. Check the condensate drain for blockage and damage. Clear
any blockages. [_ _]
13. Inspect the two fire dampers (Inlet and outlet) for damage,
corrosion or premature operation. [_ _] [_ _]
14. Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
(i) Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
(ii) Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces
that will collect dust deposits. [___]
(iii) Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
(iv) Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages. Remove from site all accumulated debris
and rubbish. [_ _]
15. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record the
results on form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347.
Ensure the form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347
is returned to the Electrical / Electronics Supervisor or
his representative. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
works.
16. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Team Leader or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
17. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Tst of batt emerg and exit lights Equip Rms from SUB 2

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive end
blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - EQUIPMENT ROOMS AND
REFUGES SUPPLIED FROM SUBSTATION 2 TMF-3012-OP-0244, only
those fittings in which the tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - EQUIPMENT ROOMS AND REFUGES
SUPPLIED FROM SUBSTATION 2 TMF-3012-OP-0244, only those
lights which does not provide suitable area lighting for the
required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - EQUIPMENT ROOMS AND REFUGES SUPPLIED FROM
SUBSTATION 2 TMF-3012-OP-0244, only those light fittings
that the battery charger operation indicator does not
function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
EQUIPMENT ROOMS AND REFUGES SUPPLIED FROM SUBSTATION 2
TMF-3012-OP-0244 for subsequent replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of Sub 6 HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor under the
supervision of an
electrical/electronics technician.
3. Refer to Manual ""Merlin Gerin Masterpact Instruction Notice""
M-STG-EL-24030
4. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carriedout and that
(a) The ""General Section "" of the above job has been completed and
(b) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring
all cabling, connections and installation meet the AS 3000
standard.
5.(Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles of the circuit
breakers and
isolators. [_ _]
6. (Sub 6 Oil Filled Transformers A & B)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to be
recorded and reported
to the Electrical/electronics team leader or his representative.
(a) Carry out Insulation resistance test, using 2500-volt insulation
tester: HV-LV / Tank
(b) Examine and clean all bushings, insulators, terminals, cable
boxes, valves along
with all fitments for oil leaks, ingress of moisture, damage.
(c) Check oil levels and add fresh oil as required. Fresh oil shall
be dielectric tested
and compliant with AS1883.
(d) Carry out a functional test of the oil temperature and
monitoringto ensure correct
Alarming and trip operation via the PMCS to the Traffic
ControlRoom.
(e) Check tightness (Torque test) of all earthing and cable
connections (MEN,
Bushings and tank) and inspect for evidence of overheating of
broken strands.
Tighten connections where necessary.
(f) Check the operation and setting of temperature and pressure
alarm / trip switches
and if necessary adjust settings in accordance with the
manufacturers Operating
and Maintenance Instructions.
(g) Inspect the transformer tank, cooling fins and fitments for
corrosion, dirt or foreign
material buildup. Clean tank cooling fins and fittings, treat
and recoat surface rust
spots.
(h) Inspect and where necessary replace the crystals in the silica
gelbreather when
fitted.
Note: Blue/Pink silica gel crystals may be carcinogenic linked
and should only
be disposed of as per the supplier's recommendations.
7. (Transformer Oil Testing 6A & 6B)
Ensure by referring to Analytical Reports that there is no PCB's
present in oils be tested.
The result of the tests, inspections and observations are to be
(a) Collect a sample of the Transformer Oil for each transformer and
have the sample
tested for dielectric strength.
8. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations including dateof
test, ground and
weather conditions are to be recorded and reported to the
Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an earthing
resistance test in
accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for tightness of
connections,
and the condition of system components e.g. Earthing
electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
9. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to be
to the Electrical/electronics team leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance and
cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are clean
and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion. Clean and
tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal
and battery voltage and battery temperature prior to
commencing the test as well
as at completion of test. Where the battery or terminal
voltage at completion of test
is less than 80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of
it's serviceable life and replacement options should be
recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i) Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for damage
etc.
10. (Operations and Maintenance Building Circuit breakers)
(a) Thoroughly, visually inspect the circuit breakers and record
andreport any damaged
or worn parts.
(b) Record the number of operations for each circuit breaker.
(c) Inspect metal and insulating parts, remove dust and dirt and
clean in accordance
with the manufacturers instructions.
(d) Clean the switchgear enclosure (cubicle)
(e) Carefully examine LV bushings and insulators for cracks, chips
orpartial
discharging.
(f) Visually check and ensure that control devices are free of
accumulated dust deposits
by carefully cleaning.
(g)Check all un-insulated cable connections for correct tension.
Check and tighten
un-insulated bolts on cable connections where practical to do so.
(h) Check all earthing and cable connections including control
cubicle, inspecting for
loose connections and signs of broken strands. Tighten and or
repair as required.
(i) Visually inspect all auxiliary wiring, plugs and terminations.
(j) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across primary contacts.
(k) Check and record winding resistance of shunt trip and the close
coils. Compare
with previous years findings.
(l) Confirm correct operation of spring charge motors and interlock
devices.
(m) Inspect, clean and lubricate all moving parts of the switchgear
operating mechanisms
as described in the Manufacturer's Maintenance Instructions.
(n) Clean the exterior of switchgear cubicles of dirt and grime,
record areas of damaged
paintwork or areas that are corroded.
(o) Examine and clean all control relays, contactors, fuses etc,
confirming connections
and continuity of all wiring.
(p) Perform millivolt drop / micro ohm test across cubicle bus bar
connections for all
phases if the bus bar is available.
(q) Perform insulation resistance tests with a 1000V insulation
testerfor one minute
per test:
(i) With the CB closed each phase to the other phases and earth.
(ii) With the CB open, across the open contacts
This test shall be carried out after maintenance.
(r) Carry out a complete functional test on each circuit breaker
andensure correct
operation including devices, flags, interlocks etc.
(s) Trip and close the circuit breaker at least five times.
(t) Reinstall all parts and ensure all switchgear is fully
operational on completion of
the maintenance.
11. (Capacitor Banks at Sub 6 (Outdoor))
(a) Carry out a thorough visual inspection, record and report any
damage.
(b) Visually inspect the outside and inside of the enclosure for
signs of corrosion on
capacitor cans and frames. Clean and remove accumulated dirt
and dust.
(c) Visually inspect all earthing and cabling connections, check for
signs of overheating
or broken strands. Check and tighten connections as required.
12. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring
further corrective actions. Raise a new job sheet for any
outstanding works and
notify the Team Leader or his representative. Include in the
Related Job"" field
of the new and this job, the job number of the alternate Job. [_
_]
13. At Substation fill-in the log book. [_ _]

03 M Inspection of ERW02 (adjacent to Sub 4) Liebert A/C

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Access to ERW02 is via the stairwell in Alexandra Avenue.
The equipment room is adjacent to Substation 4.
NOTE: Parking restrictions may apply between 7.00am and
5.30pm.
The airconditioning unit is located in equipment room ERW02
and the condenser unit is located in the riser, adjacent to

3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU-ERW2-1 - Air Conditioning Unit
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer. Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting. [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with new
setpoint and verify temperature is consistent with
ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer. [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting. [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer. [_ _]
NOTE: LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm. [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm. [_ _]
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear. [_ _]
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation. [_ _]
5. The work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation. [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running. [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local isolating
switch. [_ _]
5.4. Inspect for loose connections or leaking coils. [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local isolator. [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit. [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits. [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish. [_ _]
7.0. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record
the results on form Equipment Room Inspections
TMF-3012-OP-0347. Ensure the form Equipment Room

03 M Inspection & test of the Standby elect supply

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering each technical
shelter.
3. Carry out this job on the UPS to exercise the system and
confirm UPS system operation.
4. Check the operational condition of the Technical Shelter 10
Uninterruptable Power Supply to ensure it is operating in the
normal standby-back-up mode and there are no alarms. [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TEST IF THE UPS IS IN
THE BYPASS MODE.
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from the "AUTOMATIC CONTROL" position to the "EMERGENCY
SUPPLY + TEST " position. A changeover will occur and
the technical shelter load will be supplied from the
emergency power supply. Operate the system in this
mode for 10 minutes.
(b) Measure the voltage and load current per phase. [_ _]
(c) Using an optical thermometer, measure the temperature
of the terminals in the emergency power supply circuit.
Record in the Work Done any terminal whose temperature
increases unduly during this operation. [_ _]
(d) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
back to the "AUTOMATIC CONTROL" position. The
technical shelter load will revert to the main power
supply after a time delay has confirmed the normal
supply is healthy. [_ _]
6. (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises. [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet. [_ _]
7. Record anything outside normal parameters in the Work Done
area of the job sheet. Raise a new job sheet if there is
work requiring further attention. Priority P1.
8. Fill in the Log Book in the Technical Shelter.
9. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

48 M Insp of Light Poles on Exhibition Street

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the traffic control room prior to commencing this
job.
2. Reference:
MCL Drawings: 0230 to 0239
Asset register: G:\TFM\Operations\Lighting\
Light Poles\Light Pole Asset Register.xls
3. At each Light pole, visually inspect the condition of the
light pole as follow:
(a). Check if the pole is obviously leaning or if there is any
attachments obviously sagging. This is a visual check that
there are no obvious problems.
(b). Check if any attachments are not securely fixed.
(c). Check if there is any impact damage from vehicles. Poles
which have been impacted by vehicles should be replaced.
(d). Check if there are any cracks in the pole, particularly at
the corners of any openings in the pole. Fatigue cracks
often start at the corners of openings
(e). Check if there are any cracked, bent or broken bolts.
Cracked, bent or broken bolts should be replaced.
(f). Check if any welds are cracked or broken. Cracked or broken
welds in critical locations, eg pole to base plate welds,
should be repaired.
(g). Check if there are any bolts, covers or other parts
missing. The action required will depend on the criticality
ofthe missing part.
(h). Check if any nuts are loose or missing (visual check).
Tighten any loose nuts if required.
(i). Check if there are any obvious electrical problems like
exposed wires. Immediate attention is required if these
pose a hazard.
(k). Check if the foundation is undermined or exposed to
standing water. Undermined foundations require a more
detailed assessment. Standing water should be removed by
improved drainage.
(l). Check if the grouting between the base plate and the
foundation is cracked (crack widths greater than 0.5 mm) or
loose. Cracked grout can hold moisture and accelerate
corrosion of anchor bolts. Where grout is loose it should
be replaced.
(m). Clear any clogged drain holes at the base of the pole.
(n). Remove any debris accumulation at the base of the pole,
around the anchor bolts, or elsewhere on the structure.
(o). Comment on the general condition of the protective coating
(note blistering, flaking, rust staining etc). Remedial
action will depend upon the extent of deterioration.
(p). Remove cover plates near the base (where appropriate) and
check for damage to electrical wiring, internal corrosion,
infestation by insects, water and ponding.
5. Record work completed at each Light pole on
attached form TMF-3012-OP-0376 ""Routine Inspection of Light
Poles"".
6. Record any corrective action required in the ""Work Done""
area of the Job Sheet.
7. Return the completed jobsheet to the Civil Supervisor
or his representative.
File Inspection report in File 119.16

06 M Inspect, repair and clean Egress tunnel lighting

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this
work.
2. Have the Traffic Control Room turn all lights on.
3. Check emergency egress tunnel lighting and the lighting of
the escape stairway for operation, repair any faulty lights
found.
4. Check emergency egress tunnel emergency lighting and the
emergency lighting for the escape stairway for operation,
repair any faulty lights found.
5. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
6. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
7. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record
in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet, only those fittings
in which the tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
8. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record in the Work Done
Area of the Job Sheet only those lights which does not
provide suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
9. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record in the Work Done Area
of the Job Sheet only those light fittings that the battery
charger operation indicator does not function correctly.

11. Remove accumulated debris from light fittings and clean
diffusers of accumulated dirt.

12 M Test & inspection of the BT deluge installation

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The twelve monthly deluge system inspection and test shall be
carried out in conjunction with the fire-protection
sub-contractor and the Traffic Control Room Officers (TRCO).
2. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing the job.
(a). A tunnel closure is required. A Memorandum of Consent
(MOC) and a Permit to Work approval is required from
Translink Operations, the Maintenance Manager or his
representative prior to commencing work.
(b) Access to the Burnley tunnel shall be as per Work
Instruction, Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan Domain Tunnel
Portal Closure.
3. Reference Drawings SLG-FS- 30900 to SLG-FS-30911.
4. Prior to testing the deluge zone spray system:
(a) Ensure that the maximum capacity is available in the
dirty water sump and holding tank at the Yarra Crossing
Dirty Water Pit and the Swan Street Water Treatment
Plant. [_ _]
(b) Request the TCRO to close the bypass valve between the
pump station dirty water and the ground water sump
pits. [_ _]
(c) Install the bungs in the TAM sensors.,,[_ _]
6. Discharge the Deluge Spray Zones.
(a) Request the TCRO to actuate one (1) specified deluge
spray zones, starting at the West Portal then progressing
eastward. Spray pattern may take 30 seconds to
establish.
(b) Observe that the spray pattern provides coverage of the
tunnel floor area and note defective sprays and faulty
equipment for replacement. Observe for 15 seconds.
(c) Request the TCRO to close the one (1) specified deluge
zones.
(d) Functional test should take approximately one minute
between activation and closing the valve.
(e) Check that the deluge valve has fully closed.
(f) It should take approximately 5 minutes for each zone.
(g) It is important that the levels at the Yarra Crossing
Dirty Water Pit and the Swan St Pit are monitored at all
times by the TCRO during testing. Testing must cease if
the pit levels are high and then only resume when the pit
levels have dropped sufficiently to accommodate the
deluge water.
7. Carry out step 6 for the remaining deluge zones, one zone at
time. After activating zone FSP E068, activate both zones
FSP E068 and FSP E069 together, checking that there is no
Low Water Pressure alarm, record results on form BURNLEY
TUNNEL DELUGE TEST (EAST END) - 12 M OPERATIONAL TEST OF
BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE SYSTEM TMF-3012-OP-0266
8. Manually operate the six (6) sectioning valves, in the fire
main, through a close and open cycle. Confirm with TCRO the
operational status of the valve as it is operated. [_ _]
9. Record on forms
BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE TEST (WEST END) - 12 M OPERATIONAL
TEST OF BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE SYSTEM TMF-3012-OP-0262 and
BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE TEST (EAST END) - 12 M OPERATIONAL
TEST OF BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE SYSTEM"" TMF-3012-OP-0266, the
result of the tests for each deluge zone and sectioning
valve.
10. Request the TCRO to open bypass valves between the pump
station dirty water and ground water sump pits and to ensure
that operation of the pumps have returned to normal. Only
ground water pump in operation and the dirty water is
flowing via the triple interceptor. Perform regular visual
inspections to ensure that there is no overflow from
the dirty water tundish.
11. Remove the bungs in the TAM sensors once the deluge test is ,,
completed [_ _]
12. Record any follow up requirements in the Work Done area of
the Job sheet and raise a Job Sheet for any outstanding
works. Priority High P1.
13. Record the sub-contractors work sheet number in the Work
Done area of the job sheet and forward the sub-contractor
confirmation sheet to the Team Leader - Electrical or his
representative.
14. Notify the control room on completion of the work.
15. Forward completed check form,
BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE TEST (WEST END) - 12 M OPERATIONAL
TEST OF BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE SYSTEM TMF-3012-OP-0262 and
BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE TEST (EAST END) - 12 M OPERATIONAL
TEST OF BURNLEY TUNNEL DELUGE SYSTEM TMF-3012-OP-0266, to
the Team Leader - Electrical or his representative upon
completion of the job.

01 M Inspection & test running of the WL TSH generators

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
Supply to ensure it is operating in the normal
standby-back-up mode. [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
MODE.
4. Refer to reference manual Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
5. (a) Check that the generator was left in "AUTO" [_ _]
(b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuel and water. [_ _]
(c) Check oil level. [_ _]
(d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates. [_ _]
(e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ). [_ _]
(f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts [_ _]
(g) Record the battery voltage in the "Work Done" area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
(h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
Physically open the cap, as the gauge could be
misleading. [_ _]
(j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
with the last entry. [_ _]
6. Reference manual, Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP
Electrical Pty Ltd Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI
[M-MCL-ME-20016]
7. (a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch on the generator
DC panel to "" RUN "" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch
back to "" AUTO ""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from "" AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST
"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature. [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back
to " AUTOMATIC CONTROL" the generator will continue to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
(g) Record the hours run, from the hours run meter, in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet.
8. (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises. [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet. [_ _]
9. Fill in the Generator Log Book and record anything outside
normal parameters in the "Work Done" area of the job
sheet. Raise a new job for any works requiring further
repairs. Priority High P1.
10.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
11.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
12.Record the Hours run in Mainpac under "Plant" use RH mouse
click then select "Open" then select "Meter
Readings" in edit mode add the Meter Reading for the
appropriate TSH Generator.

12 M Inspect the North Sticks

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference: Melbourne City Link - The Stick Wall Periodic
Non-Destructive Testing - Scope.
Report No. 4199/002 Provided by Intico.
3. Refer to "Red Stick Wall Inspections - Stick Inspectional
Location Details" TMF-3012-OP-0356 for the location of the
various components and structural items for inspection.
Item 3.1
(a) Visually inspect, from the access door, the base and
interior of each stick looking for water pooling in the
base, evidence of moisture and or corrosion.
(b) Visually inspect the seal of the access door for damage
(c) Examine stick interior for evidence of the source of any
possible leak e.g. Top cover or access door.
(d) Estimate the depth and quantity of any water residue and
record.
(d) Record details of any water residues (along with source),
corrosion and or damage on form "ANNUAL NORTH STICK
INSPECTION" TMF-3012-OP-0352. Raise a new jobsheet for any
outstanding works.
Item 3.2
(a) Visually inspect, from the ground and using binoculars, all
faces of each stick, examining the protective coating for
cracks, peeling, blisters and evidence of corrosion.
(b) Record details of any degradation of protective coating and
or corrosion on form"ANNUAL NORTH STICK INSPECTION"
TMF-3012-OP-0352. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
works.
Item 3.3
(a) Visually inspect the Foundation to Stick seal. Examine for
the effectiveness of the elastic seal between the steelwork
and the concrete foundation. Seal may separate from the
surfaces or may be missing.
(b) Record details of any degradation of the seal material and
or any damaged or missing material on form "ANNUAL NORTH
STICK INSPECTION" TMF-3012-OP-0352. Raise a new jobsheet
for any outstanding works.
Item 3.4
(a) Visually examine each stick for signs of structural damage.
This would include vandalism, impact and or displacement.
Examine the linearity of each stick against the remainder of
the group. .
(b) Inspect the access door, at the base, for damage and a full
complement of setscrews.
(c) Record details of any structural damage along with all other
visible damage on form "ANNUAL NORTH STICK INSPECTION"
4. Notify the Traffic Control room on completion of the job.

03 M Inspection of Thytec UPS system in WL TSH's

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
3. Refer to Manual: Thytec 30KVA UPS 12 Pulse
[ M-MCL-ME20000/20011 ] Manual.
4. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
charged ) record results in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037. [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts: A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
5. At By-pass Switch (Wall Mounted)
(a) Press the TRANSFER button, on the UPS control panel, to
transfer the UPS to the by-pass mode.
(b) Wait until the amber By-Pass led is illuminated.
(c) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet,
to the OFF position, to isolate the batteries.
(d) Press the OFF button, on the UPS control panel, to
switch OFF the UPS unit.
(e) Switch the EXTERNAL BY-PASS switch (wall mounted above
UPS) to the BY-PASS position. The UPS unit is now
by-passed.
WARNING: DO NOT USE THE INTERNAL BY-PASS SWITCH, AS THIS
SWITCH IS NOT INTERLOCKED.
(f) Switch the EXTERNAL by-pass switch to the NORMAL
position.
(g) Press the ON button, on the UPS control panel. An UPS
start is initiated.
(h) Wait for INV. ON green led to illuminate.
(i) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet,
to the ON position to connect the batteries to the UPS.
(j) After about 30 secconds the BYPASS led will go OFF and
the INVERTER led will illuminate, indicating the load is
on the inverter. A noticeable change in the operating
noise of the UPS will also indicate the change of load.
6. UPS Unit.
(a) Do not operate the EMERGENCY STOP push button, on the
front of the UPS Panel, unless in extreme emergency, as
damage to the UPS electrical equipment can occur.
(b) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.
[_ _]
(c) Remove the air filter, clean and re-install, ( replace
air filter if necessary ) [_ _]
(d) Check for air flow above grills on top of the panel.
( with fan in operation ) [_ _]
(e) Visual Inspection of capacitors for any oil leaks. [_ _]
(f) Switch OFF the ""MAIN UPS"" electrical supply. The load
should then transfer to the UPS, supplying from the
batteries.
(g) Check and monitor, on the UPS display, the load current
(max. 42A per phase 30kVA UPS or max 55A per phase 40kVA
UPS).
(h) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037. [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts: A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
(i) Leave the UPS supply the load for at least ten minutes.
(j) Switch the Normal electricity supply isolator to the ON
position. The load will revert to the Normal power
supply.
7. Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
(b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on Panel
Door, is in the upright position and is not tripped.
(c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
CB ( nominally 270V. ) [_ _]
8. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the "" Work
Done "" area of the job sheet.
9.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

12 M Inspect, test and clean Domain Tunnel VSLS signs"

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Inform Traffic Control Room prior to commencing work.
2. The VSLS on the RHL wall should be serviced using a RHL Lane
closure, VSLS units on the LHL wall should be serviced using
a LHS lane closure. This excludes the VSLS Sign Message
Operation and the Sign Test Result which are carried out on
the two signs, LHS and RHS simultaneously from the equipment
room analyser.
3. Reference Manual Symon Services Operation, Training &
Maintenance Manual for TIMS, VSLS & FES M-STG-TM-29943
4. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 20, 23, 24, 25, 26 and 29.
5. Equipment Room Analysers
(a) Inspect the VSLS analyser for evidence of burnt or
damaged connections on plugs, electronic cards and
wiring.
(b) Clean the cabinet interior of any accumulated dirt or
dust.
(c) Press the TEST button on the analyser and monitor the
sign test routine. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in
Sign Test Result column on the form VSLS Systems
Inspections Domain Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0300.
(d) Inspect the cabinet for damage, ensuring the door closes
and locks securely.
6. VSLS signs
(a) Isolate sign power at the sign circuit breaker within
the VSLS sign enclosure.
(b) Check the electronic component boards for evidence of
burning or arcing.
(c) Clean the front facia of the sign, using Windex and a
soft cloth.
(d) Turn the sign circuit breaker to ON and check the pixel
operation. Record in the comments column of the form
VSLS Systems Inspections Domain Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0300
if more than 10% of the pixels have failed.
(e) (i) Check and adjust the output of the 12VDC power supply
and the inputs to the various drivers and
controllers, the voltage measured, in each case must
fall within the range of 12.9VDC and 13.1VDC. Record
result ( OK or Fail) in the Sign inspection column of
the form VSLS Systems Inspections Domain Tunnel
TMF-3012-OP-0300.
(ii) On the small VSLS signs (in the tunnel), check and
adjust the output of the 12VDC power supply and the
inputs to the various drivers and controllers, the
voltage measured, in each case must fall within the
range of 10.5VDC and 11VDC. Record result ( OK or
Fail) in the Sign inspection column of the form VSLS
Systems Inspections Domain Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0300.
(iii) On the LARGE VSLS signs (outside the tunnels), check
and adjust the output of the 12VDC power supply and
the inputs to the various drivers and controllers,
the voltage measured, in each case should fall within
the range of 12.9VDC and 13.1VDC. Record the result
( OK or Fail) in the Sign inspection column of the
form VSLS Systems Inspections Domain Tunnel
TMF-3012-OP-0300. The 7.5VDC power supply, supplies
the VSLS sign Red leds, while the 12VDC power supply,
supplies the White Leds. The Small VSLS signs have 4
LEDs per pixel while the Large VSLS signs have 3 LEDs
per pixel.
(f ) Check the operation and alignment of the Light Dependant
Resistor (LDR) by
(i) covering the LDR will cause the display intensity
to reduce
(ii) shining a torch onto the LDR will cause the
display intensity to increase.
(This function cannot be tested with the present
configuration).
7. Ensure the control room can control the sign via a TEST
message change, confirm the sign operation back to the
operator. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in the sign message
operation column of the form VSLS Systems Inspections Domain
Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0300.
8. Results of inspections and comments are recorded on form VSLS
SYSTEM INSPECTION - DOMAIN TUNNEL TIMS SIGNS AND ANALYSERS
TMF-3012-OP-0300 for tests that FAIL, record details in the
comments column of the form VSLS Systems Inspections Domain
9. On completion of the job record any outstanding corrective
actions required in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
Raise a new job sheet for any corrective work required.
10. Notify the control room on completion of work.
