03 M Inspect, Test & Clean of Yarra Boulevard Pump Station"

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths, lamps for
fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting, Brooms,
Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders, Silicon Lubricant Spray,
Rodent Bait Station
A INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the electrical
installations of the Pump Station as well the cleaning,
inspections and maintenance of the relevant areas.
B PUMP AND PUMP CONTROL OPERATION
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference Manual, TOJV, Pump Station Operation and
Maintenance Manuals - M-STG-ME-20001. Volume 3.
3. WARNING: THE WET WELL IS DESIGNATED A CONFINED SPACE AND
MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED SPACE CONDITIONS.
Refer to Work Instruction, Confined Space Entry
TMI-33012-SA-0015. Ensure the vent fan has operated for a
minimum period of 15 minutes prior to entering the dry well.
4. At the Local Control Panel
(a) Check the switchboard, situated adjacent to the pump well
for local alarm conditions. [_ _]
(b) Carry out visual inspections both internally and
externally the control panel for damage, corrosion,
evidence of insect infestation, ingress of moisture, dust
and grime (clean as required). [_ _]
(c) Check the cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating and inspect the electrical control
equipment. [_ _]
(d) Replace any failed panel indicator lamps. [___]
(e) Record the hours run reading in the Work Done area of
the job sheet. [_ _]
5. Inspect the wet well.
(a) Remove the covers (gatic lifters required) from the wet
well.
(b) Inspect for general cleanliness and accumulated debris in
the wet well, hose down any pumpable materials and remove
any non-pumpable solids. [_ _]
6. Inspection of the dry well, pumps and valves.
(a) Inspect the dry well for general cleanliness and
accumulated debris, clean if required. [_ _]
(b) The pipes, valves and pumps for corrosion and evidence
of leaks. [_ _]
7. Check the water level in the low level pump area. If the
water level is above the high level setting then manually
operate the sump pump to drain if necessary. Record in the
Work Done of the job sheet and report for corrective
maintenance. [_ _]
8. Switch the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to MANUAL
position. [_ _]
(a) Check the cabling to the pump for damage and that it is
clear from possible damage. [_ _]
9. Start the pump PSYBSWP1 by pressing the START pushbutton.
(a) Record the operating current of the pump in the Work
Done area of the job sheet. [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
and that sufficient gland water flows regularly. (One to
two drops per minute) [_ _]
(c) Observe that the pump discharge is sufficient to drawdown
the water level. [_ _]
CAUTION: Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low level
alarm point as lack of submergence may cause pumpset
damage.
(d) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton. Check the
operation of non-return valve (NRV), as the flow stops.
The NRV should close with
(i) a sharp audible metallic sound
(ii) the counterweight returning to pre-start position or
lower, as well
(iii) backflow through the pump should cease within 30
seconds.
If a faulty closure is suspected, the pump should be
re-started and run for 2 minutes and the operation of
the NRV monitored again. [_ _]
If a faulty closure is still suspected, record in the
Work Done area of the job sheet and report for
corrective maintenance. [_ _]
10. Repeat steps 8 and 9 for pump PSYBSWP2. [_ _]
11. Repeat steps 8 and 9 for pump PSYBSWP3. [_ _]
12. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position. [_ _]
13. Check the operation of the Taylor level controller, using
the wet well sight gauge situated on the wall of the dry
well. [_ _]
14. Test the operation of each of the isolating valves, in turn,
by partial closing and fully opening again. [_ _]
15. Check that the dry well ventilation system is functional by
checking the air flow and the filters for blockages. [_ _]
16. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Pump Station and
equipment etc, in the Work Done section of the
job sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
17. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done
area of the job sheet.
18. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
C ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. On entering control rooms, temporarily switch OFF ventilation
fans, if operating. [_ _]
2. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere,
use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events. [_ _]
3. Check the interior and external lighting for operation,
including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace
faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture. [_ _]
4. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor. Temperatures of ambient
plus 10?C should be considered abnormal and must be noted in
the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the abnormality.
Raise a new job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
5. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and components for evidence of burn
marks, unusual odours and overheating. Record anything
abnormal in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and raise
a new jobsheet for any corrective action. Ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc. [_ _]
7. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required. Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
8. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage. [_ _]

04 M Insp/cln of WL CCTV cams, EWP, Centre of Road"

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the right hand
lane or mounting the median strip
2. Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(b) Position 0 and 1.
(c) Lane Closure: RHS lane
(d) Electrical Cabinet Location: Tollway
3. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and the equipment mounted in the
cabinet is secure. [_ _]
(c) Check cables and terminations for signs of degradation,
re-terminate if necessary. [_ _]
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and are securely
fastened to the PT300.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.
(e) Check if surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is lit, if
not record the fact, for later replacement. [_ _]
(f) Check with TCRO that picture vision is OK. If not check
the signal from the camera using the WFM 90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly to the lead from the camera).
Ensure the co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT300
module and is secure. [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V supply to the PTZ controller and disconnect
(unplug) the control cable to the PTZ controller prior to
inspecting the camera housing. This will prevent movement
of the PTZ . [_ _]
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation. Surface insect
spray may be applied if necessary to the housing exterior
but must not be applied to the interior of the housing or
to the housing glass. If ingress of moisture or insect
infestation is evident then carry out
steps (d) and (e). [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
"Rain-X " cleaning fluid. [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater thermostat
(HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the operation of the
heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.
8. Reconnect the PTZ control cable to the PTZ controller and
re-instate the 240V power supply to the PTZ
controller. [_ _]
9. Notify the control room on completion and check the PTZ for
full movement and pre-programmed positions. If camera fails
to respond press the reset button on the PT 300 and wait 2
minutes then check again. [_ _]
10. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the "Work Done" area of the job sheet.

12 M Major inspection & test running of the generator

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The generator major service TYPE B, as set out in the
Cummins Maintenance report, shall be carried out on the
TSH generator
2. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.

Manual 960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]. The sub-contractor
shall carry out the service as per items listed on the
maintenance report column B and test as per par 5.
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch on the generator DC
panel to RUN let the engine run for at least 5 minutes,
then turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch back to AUTO.
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from AUTOMATIC CONTROL to EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST run
the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared, and
that there are no abnormal noises or vibrations. [_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature. [_ _]
( f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back
to AUTOMATIC CONTROL the generator will continue to run
for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
6. Fill in the Generator Log Book.
7. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
(a) Sub-contractors Maintenance Report No [________]
(b) Sub-contractors Field Report No [___________ ]
(c) Hours run ( from the hour run meter ) [___________]
8. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
9. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

12 M Test of batt backed emerg and exit lights SUB 6 & OMB

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 6 AND
OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE BUILDING TMF-3012-OP-0248, only
those fittings in which the tubes have been replaced.
EM/WP - 2 x 18w tube
EMG - 2 x 18w tube
EMG 1 - 1 x 10w Tungston Halogen
EMG 2 - 1 x 18w tube
EMG E - 1 x 10w tube
EX 1 - 2 x 10w tube
EM 2 - 2 x 26w tube
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 6 AND OPERATIONS AND
MAINTENANCE BUILDING TMF-3012-OP-0248, only those lights
which does not provide suitable area lighting for the
required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger
operation indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY
MAINTENANCE BUILDING TMF-3012-OP-0248, only those light
fittings that the battery charger operation indicator does
not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
SUBSTATION 6 AND OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE BUILDING
TMF-3012-OP-0248 for subsequent replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Inspect and maintain Batman Ave Escape Stair Fan

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job as well as prior
to entering the stairwell.
2. (a) Refer to Maintenance Manual, ""Operating and Maintenance manual
for Mechanical
Services - MCL Tunnels"" M-STG-ME-27400.
(b) Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation
commissioning tests.
3. Check under the fan cowl and the exit grills for debris that could
restrict the airflow. [_ _]
4. Ensure the door between Domain Tunnel and the stairwell is closed.
[_ _]
5. Request the TCO to start the fan ESF-P05 from the TCR. Ensure the
fan starts. Check
that the airflow direction is into the stairwell. [_ _]
6. (a) NOTE: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire brigade. It
will register on the local FIP
and the CCCS as a local alarm.
(b) Remove the access cover over the smoke detector, direct ""test
smoke"" from a smoke
generator, as specified on the container, onto the smoke
detector (on the inlet duct).
Check that an alarm actuates on the local fire indicator panel.
The smoke detector must
be in fault for approx 2? mins for the fan to stop and for an
alarm to genrate on
the CCCS. [_ _]
7. Check and inspect the Stairwell area.
(a) Check each door for damage, as well check the rollers, runners,
hinges, handles,
catches, and counter-weights for efficient operation. [_ _]
(d) With the supply air fan (ESF-P05) operating, record the
differential air pressure within
the stairwell and at substation level. Record readings less
than 50Pa in the ""Work Done'
area of the Job sheet. Notify the superintendent for further
investigation. [_ _]
(e) At each of the doors, starting from the tunnel and working
towards the fan.
Arrange the door catch to be non-functioning, then using a
spring balance, measure the
force required to open the door. Record the results in the
Work Done"" area of the Job
sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required, as well
advisethe maintenance
superintendent for further investigation. [_ _]
(f ) Check the time taken for the air pressure to return to the
static reading. Record in the
""Work Done"" area of the job sheet if time is greater than 2
minutes. Notify the
superintendent for further investigation.
(g) Chock each door open, then using an anemometer, measure the
velocity of air out of the
open door. The reading is to be with the door fully open and
with no obstructions.
Record the results in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job sheet
if the air flow is less than
1 metre /sec as well advise the maintenance superintendent for
further investigation. [_ _]
(h) Check the fan and motor for undue noise and vibrations. [_ _]
(i ) Check the fan bearings for noise. [_ _]
(j ) Check the fan unit for damage, corrosion, missing panel
fixings, as well as checking
the fixings of the unit for security. [_ _]
8. Ensure the action of opening a stairwell door;
(a) Generates an alarm at the TCR workstation.
(b) Causes the fan speed to vary to maintain a positive pressure inthe
stairwell.
(c) To replicate the action of the smoke detector, remove the
BATMAN AVENUE FAN alarm
relay (mounted in the rear compartment of the FIP) for at
least two and a half minutes to
ensure the fan stops. Replace the relay once the action is
confirmed [_ _]. The fire
brigade will not be called)
9. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes, with the door in both the open
and the closed position
then advise the traffic control room to shut the fan down and to turnOFF
the lighting after
leaving the stairwell, ensuring that the door to the tunnel is
closed.
10. Ensure the stairwell is clean and all rubbish and debris is removed
from the stairwell. [_ _]
11. Record anything outside normal parameters in the ""Work Done"" area
of the Job Sheet.
12. Ensure the door between the stairwell and the Domain Tunnel is
13. Notify the Control Room on completion of the job.

06 M Tst of batt emerg and exit lights Equip Rms from SUB 2

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on
EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - EQUIPMENT ROOMS AND
REFUGES SUPPLIED FROM SUBSTATION 2 TMF-3012-OP-0244, only
those fittings in which the tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - EQUIPMENT ROOMS AND REFUGES
SUPPLIED FROM SUSTATION 2 TMF-3012-OP-0244, only those lights
which does not provide suitable area lighting for the
required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - EQUIPMENT ROOMS AND REFUGES SUPPLIED FROM
SUBSTATION 2 TMF-3012-OP-0244, only those light fittings that
the battery charger operation indicator does not function
correctly.
8. Remove any excess debris from within lighting diffusers.
9. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
10. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Check operation of the Tnl Emergency Paging System
This job is to be performed in conjunction with the testing of
the Fire Telephones at the Tunnel Fire Cabinets. The manual
announcement should be "The following is a Citylink test. One,
Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, Seven, Eight, Nine, Ten."
The message should last about ten seconds.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference Manual: Australian Sound Service - Emergency Paging System
Manual - M-MCL-CU-20001.
3. Use vehicle arrow board and short term lane stoppage and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 20, 22, 23.
4. This job involves, whilst visiting all the odd numbered fire
cabinets to:
(a) listen to manual announcements over the emergency loud
speakers as well as
(b) at fire cabinet D11 listen to an automatic announcement
and
(c) at fire cabinet D17 listen to and ALL announcement
(d) listen to the announcement, in each case, and evaluate
for:-
(i) Clarity - e.g. message should be clear and
understandable,
(ii) Volume - e.g. Clearly hear message, hear above
ambient noise. A suitable volume should be QUITE
loud in the tunnel.
(iii) Listen and be aware for non-functioning loud speakers
and loud speakers with degraded output. The speakers
are mounted at 30m intervals throughout the tunnel
Record the result of your evaluation on form TUNNEL
EMERGENCY PAGING SYSTEM - DOMAIN TUNNEL PA LOUD
SPEAKER TEST - TMF-3012-OP-0366
5. On completion of the Job, return the Job sheet and Form
TUNNEL EMERGENCY PAGING SYSTEM - DOMAIN TUNNEL PA LOUD
SPEAKER TEST - TMF-3012-OP-0366 to the Electrical/Electronics
Supervisor or his representative for evaluation.
6. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the Job.

12 M Maint of TSH tolling equipment

the CML RSE Users Manual maintenance schedule, document no.
M-MCL-ET-1225.
2. Perimeter access gate at technical shelter key required.
3. To access the 400W VDC lamps on the right hand side, set up a
lane closure as per work instruction TMI-3012-OP-0002 and the
TLO procedure PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 17, 18 and Plan 12 for the
left hand side access.
Note: In locations where a rear gantry exists the 400W VDC
lamps are located and accessed via the rear gantry structure.
Note: Any changes made to the closure in Work Done area of
the Job Sheet.
4. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment and
or tools do not fall from the gantry. Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.
Adhere to safety instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 ""Working on
Gantry Structures"".
5. Notify Control Room prior to entering the Technical Shelter.
6. Complete CML RSE Maintenance Plkan PL-MCL-ET-100001.
Preventative Maintenance No:
1201: Inspect electrical Pump set
1202: No procedure to check bolts are tightened. Visually
check accessible bolt markings to ascertain if any movement,
inspect for corrosion.
1204: Inspect cabinets for cleanliness, corrosion , damage,
evidence of possible electrical malfunction, Inspect for
corrosion, ingress of moisture, insect infestation, damage
and security of all fasteners
1205: Checking VDC sensors and connectors.
The following Task is to be also carried out using extreme
care to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter the Fibre
Optic connectors or cables, ensure sufficient fibre optic
cable is available to allow removal of the fibre optic
connector (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
NOTE: Ensure the fibre Optic Connector remains free of
foreign matter.
Carefully remove the Fibre Optic Connector, clean the
connector body of any deposits. Take care to not touch the
Fibre Optic pins within the connector (if touched or dirty,
clean pins with Fibre Optic cleaner).
Apply a light coating of silicon spray to a cloth and wipe
onto the Fibre Optic connector body, replace and exercise the
Fibre Optic Connector release collar.
Where connectors cannot be easily removed, record details in
the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and report the fact
to the Team Leader or his representative.
1206: Clean VR Sensor Unit Vent with brush or similar
7. Record in the area of the Job Sheet below any outstanding
works requiring further attention. Create a new Job sheet
for any outstanding works and notify the Team Leader or his
representative of the outstanding works. Record the New job
number in the "Work Done" area of this job sheet and in the
"Related Job" field of both jobs.
8. Notify Control Room prior to departing from the Technical
Shelter.

12 M Major inspection & test run of the WL TSH generators

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The generator major service ""TYPE B"", as set out in the
Cummins Maintenance report, shall be carried out on the TSH
generator by the sub-contractor in the presence of the
electrical / electronic technician.
2. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
3. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
4. Minor Service ""TYPE B"" Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's
Manual 960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]. The sub-contractor
shall carry out the service as per items listed on the
maintenance report column ""B"" and test as per par 5.
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch on the generator DC
panel to ""RUN"" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch back
to ""AUTO"".
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY &
TEST"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no abnormal noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature. [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back
to ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" the generator will continue to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
6. Fill in the Generator Log Book.
7. Record the
(a) Sub-contractors Maintenance Report No [________]
(b) Sub-contractors Field Report No [________]
(c) Hours run ( from the hour run meter ) [________]
8. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
9. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
10.Raise a new Mainpac Job for any outstanding maintenance work
to be done.
11.Record any thing outside normal parameters in the ""Work
Done"" area of the job sheet.

24 M Insp of Light Poles on Exhibition Street

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the traffic control room prior to commencing this
job.
2. Reference:
MCL Drawings: 0230 to 0239
Asset register: G:\TFM\Operations\Lighting\
Light Poles\Light Pole Asset Register.xls
3. At each Light pole, visually inspect the condition of the
light pole as follow:
(a). Check if the pole is obviously leaning or if there is any
attachments obviously sagging. This is a visual check that
there are no obvious problems.
(b). Check if any attachments are not securely fixed.
(c). Check if there is any impact damage from vehicles. Poles
which have been impacted by vehicles should be replaced.
(d). Check if there are any cracks in the pole, particularly at
the corners of any openings in the pole. Fatigue cracks
often start at the corners of openings
(e). Check if there are any cracked, bent or broken bolts.
Cracked, bent or broken bolts should be replaced.
(f). Check if any welds are cracked or broken. Cracked or broken
welds in critical locations, eg pole to base plate welds,
should be repaired.
(g). Check if there are any bolts, covers or other parts
missing. The action required will depend on the criticality
ofthe missing part.
(h). Check if any nuts are loose or missing (visual check).
Tighten any loose nuts if required.
(i). Check if there are any obvious electrical problems like
exposed wires. Immediate attention is required if these
pose a hazard.
(k). Check if the foundation is undermined or exposed to
standing water. Undermined foundations require a more
detailed assessment. Standing water should be removed by
improved drainage.
(l). Check if the grouting between the base plate and the
foundation is cracked (crack widths greater than 0.5 mm) or
loose. Cracked grout can hold moisture and accelerate
corrosion of anchor bolts. Where grout is loose it should
be replaced.
(m). Clear any clogged drain holes at the base of the pole.
(n). Remove any debris accumulation at the base of the pole,
around the anchor bolts, or elsewhere on the structure.
(o). Comment on the general condition of the protective coating
(note blistering, flaking, rust staining etc). Remedial
action will depend upon the extent of deterioration.
(p). Remove cover plates near the base (where appropriate) and
check for damage to electrical wiring, internal corrosion,
infestation by insects, water and ponding.
5. Record work completed at each Light pole on
attached form TMF-3012-OP-0376 ""Routine Inspection of Light
Poles"".
6. Record any corrective action required in the ""Work Done""
area of the Job Sheet.
7. Return the completed jobsheet to the Civil Supervisor
or his representative.
File Inspection report in File 119.16

03 M Check operation of the Tnl Emergency Paging System
This job is to be performed in conjunction with the testing of
the Fire Telephones at the Tunnel Fire Cabinets.
The manual announcement should be "The following is a Citylink test.
One, Two, Three, Four,Five, Six, Seven, Eight, Nine, Ten."
The message should last about ten seconds.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference Manual: Australian Sound Service - Emergency Paging
System Manual - M-MCL-CU-20001.
3. Use vehicle arrow board and short term lane stoppage
Translink Procedure , PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 20, 22, 23.
4. This job involves whilst visiting all the odd numbered fire
cabinets to:
(a) listen to manual announcements over the emergency loud
speakers as well as
(b) at fire cabinet B23 listen to an automatic announcement
and
(c) at fire cabinet B45 listen to an ALL announcement.
(d) listen to the announcement, in each case, and evaluate
for:-
(i) Clarity - e.g. message should be clear and
understandable
(ii) Volume - e.g. Clearly hear message, hear above ambient
noise. A suitable volume should be QUITE loud in the
tunnel.
(iii) Listen and be aware for non-functioning loud speakers
and loud speakers with degraded output. The speakers
are mounted at 30m intervals throughout the tunnel
Record the result of your evaluation on form TUNNEL
EMERGENCY PAGING SYSTEM - BURNLEY TUNNEL PA LOUD SPEAKER
TEST - TMF-3012-OP-0365
5. On completion of the Job, return the Job sheet and Form
TUNNEL EMERGENCY PAGING SYSTEM - BURNLEY TUNNEL PA LOUD
SPEAKER TEST - TMF-3012-OP-0365 to the Electrical/Electronics
Supervisor or his representative for evaluation.
6. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the Job.

12 M Inspect the Structural components yellow beam

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference: Melbourne City Link - Visual Inspection of the
Beam Report No. 000624vi_005 Date 25 August 2003.
Item 15.1
(a) Inspect the interior of the beam structure at ground level
for evidence of the entry of water or moisture.
(b) Travel the length of the beam and visually examine the full
extent of each joint, looking for evidence of water ingress.
(c) At the junction of each cross-member and the lower face of
the beam, visually inspect for evidence of accumulated water
and or recent moisture.
(d) Whilst carrying out the above inspections, record any
evidence of corrosion and or any degradation of internal
surfaces.
(e) Record details of any water residues, corrosion and or
damage on form ANNUAL BEAM INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0351.
Item 15.2
(a) Visually inspect the internal studs/nuts/packers at ground
level for evidence of moisture and or recent wetness.
(b) Visually inspect the studs/nuts/packers at ground level for
any evidence of corrosion.
(c) Record details of any water residues, corrosion and or
Item 15.3
(a).Visually inspect, from the ground, all external surfaces
and joints of the beam using binoculars.
Examine for the integrity of the paint coating on the
various faces, examine for peeling paint, blisters and
evidence of corrosion.
Record details of any outstanding works for surface coating
damage, corrosion and or damage on form ANNUAL BEAM
INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0351. Raise a new jobsheet for any
outstanding works.
Item 15.4
(a) Visually inspect the Beam to foundation connections
(foundation studs) for signs of degradation or corrosion,
inspect the protective coatings (Coverings and coatings)
for integrity and degradation.
(b) Visually inspect grouting and paintwork for cracks,
blistering, peeling and damage and any corrosion.
Record details of any outstanding works required to correct
cracks, chips or damage to the protective coatings on form
ANNUAL BEAM INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0351.
Raise a new job for outstanding works.
Item 15.5
(a) Visually inspect the foundation moat for effective drainage.
Remove and clean all debris and materials from the moat.
Ensure the moat drains effectively.
Record details of outstanding works required to correct any
water residues and or corrosion and or damage on form
Raise a new jobsheet for outstanding works.
Item 15.6
(a) Visually inspect the beam for signs structural damage like
vandalism, impact or movement.
(b) Visually inspect the access door at the base of the beam to
ensure it is intact and has a full complement of setscrews.
Record details of any outstanding works for vandalism,
impact and or movement on form ANNUAL BEAM INSPECTION
TMF-3012-OP-0351. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
works.
3. Notify the Traffic Control room on completion of the job.

03 M Inspect, Test & Clean Olympic Park Pump Station

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths,
lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting,
Brooms, Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders, Silicon
Lubricant Spray, Rodent Bait Station
A INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the Pumps,
electrical installations and Control panel as well the cleaning,
inspections and maintenance of the related area.
B PUMP AND PUMP OPERATION
1. Notify the Control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference Manual TOJV Pump Station Operation and Maintenance
Manuals - M-STG-ME-20001. Volume 3.
3. WARNING: BOTH THE WET WELL AND THE VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED
CONFINED SPACES AND MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED
SPACE CONDITIONS.
Refer to Work Instruction, Confined Space Entry
TMI-3012-SA-0015.
4. Inspect the Local Control Panel
(a) Check the switchboard, located in Sub-station 5, for
local alarm conditions.
(b) Carry out visual inspection both internally and
externally of the control panel for damage, corrosion,
evidence of insect infestation, ingress of moisture, dust
and grime (clean as required). [_ _]
(c) Check the cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating, inspect the electrical control
equipment. [_ _]
(d) Record readings of the hour run meters, for each pump, in
the Work Done area of the job sheet . [_ _]
5. Inspection of pump wet well and valve pit.
(a) Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the
valve pit, inspect both the wet well and the valve pit
for general cleanliness and debris. Clean if
required. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external condition of the pipework and
valves for evidence corrosion and leaks. [_ _]
6. Switch the pump AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position.
(a) Measure and record the operating current and compare with
the rated (80A) current. [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running or
vibration and abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Check that the cabling to the pump for damage and that it
is clear from possible damage. [_ _]
CAUTION: Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low level
alarm point as lack of submergence may cause pumpset damage.
7. Start pump PSOPP1 (Pump A1 starter) by pressing the START
pushbutton. [_ _]
(a) Record the operating current of the pump, in the Work
Done area of the job sheet. [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
and abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Observe the level controller readout for variations, with
respect to the operation of the pump. [_ _]
(d) Observe that the pump drawdown rate is sufficient to draw
down the water level in the wet well. [_ _]
(e) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton. Check the
operation of the non-return (NRV), as the water flow
stops. The NRV should close with a sharp audible
metallic sound, as well, backflow through the pump should
cease within 30 seconds. If a faulty closure is
suspected, the pump should be re-started, operated
for 2 minutes and the operation of the NRV should then be
monitored again. If a faulty closure is still
suspected, record the details in the Work Done area of
the Job sheet, and report for corrective
maintenance. [_ _]
8. Repeat step 7 for PSOPP2 (Pump A2 starter). [_ _]
9. Repeat step 7 for PSOPP3 (Pump B1 starter). [_ _]
10. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position. [_ _]
11. Check the operation of the float switches. Manually trip
the floats from the valve pit by lifting up the High/High
float and the Low/Low floats respectively with a hook bar
and then checking that the alarms were received at the
Control Room. [_ _]
12. When this job falls in either January, February or March.
Lift the level controller sensor out of the protective
conduit, then carefully, clean the recess in the sensor base
of all dirt and debris. [_ _]
13. Test the operation of the isolating valves by partially
closing and the fully re-opening. [_ _]
14. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Pump Station and
equipment etc, in the Work Done section of the job sheet
and report to the Team Leader or his representative and
raise a new job for any repairs.
15. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
16. Notify the control room that the inspection has been
completed.
C ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. On accessing the control panel(s), be aware of the
atmosphere, use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to
monitor any abnormal events. [_ _]
2. Check the interior lighting of the control panel for
operation, replace faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting
fixture. [_ _]
3. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels. Use an Infra-red temperature
sensor. Temperatures of ambient plus 10?C should be
considered abnormal and must be noted in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team Leader or his
representative is informed of the abnormality. Raise a new
job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
4. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and components for evidence of burn
marks, unusual odours and overheating. Record anything
abnormal in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new jobsheet for any corrective action. Ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. [_ _]
5. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc. [_ _]
6. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required. Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
7. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage. [_ _]
8. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for
dust, grime and condensation, clean enclosures of any
accumulated dust, dirt and debris. [_ _]
9. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.
Clean or replace filters as required. [_ _]
10. Inspect systems, mounted within the control panel(s), for
faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged switches and
buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
11. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators. Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged in
the work done area of the job sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error. [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw connections, for security. [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose. [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
and debris. [_ _]
12. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.
13. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader
or his representative of any corrective actions. [_ _]
D. Building Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the control panel interior for evidence of moisture
ingress. Inspect for source of any water. Record any
details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform the
Team Leader or his representative. [_ _]
2. Check that the control panel(s) are not obstructed by
furnishings and or stored items. Remove any
obstruction. [_ _]
3. Remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of cabinets,
ledges, cable trays, cables, etc. Note: Dust will settle on
all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops of cabinets, tops of
cabinet doors, tops of meter escutcheons etc. [_ _].
4. Clean all exterior surfaces of cabinets using approved
cleaning materials . [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from cabinets, light fittings and
cable trays . [_ _]
6. Remove any accumulated rubbish and debris. [_ _]
7. Sweep and vacuum the floor surfaces at the control
panel(s). [_ _]
8. Visually inspect rodent bait station for bait. Replace bait
station if bait is near exhausted. [_ _]
9. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of the
job sheet. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
corrective actions. [_ _]
10. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service
e.g. Fans, Air Conditioners. [_ _]
(b) All Enclosures are closed and locked. [_ _]
(c) All Lighting turned OFF [_ _]
11. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
12. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to departing.

03 M Insp of Liebert AC units accessed via the Mezzanine Lvl

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job
2. Access to both ERE 03 and ERW 05 is via the Grant Street
stairwell. Both equipment rooms are adjacent to Substation
1. Access from Grant Street is via the mezzanine floor, then
down a ladder to the Domain Tunnel Walkway and then,
10 metres along the walkway to Substation 1 entrance.
Prior to walking along the walkway, be aware of the traffic
conditions and take appropriate precautions.
Use a ladder to climb over the smoke ducts. DO NOT GO
THROUGH THE SMOKE DUCTS.
ACU Air Conditioning Units are located in the respective
equipment rooms, while the condenser units are mounted on the
Mezzanine level above the equipment rooms.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer. Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting. [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with new
setpoint and verify temperature is consistent with
ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer. [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting. [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer. [_ _]
NOTE: LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm. [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear. [_ _]
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation. [_ _]
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation. [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running. [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch. [_ _]
5.4. Inspect for loose connections or leaking coils. [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean the condenser coils if required using compressed
air. [_ _]
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator. [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit. [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits. [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish. [_ _]
7.0. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record
the results on form Equipment Room Inspections
TMF-3012-OP-0347. Ensure the form Equipment Room
Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347 is returned to the Electrical
Electronics Supervisor or his representative. Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Team Leader or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
9.0 Notify the control room on completion of the job.

06 M Check of Vent Station Smoke Damper Actuators
These checks are carried out to verify the operability of the
Ventilation Station smoke duct damper actuators for each
Ventilation Station.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. In conjunction with Traffic Control Room Operators set TCR
PMCS system smoke damper actuator controls for manual
operation
3. Open a minimum of 4 smoke duct dampers upstream of the
ventilation station to prevent negative pressure being
generated in the smoke duct, from the normal ventilation
system, when smoke dampers are opened.
4. Open and close each damper at least twice and observe the
panel for indications of non- standard operation such as
dampers that open or close sluggishly, or fail to open or
close completely.
5. Close the Ventilation station smoke duct dampers.
6. Close tunnel smoke duct dampers.
7. Record in Work Done area of the Job Sheet those dampers that
have suspect operation.
8. Notify the control room om completion of the job.

12 M Routine Maint. of Tunnel Smoke Duct damper actuator

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Approximately 10% of smoke dampers in the tunnel are to be
inspected annually.
The Team Leader Electrical shall obtain the previous year
check sheet TMF-3012-OP-0260 and use to allocate dampers to
be inspected with this job sheet.
2. Obtain Permit to Work for operation of smoke damper by TCRO.
3. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
4. Reference Manual: TROX Technik - Melbourne City Link Tunnel
Project, Operating & Maintenance Instructions Manual
M-STG-VE-26100.
5. Access to the tunnel shall be as per Work Instruction,
Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 23,24,25, and 26. Use the Plan best suited
to the smoke dampers circled for inspection on check sheet
BURNLEY TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF
BURNLEY TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION"" TMF-3012-OP-0260
6. Carry out inspection of smoke dampers circled on check sheet
using the elevated work platform in B mode.
Note that either the LHS or the RHS or both sides of a
nominated damper may require inspection.
7. Request the TCRO to open and then close the smoke dampers
that are to be inspected.
8. Observe the damper blades for non-standard operation such as
(a) dampers that open or close sluggishly
(b) dampers that fail to open or close completely
(c) dampers that move sluggishly.
(d) Record an OK or FAIL result on check sheet BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION TMF-3012-OP-0260
9. Repeat step 8 for all dampers to be inspected.
10. Note the Condition Rating for the dampers tested.
11. Record in Work done area of Job sheet any dampers that have
failed operation and raise new job sheet for repair.
Priority High P1.
12. Notify the TCR on completion of the job.
13. On completion of the job, forward check sheet BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION TMF-3012-OP-0260 to the Team Leader
Electrical or representative for sign off.

06 M Test batt backed emerg and exit lights SUB 3 & Environs

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record
on EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND
ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0245, only those fittings in which the
tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS
TMF-3012-OP-0245, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 3 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0245,
only those light fittings that the battery charger operation
indicator does not function correctly.
8. Remove any excess debris from within lighting diffusers.
9. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
10. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Inspect of ERE16 & RRB03 Liebert AC units in Sub 3 Bldg

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Access to the air conditioners within equipment room ERE16
and RRB03, is via an external door situated on the Burnley
Tunnel walkway 20 metres west of Burnley Portal.
Access to the condensers is via external doors, on south side
of Bldg, into substation 3B.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer. Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting. [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with new
setpoint and verify temperature is consistent with
ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer. [_ _]
c. Repeat above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting. [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer. [_ _]
NOTE: LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm. [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary. Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm. [_ _]
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm drain line
clear. [_ _]
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation. [_ _]
5. ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condensor unit and check for undue cycling
operation. [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running. [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local isolating
switch. [_ _]
5.4. Inspect for loose connections or leaking coils. [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the fan isolator. [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit. [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls. [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits. [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure. [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish. [_ _]
7.0 Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record the
results on form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347.
Ensure the form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347
is returned to the Electrical / Electronics Supervisor or
his representative. Raise a new jobsheet for any
outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Team Leader or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Inspect, test and clean Tunnel TIMS & FES

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Inform Traffic Control Room prior to commencing work.
2. The TIMS and FES over the centre and RHS lanes should be
serviced together using RHS and Centre Lane closure, LHS
TIMS and FES should be serviced using a LHS lane closure.
This excludes the Sign Message Operation and the Sign Test
Result which are carried out on the three signs, LHS, RHS and
centre simultaneously from the equipment room analyser.
3. Reference Manual Symon Services Operation, Training &
Maintenance Manual for TIMS, VSLS & FES M-STG-TM-29943
4. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 27, 28.
5. Equipment Room Analysers
(a) Inspect the TIMS and FES analysers for evidence of burnt
or damaged connections on plugs, electronic cards and
wiring.
(b) Clean the analyser cabinet interiors of any accumulated
dirt or dust.
(c) Press the TEST button on the analyser and monitor the
sign test routine. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in
Sign Test Result column on the form.
(d) Inspect the cabinet for damage, ensuring the door closes
and locks securely.
6. TIMS Signs
(a) Isolate sign power at the sign circuit breaker within
the TIMS sign enclosure.
(b) Check the electronic component boards for evidence of
burning or arcing.
(c) Clean the front fascia of the sign, using Windex and a
soft cloth.
(d) Turn the sign circuit breaker to ON and check the pixel
operation. Record in the comments column if more than
10% of the pixels have failed.
(e) Check the output of the 12VDC power supply and the inputs
to the various drivers and controllers, the voltage
measured, in each case should fall within the range of
11V ?0.8V. Record result ( OK or Fail) in the Sign
inspection column of the form.
(f) Check the operation and alignment of the Light Dependant
Resistor (LDR) by covering the LDR, then by monitoring
the the LEDs on the lighting luminosity board for change,
to determine LDR operation.
(g) Ensure the front fascia, in the area of the LDR, is
clean and completely free of all dirt and grime.
7. FES Signs
(a) Clean the fitting and perspex of all dirt and grime.
(b) Check the sign lighting for operation and replace faulty
components. (Lighting comprises a selection of 18W, 30W &
36W Cool White Fluorescent Tubes.)
(c) Check with the TCR and confirm TCR operation of sign
control.
8. Ensure the control room can control the sign via a TEST
message change, confirm the sign operation back to the
operator. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in the sign message
operation column of the form.
9. Record the results of TIMS inspections and any comments on
form TIMS SYSTEM INSPECTION - DOMAIN TUNNEL TIMS SIGNS AND
ANALYSERS TMF-3012-OP-0288, and record the result of the FES
inspections and any comments on form FES SYSTEM INSPECTION -
DOMAIN TUNNEL FES SIGNS AND ANALYSERS TMF-3012-OP-303, for
any test that FAILs, record the details in the comments
column of the appropriate form.
10. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable,
Leaky Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipework,
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet.
11. On completion of the job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet. Raise a
new job sheet for any corrective work required.
12. Notify the control room on completion of work.

A INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the electrical
installations of Substations as well the cleaning, inspections
and maintenance of the relevant areas.

areas.

given to the following:

ventilation fans, if operating, toreduce ambient
noise. [_ _]

other environmental conditions. [_ _]

discharge or looseness of components. [_ _]

connections for degradation and damage. [_ _]

inspection results requiring further corrective actions.

fans are returned to service. [_ _]

03 M Load test of the MGE UPS

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the work.
2. Check with the control room if any UPS alarms are relevant.
3. Refer to MGE UPS Systems Manual, Galaxy User Manual
E-679380XT/FA, M-STG-EL-24009, and Schnieder Electric Tunnel
Electrical Services Training Notes, M-STG-EL-24001,
Section 9.
WARNING
THE UPS BATTERY POTENTIAL IS APPROXIMATELY 380 VOLTS AND IS
EARTHED. THE BATTERIES CAN DELIVER A FAULT CURRENT OF
APPROXIMATELY 9000 AMPS. EXPOSED BATTERY TERMINALS ARE
DANGEROUS AND MUST NOT BE TOUCHED. IN THE VICINITY OF THE
BATTERIES USE ONLY TOOLS WHICH ARE FULLY INSULATED.
SAFETY GLASSES MUST BE WORN WHEN CARRYING OUT MEASUREMENTS
ON THE BATTERIES.
4. Check the UPS control panel readout for alarms and or normal
status. If an alarm is found, record the alarm in the Work
Done Area of the Job Sheet. Do Not Continue with this Job if
an alarm is present. [_ _]
5. Record measurements on form 03 M MGE Uninterruptible Power
Supply Battery Inspection and Test, TMF-3012-OP-0099.
6. Measure and record the UPS room temperature. [_ _]
7. Check and record DC voltage and AC ripple voltage for each
bank of batteries. If a discrepancy is found then record in
the Work Done Area of the Job Sheet. Do Not Continue
this job sheet if there is a discrepancy in the readings
recorded and the readings expected. [_ _]
8. To simulate a power failure, Open Mains 1 Isolator (Q1), the
UPS operation will change to the batteries. [_ _]
9. Operate the UPS, in this mode, for at least 10
minutes. [_ _]
10. Measure and record the DC voltage for each shelf of the
battery banks.
11. Measure and record the DC current flow in each battery bank.
12. Return the UPS to normal operation by closing Mains 1
Isolator Q1. [_ _]
13. With an Optical thermometer measure the temperature of the
batteries and their inter-connections. Temperature readings
should approximate ambient room temperature. When a
connection is found to having a temperature greater than 5
degrees above room temperature, in the Work Done Area of
the Job Sheet, record the battery location, terminal
identification, measured temperature. [_ _]
14. With an Optical thermometer measure the average temperature
of the two (AC & DC) capacitor banks and record the result.
15. With an anemometer measure and record the airflow from each
of the UPS cooling fans.
16. With the Optical thermometer measure and record the
temperature of each of the UPS cooling fans. [_ _]
17. Ensure Normal operation of the UPS. [_ _]
18. Sweep and clean the UPS room:
Sweep the floor and remove accumulated webs from the
walls. [___]
Sweep the control panel room floors as well, vacuum the
control panel enclosures and any surfaces that will collect
dust deposits. [___]
Clean the front panel of all accumulated dirt and
dust. [___]
Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish. [_ _]
19. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the UPS room and
equipment etc, in the "Work Done"section of the job
sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
20. Leave a duplicate 03M MGE Uninterruptible Power Supply
Battery Inspection and test form in the UPS room. Compare
previously recorded data and record in the Work Done
Area of the Job Sheet any data that shows any degradation.
21. Notify the control room on completion of the job."

****Complete the following CityLink Asset Condition Rating****
ASSET CONDITION RATING
Rate the Condition of the Asset.
Note:
[ 1 ] - Excellent.
Asset is new or in as new condition
[ 2 ] - Good.
Asset is fully operational, well presented, performing
it's intended function.
[ 3 ] - Fair.
Asset is functional and operational but showing signs of
deterioration that will result is some intervention
works possibly within the next 12 months. May not be
performing it's intended function to the full degree.
[ 4 ] - Poor.
Asset is functional and operational but showing major
signs of deterioration that will require intervention
works within the next 3 months. Not performing it's
intended function.
CONDITION RATING SCORE [_ _]

in the Work Done area of the job sheet(photograph if possible).

06 M Inspection of ponds
1. Keys to perimeter access gates are required.
2. Inspect the pollution control ponds and record the results on the
form Sediment Ponds Inspection TMF-3012-OP-0035:
(a) Remove rubbish and debris from the pond and spillway.
(b) Inspect the pond embankments for structural integrity
and erosion.
(c) Check pond for excessive weed infestation, odours,
breeding insects and sediment accumulation.

necessary.

lining of the pond.

materials causing a blockage.
(g) Inspect the low flow outlets for blockages, remove any
accumualted debris or materials capable of causing a
blockage.

parameters in the section of the Job Sheet below and raise
a new job sheet for any repair works that are required.
Report any outstanding works to the Civil Team Leader."

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of Sub 3B HV system for operatn & Faults

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor under the
supervision of an
electrical/electronics technician.
3. Refer to Manual ""Merlin Gerin Masterpact Instruction Notice""
M-STG-EL-24030
4. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carriedout and that
(a) The ""General Section "" of the above job has been completed and
(b) The number of operation cycles of the circuit breakers has been
recorded and
(c) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring
all cabling, connections and installation meet the AS 3000
standard.
5. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each of the
circuit breakers
and Isolators. [_ _]
6. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations including
dateof test, ground and
weather conditions are to be recorded and reported to the
Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an earthing
resistance test in
accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for tightness of
connections,
and the condition of system components e.g. Earthing
electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
7. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to be
recorded and reported
to the Electrical/electronics team leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance and
cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are clean
and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion. Clean and
tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal
and battery voltage and battery temperature prior to
commencing the test as well
as at completion of test. Where the battery or terminal
voltage at completion of test
is less than 80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of
it's serviceable life and replacement options should be
recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i) Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for damage
etc.
8. (Capacitor Banks at Sub 3 (Indoor))
(a) Carry out a thorough visual inspection, record and report any
damage.
(b) Visually inspect the outside and inside of the enclosure for
signs of corrosion on
capacitor cans and frames. Clean and remove accumulated dirt
and dust.
(c) Visually inspect all earthing and cabling connections, check for
signs of overheating
or broken strands. Check and tighten connections as required.
9. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet, inspection
resultsrequiring
further corrective actions. Raise a new job sheet for any
outstanding works and
notify the Team Leader or his representative. Include in the
Related Job"" field
of the new and this job, the job number of the alternate Job. [_
_]

03 M Maint of the Variable Message Sign

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

Maintenance Manual, M-MCL-TM-100026.

cabinets, sign, external cables and conduits for vandalism,
mechanical damage, water ingress, condensation or insect
infestation. Also check inside cabinets for tripped circuit
breakers, disconnected wires, burn marks from excessive heat.

the Work Done area of the Job Sheet if the failed LEDs exceed

12 M Joint Leakage Drain Inspections & Cleaning

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26.
In the work done area record:
a. Any deviations from the plan.
b. Lane closure start time.
c. Lane closure finish time.
d. Weather conditions.
3. Joint Leakage Drains (JLD) are located on the outside of the
left and right hand lanes of the tanked section of the
Burnley Tunnel.
4. Inspect JLDrains for water flow, blockages, deposits and
conditions. Record the details for each drain on form
Burnley Tunnel Joint Leakage Drain TMF-3012-OP-0275.
5. The JLD's are inspected via an inspection point which is a
square Gatic plate with a hinged lid. This lid is held secure
in position by a Philips head screw.
6. Access both ends of drain by unscrewing covers in both the
LHL and the RHL.
(a) To inspect the drain sets, shine the torch down one open
cover, then at the corresponding open cover, using the
extendable mirror, look for the lighted torch.
(b) Record the condition of the pipe e.g. the cleanliness
and / or blockage of the drain on form Burnley Tunnel
Joint Leakage Drain TMF-3012-OP-0275.
(c) Record the condition of each drain e.g. buildup of
calcite, slime, silt etc and whether or not there is a
flow of water present.
**Use Condition Words : WET, DRY, CLEAR, OBSTRUCTED and
if obstructed record the action that was taken to clear
the obstruction ( ie: hydrant flushed or Jet flushed).
7. If there is water flow present, then at the dirty water pit,
inspect the Dirty Water pit where the flow enters (If it does
enter into a pit). Measure and record the flow and elapsed
time for on form Burnley Tunnel Joint Leakage Drain
TMF-3012-OP-0275.
8. Record all details on the inspection sheet, as all the
information is important.
9. Ensure all the pit covers and Gatic covers are closed and
secured on completion of each inspection.
10. Ensure a completed copy of the form Burnley Tunnel Joint
Leakage Drain TMF-3012-OP-0275. are forwarded to the Civil
Team Leader or representative on completion of the job and
prior to end of shift. Civil Team Leader or representative
is to record and sign off each form and raise any actions
(job sheets) for further inspection or cleaning
conditions. Record the details for each drain between B20 to ,,B38
on form Burnley Tunnel Joint Leakage Drain ,,TMF-3012-OP-0275A.
Joint Leakage Drain TMF-3012-OP-0275A.

12 M Test & inspection of the DT deluge installation

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The twelve monthly deluge system inspection and test shall be
carried out in conjunction with the fire-protection
sub-contractor and the Traffic Control Room Officers (TRCO).
2. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing the job.
(a). A tunnel closure is required. A Memorandum of Consent
(MOC) and a Permit to Work approval is required from
Translink Operations, the Maintenance Manager or his
representative prior to commencing work.
(b) Access to the Domain tunnel shall be as per Work
Instruction, Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan Domain Tunnel
Portal Closure.
3. Reference Drawings SLG-FS- 30900 to SLG-FS-30911.
4. Prior to testing the deluge zone spray system:
(a) Ensure that the maximum capacity is available in the
dirty water sump and holding tank at the Yarra Crossing
Dirty Water Pit and the Swan Street Water Treatment
Plant. [_ _]
(b) Request the TCRO to close the bypass valve between the
pump station dirty water and the ground water sump
pits. [_ _]
(c) Install the bungs in the TAM sensors.,,[_ _]
6. Discharge the Deluge Spray Zones.
(a) Request the TCRO to actuate one (1) specified deluge
spray zones, starting at the East Portal then progressing
westward. Spray pattern may take 30 seconds to
establish.
(b) Observe that the spray pattern provides coverage of the
tunnel floor area and note defective sprays and faulty
equipment for replacement. Observe for 15 seconds.
(c) Request the TCRO to close the one (1) specified deluge
zones.
(d) Functional test should take approximately one minute
between activation and closing the valve.
(e) Check that the deluge valve has fully closed.
(f) It should take approximately 5 minutes for each zone.
(g) It is important that the levels at the Yarra Crossing
Dirty Water Pit and the Swan St Pit are monitored at all
times by the TRCO during testing. Testing must cease if
the pit levels are high and only resumed when the pit
levels have dropped sufficiently to accommodate the
deluge water.
7. Carry out step 6 for the remaining deluge zones, one zone at
a time. After activating zone FSP W016, activate both zones
FSP W016 and zone FSP W017 together, checking that there is
no Low Water Pressure alarm, record results on form DOMAIN
TUNNEL DELUGE TEST - 12 M OPERATIONAL TEST OF DOMAIN TUNNEL
DELUGE SYSTEM TMF-3012-OP-0256
8. Manually operate the six (6) sectioning valves, in the fire
main, through a close and open cycle. Confirm with TCRO the
operational status of the valve as it is operated. [_ _]
9. Record on form DOMAIN TUNNEL DELUGE TEST - 12 M OPERATIONAL
TEST OF DOMAIN TUNNEL DELUGE SYSTEM TMF-3012-OP-0256, the
result of the tests for each deluge zone and sectioning
valve.
10. Request the TCRO to open bypass valves between the pumps
station dirty water and ground water sump pits and to ensure
that operation of the pumps have returned to normal. Only
ground water pump in operation and the dirty water is
flowing via the triple interceptor. Perform regular visual
inspections to ensure that there is no overflow from
the dirty water tundish.
11. Remove the bungs in the TAM sensors once the deluge test is ,,
completed [_ _]
12. Record any follow up requirements in the Work Done area of
the Job sheet and raisea Job Sheet for any outstanding
works. Priority High P1.
13. Record the sub-contractors work sheet number in the Work
Done area of the job sheet and forward the sub-contractor
confirmation sheet to the Team Leader - Electrical or his
representative.
14. Notify the control room on completion of the work.
15. Forward completed check form DOMAIN TUNNEL DELUGE TEST -
12 M OPERATIONAL TEST OF DOMAIN TUNNEL DELUGE SYSTEM
TMF-3012-OP-0256, to the Team Leader
- Electrical or his representative upon completion of the
job.

12 M Collect dust sample from atop Jet Fan for analysis

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Collecting of dust sample should be performed in conjunction
with mid year Burnley Tunnel Jet Fan maintenance activities,
as this will ensure all necessary Traffic Management is in
place.
2. Refer to procedure TMI-3012-OP-0042, Tunnel Dust Sampling.
3. The dust sample must be taken from the top of a Jet Fan that
is located between Burnley Tunnel sections B50 and B54.
Note: There are four Jet Fans located in this section of the Burnley
Tunnel, these are JFE32 (Right Lane), JFE33 (Left Lane),
JFE34 (Right Lane), and JFE35 (Left Lane).
4. Take two samples from any one of the above Jet Fans. The two
samples are to be taken with the use of an uncontaminated
disposable glove by sweeping up the dust by hand.
An approximate amount of two tablespoons per sample is
adequate for testing. Place the dust samples into two
separate clear zip bags (sealable bags). Eye protection
and a Class P2 Dust mask should be worn whilst taking the
samples, as the dust particles may be disturbed and become
airborne.
5. Label both test samples with the Jet Fan number, job number
and date.
6. Forward both samples to the Maintenance Engineer, or
Supervisor Elect or his representative who will arrange for
testing to be carried out by AWN Consultants
(ph: 03 9758 7299).

01 W Mon, m'sure & report Swan St pump stn flows
The measure of water flowing from the Swan Street pump station
is a measure of all the water collected in the Burnley Tunnel
drainage systems, from both dirty and Groundwater sources.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. For detail of Job, refer to Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL
DRAINAGE TMI-3012-OP-0031.
3. The Civil Team leader is to provide a copy of the previous
WEEKLY BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS TMF-3012-OP-0233 for
detail of the previous readings.
4. At the Swan Street Pump Station Motor Control Centre, record
the Time and the Total flow in kilo litres for the pump
station on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS
TMF-3012-OP-0233.
5. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
6. Ensure a copy of the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS
TMF-3012-OP-0233 is forwarded to the Civil Team Leader for
evaluation on completion of the job.
Note: An increase or decrease in the pump station outflows
in excess of 0.5 litres/s could indicate a problem. Raise a
job to investigate to check the various bay flows for the
reason to the change in water flowrate.
