and FES should be serviced using a LHS lane closure. This
excludes the Sign Message Operation and the Sign Test Result
which are carried out on the three signs, LHS, RHS and centre
simultaneously from the equipment room analyser.
3. Reference Manual Symon Services Operation, Training &
Maintenance Manual for TIMS, VSLS & FES M-STG-TM-29943
4. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure
PR-RS-IR-059 Plans 27, 28
5. Equipment Room Analysers
(a) Inspect the TIMS and FES analysers for evidence of burnt
or damaged connections on plugs, electronic cards and
wiring.
(b) Clean the analyser cabinet interiors of any accumulated
dirt or dust.
(c) Press the TEST button on the analyser and monitor the
sign test routine. Record the result (OK or Fail) in
Sign Test Result column on the form.
(d) Inspect the cabinet for damage, ensuring the door closes
and locks securely.
6. TIMS Signs
(a) Isolate sign power at the sign circuit breaker within
the TIMS sign enclosure.
(b) Check the electronic component boards for evidence of
burning or arcing.
(c) Clean the front fascia of the sign, using Windex and a
soft cloth.
(d) Turn the sign circuit breaker to ON and check the pixel
operation. Record in the comments column if more than
10% of the pixels have failed.
(e) Check the output of the 12VDC power supply and the inputs
to the various drivers and controllers, the voltage
measured, in each case should fall within the range of
10.2V and 11V . Record result ( OK or Fail) in the Sign
inspection column of the form.
(f) Check the operation and alignment of the Light Dependant
Resistor (LDR) by covering the LDR, then by monitoring
the LEDs on the lighting luminosity board for change, to
determine LDR operation.
(g) Ensure the front fascia, in the area of the LDR, is clean
and completely free of all dirt and grime.
7. FES Signs
(a) Clean the fitting and perspex of all dirt and grime.
(b) Check the sign lighting for operation and replace faulty
components. (Lighting comprises a selection of 18W, 30W &
36W Cool White Fluorescent Tubes.)
(c) Check with the TCR and confirm TCR operation of sign
control.
8. Ensure the control room can control the sign via a TEST
message change, confirm the sign operation back to the
operator. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in the sign message
operation column of the form.
9. Record the results of the TIMS inspections and any comments
on form TIMS SYSTEM INSPECTION - BURNLEY TUNNEL TIMS SIGNS
AND ANALYSERS TMF-3012-OP-0287, and record the result of the
FES inspections and any comments on form FES SYSTEM
INSPECTION - BURNLEY TUNNEL FES SIGNS AND ANALYSERS
TMF-3012-OP-0302, for any test that FAILs, record the details
in the comments column of the appropriate form.
10. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable,
Leaky Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipe work,
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the Work
Done area of the Job Sheet .
11. On completion of the job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet. Raise a
new job sheet for any corrective work required.
12. Notify the control room on completion of work.

12 M Inspect of Liebert AC units accessed via the EE Tunnel.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The 12 month service of the air conditioner shall be carried
out by the sub-contractor in the presence of the electrical
electronic technician and in conjunction with the 3 monthly
service.

(a) Arrange for the control room to start Supply Air fan
ESFP01. ESFP01 is the Supply Air for the Emergency Egress
Tunnel.

Egress Tunnel lighting prior to entering the tunnel.
4. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project. M-STG-ME-27400.
5. Check the electrical switchboard for
(a) faulty indicating lamps [_ _]
(b) connections, contacts, wiring and or components that may
be overheated. [_ _]
6. Compare the meter readings of the motor current with the
nameplate ratings. [_ _]
7. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following electrical
service:
(a) Check switchboard for overload settings. [_ _]
(b) Check all electrical control equipment operations and
calibration. [_ _]
(c) Check functionality and calibration of microprocessor
based controls. [_ _]
8. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following mechanical
service at the compressor.
(a) Accurately assess and record compressor
superheat. [_ _]
(b) Check and record the suction and discharge
pressures. [_ _]
(c) Check that the suction and discharge pressures are normal
and stable. [_ _]
(d) Check the setting and operation of the high and low
pressure cut out switches. [_ _]
(e) Confirm that the refrigerant charge is correct and that
there are no leaks. [_ _]
(f) Check the crankcase heater for correct operation. [_ _]
(g) Confirm that the refrigerant is dry (use sight glass),
fit a new dryer if required. [_ _]
(h) Check that the compressor mounting rubbers are secure and
serviceable. [_ _]
9. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following mechanical
service at the evaporator.
(a) Check the efficiency of the evaporator. [_ _]
(b) Check the evaporator air flow. [_ _]
(c) Check the evaporator fan operation for efficiency and
rectify any degraded operation. [_ _]
(d) Check the evaporator for leaks, repair any faults
found. [_ _]
(e) Check the filter media for efficiency and operation, fit
a new filter if required. [_ _]
10. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following mechanical
service at the condenser.
(a) Check the condenser air flow. [_ _]
(b) Check the cooling fan(s) operation for efficiency and
rectifying any degraded operation. [_ _]
(c) Check the condenser for leaks, repair any faults
11. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following mechanical
service at the humidifier (where fitted).
(a) Check the humidifier inlet water strainer for
blockage. [_ _]
(b) Check the humidifier operation. [_ _]
12. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
13. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
14. If sub contractor costs are unknown use the amount entered
in the Estimated Job Costs as an additional cost in the
transactions. Use Sub-contractor Costs - Outside Services.

03 M Measure & report on BT GW TNL Bay flows in drainage sys

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 21, 22, 25, 26.
3. References:
(a) Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0031.
(b) Operation & Maintenance Manual - Tunnel Drainage Stage 2
Design Report R-STG-EN-006 Rev 1.
4. At each bay flow groundwater pit.
(a) Measure the Volume/time water flow from each agi-pipe,
in-turn, into the pit. Readings are carried out by
collecting the water, from an agi-pipe, in a calibrated
measuring container for 5 to 10 seconds.
e.g. 800 mls/10 secs
450 mls/10 secs
1 litre/8 secs
The results are then measured and recorded on the form
BURNLEY TUNNEL - BAY FLOW MONITORING TMF-3012-OP-0235.
5. (a) Carry out pit inspections on bay flow groundwater pits
201, 202, 203, 238, 239, 240, 241, 242, 243, 244, 245,
246, 247 & 251 whilst doing the above readings and
record pit conditions on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL
GROUNDWATER PIT AND PIPE INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0232.
This form is supplied with the six weekly Burnley Tunnel
pit inspections, segment flow and bore level job sheet.
(b) Use a torch to inspect each pipe and associated pits for
cleanliness and the accumulation of calcites.
(c) Record the build up of calcites in the pipes and pits in
Millimetres (mm). Cleaning and removal of calcites is
required when a build up of 50mm occurs in a 200mm pipe
or a 25mm in a 100mm pipe.
(d) Record a description of the calcite. e.g. slimy, milky
or hard etc.
(e Record the results on form BURNLEY TUNNEL GROUNDWATER PIT
AND PIPE INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0232.
6. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
7. Ensure the completed copy of the forms:
BURNLEY TUNNEL - BAY FLOW MONITORING TMF-3012-OP-0235 and
BURNLEY TUNNEL GROUNDWATER PIT AND PIPE INSPECTIONS
TMF-3012-OP-0232 are forwarded to the Civil Team Leader or
representative for evaluation on completion of the job and
prior to the end of the shift. Civil Team Leader or
representative is to record and raise actions (job sheets)
and sign off each form and raise any actions (Job sheets) for
further inspections or cleaning.

03 M Insp Thytec UPS System SL TSH's

03 M Inspection of Thytec UPS system in SL TSH's
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
3. Refer to Manual: Thytec 30KVA UPS 12 Pulse
[ M-MCL-ME20000/20011 ] Manual.
4. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
charged ) record results in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037. [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts: A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
5. At By-pass Switch (Wall Mounted)
(a) Press the TRANSFER button, on the UPS control panel, to
transfer the UPS to the by-pass mode.
(b) Wait until the amber By-Pass led is illuminated.
(c) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet,
to the OFF position, to isolate the batteries.
(d) Press the OFF button, on the UPS control panel, to
switch OFF the UPS unit.
(e) Switch the EXTERNAL BY-PASS switch (wall mounted above
UPS) to the BY-PASS position. The UPS unit is now
by-passed.
WARNING: DO NOT USE THE INTERNAL BY-PASS SWITCH, AS THIS
SWITCH IS NOT INTERLOCKED.
(f) Switch the EXTERNAL by-pass switch to the NORMAL
position.
(g) Press the ON button, on the UPS control panel. An UPS
start is initiated.
(h) Wait for INV. ON green led to illuminate.
(i) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet,
to the ON position to connect the batteries to the UPS.
(j) After about 30 secconds the BYPASS led will go OFF and
the INVERTER led will illuminate, indicating the load is
on the inverter. A noticeable change in the operating
noise of the UPS will also indicate the change of load.
6. UPS Unit.
(a) Do not operate the EMERGENCY STOP push button, on the
front of the UPS Panel, unless in extreme emergency, as
damage to the UPS electrical equipment can occur.
(b) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.
[_ _]
(c) Remove the air filter, clean and re-install, ( replace
air filter if necessary ) [_ _]
(d) Check for air flow above grills on top of the panel.
( with fan in operation ) [_ _]
(e) Visual Inspection of capacitors for any oil leaks. [_ _]
(f) Switch OFF the ""MAIN UPS"" electrical supply. The load
should then transfer to the UPS, supplying from the
batteries.
(g) Check and monitor, on the UPS display, the load current
(max. 42A per phase 30kVA UPS or max 55A per phase 40kVA
UPS).
(h) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037. [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts: A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
(i) Leave the UPS supply the load for at least ten minutes.
(j) Switch the Normal electricity supply isolator to the ON
position. The load will revert to the Normal power
supply.
7. Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
(b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on Panel
Door, is in the upright position and is not tripped.
(c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
CB ( nominally 270V. ) [_ _]
8. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the "" Work
Done "" area of the job sheet.
9.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

_]

12 M Test of batt backed emerg and exit lights SUB 1

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Notify the control room of the areas that will be effected
during this test.
3. Refer to Australian Standard AS/NZS 2293.2 : 1995. This
standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate.
Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 1, ERE 01,
03, ERW 05 & ERW 06 TMF-3012-OP-X242, only those fittings in
which the tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 1, ERE 01, 03, ERW 05 & ERW 06
TMF-3012-OP-X242, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUB 1, ERE 01, 03, ERW 05 & ERW 06
TMF-3012-OP-X242, only those light fittings that the battery
charger operation indicator does not function correctly.
8. Clean all light emitting and reflecting surfaces of the
emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE
TEST - SUB 1, ERE 01, 03, ERW 05 & ERW 06 TMF-3012-OP-0242
for subsequent replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Inspect, test and clean Burnley Tunnel VSLS signs

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Inform Traffic Control Room prior to commencing work.
2. The VSLS on the RHL wall should be serviced using a RHL Lane
closure, VSLS units on the LHL wall should be serviced using
a LHS lane closure. This excludes the VSLS Sign Message
Operation and the Sign Test Result which are carried out on
the two signs, LHS and RHS simultaneously from the equipment
room analyser.
3. Reference Manual Symon Services Operation, Training &
Maintenance Manual for TIMS, VSLS & FES M-STG-TM-29943
4. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 20, 23, 24, 25, 26 and 29.
5. Equipment Room Analysers
(a) Inspect the VSLS analyser for evidence of burnt or
damaged connections on plugs, electronic cards and
wiring.
(b) Clean the cabinet interior of any accumulated dirt or
dust.
(c) Press the TEST button on the analyser and monitor the
sign test routine. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in
Sign Test Result column on the form.
(d) Inspect the cabinet for damage, ensuring the door closes
and locks securely.
6. VSLS Signs
Note: As at 10-05-04 the large VSLS units at Power St,
Kingsway On ramp and Westgate Freeway have been
replaced with new generation VSLS units. Voltage Test
levels are different on the old and new generation
units.
(a) Isolate sign power at the sign circuit breaker within
the VSLS sign enclosure.
(b) Check the electronic component boards for evidence of
burning or arcing.
(c) Clean the front facia of the sign, using Windex and a
soft cloth.
(d) Turn the sign circuit breaker to ON and check the pixel
operation. Record in the comments column of the form
VSLS Systems Inspections Burnley Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0299
if more than 10% of the pixels have failed.
(e) (i) Check and adjust the output of the 12VDC power supply
and the inputs to the various drivers and
controllers, the voltage measured, in each case must
fall within the range of (10.2V and 11V old VSLS
units) and (12.5 to 13VDC and 6.5 to 6.7V for new
VSLS units) . Record result ( OK or Fail) in the Sign
inspection column of the form VSLS Systems
Inspections Burnley Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0299.
(ii) On the small VSLS signs (within the tunnel), check
and adjust the output of the 24VDC power supply and
the inputs to the various drivers and controllers,
the voltage measured, in each case must fall within
the range of 23.2V and 24V. Record result ( OK or
Fail) in the Sign inspection column of the form VSLS
Systems Inspections Burnley Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0299.
(iii) On the LARGE VSLS signs (outside the tunnel), check
the range of 12.0 to 12.1 V and 6.5 to 6.7V.
Record result ( OK or Fail) in the Sign inspection
column of the form VSLS Systems Inspections Burnley
Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0299.
The 12 V power supply, supplies the VSLS sign Red
LEDs, while the 24V power supply, supplies the White
LEDs. The Small VSLS signs have 4 LEDs per pixel
while the Large VSLS signs have 3 Leds per pixel.
(f) Check the operation and alignment of the Light Dependant
Resistor (LDR) by
(i) covering the LDR will cause the display intensity to
reduce
(ii) shining a torch onto the LDR will cause the display
intensity to increase. (This function cannot be
tested with the present configuration).
7. Ensure the control room can control the sign via a TEST
message change, confirm the sign operation back to the
operator. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in the sign message
operation column of the form VSLS Systems Inspections
Burnley Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0299.
8. Results of inspections and comments are recorded on form
VSLS Systems Inspections Burnley Tunnel TMF-3012-OP-0299 for
tests that FAIL, record details in the comments column of the
form.
9. On completion of the job record any outstanding corrective
actions required in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
Raise a new job sheet for any corrective work required.
10. Notify the control room on completion of work.

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor
under the supervision of an electrical/electronics
technician.
3. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carried out and that
(a) The General Section of the above job has been completed
and
(b) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring all cabling, connections and
installation meet the AS 3000 standard.
4. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each
Circuit Breaker and Isolator. [_ _]
5. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations
including date of test, ground and weather conditions are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an
earthing resistance test in accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for
tightness of connections, and the condition of system
components e.g. Earthing electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
6. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance
and cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are
clean and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion. Clean and tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal and battery voltage and
battery temperature prior to commencing the test as
well as at completion of test. Where the battery or
terminal voltage at completion of test is less than
80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of it's serviceable life and
replacement options should be recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i) Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for
damage etc.
7. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions. Raise a new
job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative. Include in the Related Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job. [_ _]
8. At Substations fill-in the log book. [_ _]

M-OMB-OM-20000.

5. Work plan for AHU 1
5.1 Check the unit for damage, corrosion as well as, damage to the
ducting and
connections. [_ _]
5.2 Check the unit, whilst in operation, for any unusual noise and any
vibration. [_ _]
5.3 Check air filters, fit new filter media as required. 8 off Filters
610mm X 610mm X 570mm.
Clean and refit wire retaining frame. [_ _]
5.4 Check pressure drop across the filter media. [_ _]
5.5 Check fan mounts, keys, grub screws and fastenings for security.
[_ _]
5.6 Check the fan motor and the fan bearings for leaks of grease.
Remove excess grease
and clean. [_ _]
5.7 Check the condition and tension of the vee belts, as well as the
pulley wear, adjust of
fit new vee-belts if required. [_ _]
5.8 Check that the drip tray is clean and that the drain is clear of
blockages. [_ _]
5.9 Check hot water heat exchanger for leaks. [_ _]
5.10 Check the hot water piping and control valves for damage and leaks.
[_ _]
5.11 Check dampers for operation, damage and or corrosion, repair faultycomponents.
[_ _]
6. Work plan for Chiller Unit - CH 1
6.1. Check the unit for undue noise and vibration whilst the unit is
running e.g .Noisy fan
motors, noisy compressor unit, loose access panels, loose piping.
[_ _]
6.2. Clear any accumulated debris from condenser airflow inlet. [_ _]
6.3. Check condenser coils for damage. Clean with compressed air if
necessary. [_ _]
6.4. Measure and record the output air temperature of the condenser.
6.5 Check the compressor for gas leaks and ensure there is sufficient
oil in
compressor. [_ _]
6.6 Check the compressor sump heaters for operation. [_ _]
6.7 Inspect the compressor and its components for damage or corroded
components. [_ _]
6.8 Check the compressor flexible mounts for serviceability, replace
damaged or ineffective
flexible mounts. [_ _]
6.9 Check the operation of all safety controls, e.g. HP, LP and oil
safety switches. [_ _]
6.10 Check all electrical cables for security and fixings. [_ _]
6.11 Check the sight glass for level of oil, and the presence or not,
ofbubbles in the
refrigerant flow. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the job
sheet, if the oil level is low
or if bubbles are present in the refrigerant flow. [___]
7. Repeat Step 6 for Chiller Unit - CH 2.

8.1. With fan operating, check the condenser unit for noise and

8.2. Clear any accumulated debris from the airflow path. Clean the

grime using compressed air. [_ _]
8.3. Check the condenser coils for damage. [_ _]
8.4. Check and record the temperature of the air expelled from the

8.5. Check complement of operating fans is representitive of thermal

of any sightings.

(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.

(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.

terminals.

winding heater bridge. Record the result in the ""Work

connections and carry out

and earth. Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.

theheater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.

megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a

Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate. Notify the Team Leader or his

outstanding works.

par 5.
4. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch on the generator DC
panel to ""RUN"" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch
back to ""AUTO""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY &
TEST"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switch board back
to ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" the generator will continune to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]

check sheet TMF-3012-OP-0258 and use to allocated dampers to
be inspected with this job sheet.
2. Obtain Permit to Work for operation of smoke damper by TCRO.
3. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
4. Reference Manual: TROX Technik - Melbourne City Link Tunnel
Project, Operating & Maintenance Instructions Manual
M-STG-VE-26100.
5. Access to the tunnel shall be as per Work Instruction,
Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 23,24,25, and 26. Use the Plan best suited
to the smoke dampers circled for inspection on check sheet
""DOMAIN TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF

6. Carry out inspection of smoke dampers circled on check sheet
DOMAIN TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION"" TMF-3012-OP-0258 using
the elevated work platform in B mode. Note that either the
LHS or the RHS or both sides of a nominated damper may
require inspection.

TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF
DOMAIN TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION"" TMF-3012-OP-0258 to

05 Y Inspect the welds of the North Sticks

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference: Melbourne City Link - The Stick Wall Periodic
Non-Destructive Testing - Scope. Report No. 4199/002 Provided
by Intico.
3. Refer to Report No. 4199/007
Item 1.1
External
Examine the external features from the stick to foundation
interface up to a minimum of 2 metres above the baseplate
for evidence of metal and or paint cracking as well as
evidence of corrosion setting in.
(a) Visually examine the welds connecting the vertical
stiffeners to the skin plates.
(b) Visually examine the welds connecting the upper base plate
to the vertical elements (Stiffeners and skin plates).
Internal
Examine the all internal features, using the access door,
from the upper base plate up to a minimum height of 500 mm
evidence of corrosion setting in. A torch and mirror is
required.
(c) Visually examine the welds connecting the vertical
stiffeners to the skin plates
(d) Visually examine the welds connecting the upper base plate
(e) Examine the general internal cavity for visible degradation
as well as any evidence of moisture of water deposits.
(f) Record all details of any cracks in the metal or welds or
paint surfaces along with any evidence of water residues as
well as any corrosion and or degradation. Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
Item 1.2
(a) Visually examine the protective "Denso Tape" wrap on each
of the fixing nuts. Examine for signs of deterioration and
for any evidence of corrosion of the nut or stud.
(b) Record details of any deterioration of the protective wrap
and or corrosion. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
works.
Item 1.3
(a) Visually inspect the external surface of the welds joining
the two box sections of the stick, at splice level.
Particular attention should be paid to detecting paint
cracking that may occur at the joint line. Use an elevated
work platform to access and inspect the joint in each face,
where EWP access is not possible use binoculars.
(b) Visually inspect the external faces for visible degradation
and or corrosion.
(c) Record details of any evidence of cracks in paint or the
metal (welds) as well as any surface degradation. Raise a
new jobsheet for any outstanding works.
Item 2.1
(a) Carry out a NDT Test on the "vertical stiffener to skin
plate welds" and the "upper base plate to skin plate and
stiffener welds". Test all welds up to a height of +500mm
from the upper base plate
(b) Provide a written report of the result of each test.
Item 4.1 (First Inspection in 2008)
(a) Carry out a NDT examination of the "Upper base plate -
underside surfaces in the upper baseplate to lower baseplate
stiffener welds". Carry out the examination via the access
door. Examine all accessible areas for discontinuity of the
plate-weld joint and for crack indications in the upper
baseplate.
4. Notify the Traffic Control room on completion of the job.

06 M Test of batt backed emerg and exit lights Mezz Lvl

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.

during this test.

standard sets out the procedure to be adopted when testing
and proving the operation of battery backed emergency
lighting.
4. Ensure that no interruption to the normal supply has taken
place for a period of at least 16 hours prior to conducting
this discharge test. [_ _]
5. Replace fluorescent lamps that exhibit excessive
end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate.
Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST
MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL TMF-3012-OP-X241, only those fittings
in which the tubes have been replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for
90 minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY
LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST - GRANT ST MEZZANINE FLOOR LEVEL
TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those lights which does not provide
suitable area lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger
operation indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY
TMF-3012-OP-0241, only those light fittings that the battery
charger operation indicator does not function correctly.

parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.

12 M Inspect, test and clean Southern Link VSLS signs

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Inform Traffic Control Room prior to commencing work.
2. The VSLS on the RHL should be serviced using a RHL Lane
closure, VSLS units on the LHL should be serviced using
a LHS lane closure. This excludes the VSLS Sign Message
Operation and the Sign Test Result which are carried out on
the two signs, LHS and RHS simultaneously from the equipment
room controller.
3. Reference Manual Symon Services Operation, Training &
Maintenance Manual for TIMS, VSLS & FES M-STG-TM-29943
4. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 20, 23, 24, 25, 26 and 29.
5. Equipment Room Analysers
(a) Inspect the VSLS analyser for evidence of burnt or
damaged connections on plugs, electronic cards and
wiring.
(b) Clean the cabinet interior of any accumulated dirt or
dust.
(c) Press the TEST button on the analyser and monitor the
sign test routine. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in
Sign Test Result column on the form.
(d) Inspect the cabinet for damage, ensuring the door closes
and locks securely.
6. VSLS Signs
Note: As at 10-05-04 the large VSLS units at Power St,
Kingsway On ramp and Westgate Freeway have been
replaced with new generation VSLS units. Voltage Test
levels are different on the old and new generation
units.
(a) Isolate sign power at the sign circuit breaker within
the VSLS sign enclosure.
(b) Check the electronic component boards for evidence of
burning or arcing.
(c) Clean the front facia of the sign, using Windex and a
soft cloth.
(d) Turn the sign circuit breaker to ON and check the pixel
operation. Record in the comments column of the form
VSLS Systems Inspections Southern Link TMF-3012-OP-0394
if more than 10% of the pixels have failed.
(e) (i) Check and adjust the output of the 12VDC power supply
and the inputs to the various drivers and
controllers, the voltage measured, in each case must
fall within the range of (10.2V and 11V old VSLS
units) and (12.5 to 13VDC and 6.5 to 6.7V for new
VSLS units) . Record result ( OK or Fail) in the Sign
inspection column of the form VSLS Systems
Inspections Southern Link TMF-3012-OP-0394.
(ii) On the small VSLS signs (within the tunnel), check
and adjust the output of the 24VDC power supply and
the inputs to the various drivers and controllers,
the voltage measured, in each case must fall within
the range of 23.2V and 24V. Record result ( OK or
Fail) in the Sign inspection column of the form VSLS
Systems Inspections Southern Link TMF-3012-OP-0394.
(iii) On the LARGE VSLS signs (outside the tunnel), check
the range of 12.0 to 12.1 V and 6.5 to 6.7V.
Record result ( OK or Fail) in the Sign inspection
column of the form VSLS Systems Inspections Southern
Link TMF-3012-OP-0299.
The 12 V power supply, supplies the VSLS sign Red
LEDs, while the 24V power supply, supplies the White
LEDs. The Small VSLS signs have 4 LEDs per pixel
while the Large VSLS signs have 3 Leds per pixel.
(f) Check the operation and alignment of the Light Dependant
Resistor (LDR) by
(i) covering the LDR will cause the display intensity to
reduce
(ii) shining a torch onto the LDR will cause the display
intensity to increase. (This function cannot be
tested with the present configuration).
7. Ensure the control room can control the sign via a TEST
message change, confirm the sign operation back to the
operator. Record the result (Ok or Fail) in the sign message
operation column of the form VSLS Systems Inspections
Southern Link TMF-3012-OP-0394.
8. Results of inspections and comments are recorded on form
VSLS Systems Inspections Southern Link TMF-3012-OP-0394 for
tests that FAIL, record details in the comments column of the
form.
9. On completion of the job record any outstanding corrective
actions required in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
Raise a new job sheet for any corrective work required.
10. Notify the control room on completion of work.

03 M Inspect and maintain Swan St Shaft Stairwell Fan

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Refer to Maintenance Manual, Operating and Maintenance manual
for Mechanical Services - MCL Tunnels M-STG-ME-27400.
3. Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation commissioning tests.
4. The fans are accessed via a ladder to the roof of Sub-station
2
5. (a) Check the inlet grill, on the roof, for damage and debris
that would restrict air flow. [_ _]
(b) Check the roof mounted ducts for damage, corrosion and
fixings. [_ _]
(c) Check the wall mounted air supply grill, in the shaft,
for damage, corrosion, damage and debris. [_ _]
6. Work plan confirming the operation of the Swan St Shaft
stairwell pressurisation fan (SF-SS2-7) (2A ESF P03).
(a) Ensure all doors are closed, e.g. Burnley Tunnel to
stairwell, Refuge Area and head of stairs. [_ _]
(b) Request the traffic control room operator to start the
fan, ensure the air flow is into the egress stairs. [_ _]
(c) Note: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire
brigade. It will register on the local FIP and the CCCS
as an alarm. Remove the cover over the smoke detector,
direct test smoke from a smoke generator, as specified on
the container, onto the smoke detector (on the ducting).
Check that an alarm actuates on the local fire panel.
(The fan will not stop due to a time delay) [_ _]
(d) Request the traffic control room operator to start the
fan. [_ _]
(e) Remove the relay mounted in the rear compartment of the
fire indicator panel. The relay is labelled Swan Street
Escape Stair Relay. Check that the fan stops after
approx. two and a half minutes. [_ _]
(f) Replace the relay and request the traffic control room
operator to start the fan again and confirm fan
operation. [_ _]
(g) Request the traffic control room opertor to turn the fan
OFF, and advise the traffic control room operator that you
will be controlling it locally. [_ _]
(h) Switch the fan control switch AUTO OFF MANUAL to manual
and then start the fan locally. The speed of the fan can
be controlled using the variable control on the cabinet
door. Confirm operation. [_ _]
(i) Switch the fan OFF and switch the fan control switch AUTO
OFF MANUAL to the AUTO position and request the traffic
control room operator to start the fan again. [_ _]
7. Check the operation of controls and alarms.
(a) Open in turn, the Tunnel door, door to refuge 3, the
stairwell entry door at foot of stairwell and the exit
door at the head of the stiarwell. Confirm an alarm at
the TCR workstation. [_ _]
(b) Check the doors for damage, as well check the roller,
runners, handles, stops, counter-weight ropes, tube and
counter-weights for efficient operation. [_ _]
(c) In turn, chock open the each door, then using an
anemometer, measure the velocity of air out of the open
door. The reading is to be taken with the door fully
open and with no obstructions.
Record results in Work Done Area of the job sheet if less
than 1 metre per second and advise the maintenance
superintendent for further investigation. [_ _]
(d) Arrange the door catches to be non-functioning, then
using a spring balance measure the force required to open
the doors. Record results in the Work Done area of the
job sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required.
Advise the superintendent for further
investigation. [_ _]
(e) With all the doors to the egress stairs closed, check the
differential pressure on the Diff Press gauge. Record
readings of less than 50Pa in the Work Done area of the
jobsheet. Advise the superintendent for further
investigation. Record traffic control room reading
also. [_ _]
(f) After closing the door, check the time taken for the
stair air pressure to return its static level. Record in
the Work Done area of the job sheet if the time is
greater than 2 minutes. Advise the superintendent for
further investigation. [_ _]
8. Check the fire door and its operation.
(a) Remove all equipment installed to facilitate the above
test. Ensure the door functions and closes correctly.
Confirm with the Traffic Control room that the door
status indication in the control room is
correct. [_ _].
9. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes then request the traffic
control room operator to shut the fan down prior to leaving
the cross passage.
10. Check the condition of the flexible duct connections. [_ _]
11. Check the fan enclosure and mounts for security of
fastenings and tension. [_ _]
12. Check the fan impellor for build-up of dirt, clearances from
the housing and alignment. [_ _]
13. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet. [_ _]
14. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

04 M Insp & clean of WL CCTV cams, 23 Boom emerg lane etc."

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane.
2. Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: 23mt boom.
(b) Lane Closure: Emergency lane.
(c) Electrical Cabinet Location: Freeway.
3. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if necessary.
[_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and check that the equipment mounted
in the cabinet is secure. [_ _]
(c) Check cables and terminations for signs of degradation,
re-terminate if necessary. [_ _]
(d) Check the fibre patch leads for damage and that they are
securely fastened to the PT300.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.
(e) Check if surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is lit, if
not record the fact, for later replacement. [_ _]
(f) Check with TCRO that picture vision is OK. If not check
the signal from the camera using the WFM 90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly to the lead from the camera).
Ensure the co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT300
module and is secure. [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V supply to the PTZ controller and disconnect
(unplug) the control cable to the PTZ controller prior to
inspecting the camera housing. This will prevent movement
of the PTZ . [_ _]
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation. Surface insect spray
may be applied if necessary to the housing exterior
but must not be applied to the interior of the housing or
to the housing glass. If ingress of moisture or insect
infestation is evident then carry out steps (d) and
(e). [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X cleaning fluid. [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater
thermostat (HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the
operation of the heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.
8. Reconnect the PTZ control cable to the PTZ controller and
re-instate the 240V power supply to the PTZ controller.
[_ _]
9. Notify the control room on completion and check the PTZ for
full movement and pre-programmed positions. If camera fails
to respond press the reset button on the PT 300 and wait 2
minutes then check again. [_ _]
10.On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.

03 M Inspect, Test & Clean Church St Pump Station Equipment

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths,
lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting,
Brooms, Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. On accessing the pump station control panel(s), be aware of
the atmosphere, use your senses of sight, smell and hearing
to monitor any abnormal events. [_ _]
3. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of
the job sheet. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
corrective actions. [_ _]
4. Reference Manual TOJV Pump Station Operation and Maintenance
Manuals - M-STG-ME-20001. Volume 3.
5. WARNING: BOTH THE WET WELL AND THE VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED
CONFINED SPACES AND MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED
SPACE CONDITIONS.
Refer to Work Instruction, Confined Space Entry
TMI-3012-SA-0015.
6. Inspect the Switchboard
(a) Check the switchboard, situated adjacent to the pump
station, for local alarm conditions. [_ _]
(b) Carry out visual inspections both internally and
externally the control panel for vandalism, damage,
corrosion, insect infestation, moisture ingress, dust and
grime(clean as required). [_ _]
(c) Check the cable connections for tightness and evidence of
overheating and inspect the electrical control
equipment. [_ _]
(d) Record the reading of the hour run meter, for the pump,
in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
7. Inspection of pump wet well and valve pit.
(a) Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the
valve pit, inspect both the wet well and the valve pit
for general cleanliness and debris. Clean if
required. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external condition of the pipework and
valves for evidence corrosion and leaks. [_ _]
8. Switch the pump AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position. [_ _] CAUTION: Do not pump the wet well below
the Low/Low level alarm point as the lack of submergence may
cause damage to the pumpset.
(a) Check the position of the counterweight for the pump
non-return valve (NRV) prior to starting the
pump. [_ _]
(b) Check that the cabling to the pump for damage and that it
is clear from possible damage. [_ _]
9. Start the pump PSCH1 by pressing the START button.
(a) Measure and record the operating current of the pump in
the Work Donearea of the job sheet. (FLC 75A.).
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
and abnormal noises.
(c) Observe the level controller readout for variations,
with respect to the operation of the pump. [_ _]
(d) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton. Check
the operation of each non-return valve (NRV), as the
water flow stops. Indicators to the correct operation
of the NRV would be, the NRV closing with an sharp
audible metallic sound, the counterweight returning to
its original position or lower , as well, backflow
through the pump should cease within 30 seconds. If a
faulty closure is suspected, the pump should be
re-started, operated for 2 minutes and the operation of
the NRV should then be monitored again. If a faulty
closure is still suspected, report for corrective
maintenance. [_ _]
10. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position. [_ _]
11. Check the operation of the float switches. Manually trip
the floats from the surface by lifting up the High/High
float and the Low/Low float cables respectively with a hook
bar and then checking if the alarms were received at the
Control Room. [_ _]
12. When this job falls in either January, February or March.
Lift the level controller sensor out of the protective
conduit, then carefully, clean the recess in the sensor base
of all dirt and debris. [_ _]
13. Test the operation of the isolating valves by partially
closing and then fully opening. [_ _]
ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. Check the interior and external lighting for operation,
replace or repair any faulty lighting fixture. [_ _]
2. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor. Temperatures of ambient
plus 10?C should be considered abnormal and must be noted in
the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. [_ _]
3. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
equipment and components for evidence of burn marks, unusual
odours and overheating. record anything abnormal
in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the
Team Leader or his representative is informed of the
4. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc. [_ _]
5. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required. Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
6. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage. [_ _]
7. Inspect the electrical enclosures internally for dust, grime
and condensation, clean the enclosure(s) of any accumulated
dust, dirt and debris. [_ _]
8. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of
obstructions. [_ _]
9. Visually inspect systems, mounted within the building or
room(s), for faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged
switches and buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions. [_ _]
10. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following.
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators. Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged in
the work done area of the job sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error. [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw connections, for security. [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose. [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
and debris. [_ _]
11. Clean lighting diffusers (including emergency and Exit
lighting) and lens of accumulated dust and debris. [_ _]
12. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation. Record
anything abnormal in the Work Done area of the job
sheet. Record anything abnormal in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his
representative of outstanding actions. [_ _]
Building (Control Panel(s) Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the control panel for evidence of moisture ingress.
Inspect for source of
any water. Record any details in the Work Done area of
the job sheet and inform the Team Leader or his
representative. [_ _]
2. Check the doors and windows for damage, operation, lubricate
and repair as required and record in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet. Inform the Team Leader or his
representative of any outstanding works. [_ _]
3. Clean and remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of
cabinets, ledges, cable trays, cables, etc. Note: Dust will
settle on all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops of cabinets,
tops of cabinet doors, tops of meter
escutcheons etc. [_ _].
4. Clean exterior surfaces of cabinets where necessary. [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets and
ceilings. [_ _]
6. Remove from site all accumulated rubbish and debris. Empty
rubbish bins and replace liners. [_ _]
7. Sweep, vacuum and remove all accumulated dirt and dust from
the control panel interior. [_ _]
8. Carry out Exterior Checks of Control panel.
(a) Visually inspect the exterior surfaces of the control
panel(s) for damage, erosion, graffiti. [_ _]
(b) Inspect (if applicable) the general area surrounding
the control panel for erosion and damage to surfaces,
fences, gates, pavements [_ _]
9. Remove any accumulated debris from the surrounds. [_ _]
10. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service e.g.
pumps etc. [_ _]
(b) All Enclosures closed and locked. [_ _]
(c) All Lighting turned OFF [_ _]
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures leaks
lighting faults, door damage, evidence of structural damage
to the Pump Station and equipment etc, in theWork Done
section of the job sheet and report to the Team Leader or
his representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
12. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done
area of the job sheet. [_ _]
13. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Inspection of HVAC system within TSHs

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The 12 month service of the SL TSH air conditioners shall be
carried out on the air conditioners by the sub-contractor in
the presence of the electrical / electronic technician and in
conjunction with the 1 and 6 monthly service.
2. Perimeter access gate and Technical Shelter keys are
required.
3. Notify the control room prior to entering technical shelter
4. Carry out Annual Service of Process Cooling Unit as per
Liebert Corp. Manual Reference Haden, Process Cooling Systems
Technical Shelter Manual, Section 3.2. Liebert Intercool,
User Manual Sector 4 [M-MCL-ME-20014]
5. Check the electrical switchboard for connections, contacts,
wiring and or components that may be overheated. [_ _]
6. Compare the meter readings of the motor current with the
nameplate ratings. [_ _]
7. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following electrical
service:
(a) Check switchboard for overload settings. [_ _]
(b) Check all electrical control equipment operations and
calibration. [_ _]
8. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following mechanical
service at the compressor.
(a) Check and record the suction and discharge
pressures. [_ _]
(b) Check that the suction and discharge pressures are normal
and stable. [_ _]
(c) Confirm that the refrigerant charge is correct and that
there are no leaks. [_ _]
(d) Confirm that the refrigerant is dry (use sight glass),
fit a new dryer if required. [_ _]
(e) Check that the compressor mounting rubbers are secure and
serviceable. [_ _]
9. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following mechanical
service at the evaporator.
(a) Check the efficiency of the evaporator. [_ _]
(b) Check the evaporator air flow. [_ _]
(c) Check the evaporator fan operation for efficiency and
rectify any degraded operation. [_ _]
(d) Check the evaporator for leaks, repair any faults
found. [_ _]
(e) Check the filter media for efficiency and operation, fit
a new filter if required. [_ _]
10. The sub-contractor shall carry out the following mechanical
service at the condenser.
(a) Check the condenser air flow. [_ _]
(b) Check the cooling fan(s) operation for efficiency and
rectifying any degraded operation. [_ _]
(c) Check the condenser for leaks, repair any faults
found. [_ _]
11. Fill in the HVAC Service Log book
12. Fill in Technical Shelter log book.
13. Record the sub-contractors job report No. in the work done
area of the job sheet.
14. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
15. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
16. If sub contractor costs are unknown use the amount entered
in the Estimated Job Costs as an additional cost in the
transactions. Use Sub-contractor Costs - Outside Services.

(b) Carry out visual inspections both internally and
externally of the control panel for damage, corrosion,
evidence of insect infestation, ingress of moisture, dust
and grime (clean as required). [_ _]
(c) Check cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating and inspect electrical control
equipment. [_ _]
(d) Record readings of the hour run meters, for each pump, in
the Work Done area of the job sheet.
6. Inspect the pump wet well and the valve pit.
Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the valve
pit, enter the well and inspect for general cleanliness and
accumulated debris in the wet well, valve pit and the
condition of the pipework and valves and any evidence of
corrosion. [_ _]
7. Switch the pump PSSBP1 AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to
the MANUAL position. [_ _]
(a) Measure the operating current and compare with the rated
current. ( 170A). Record the results in the Work Done
area of the job sheet. [_ _]
(b) Check the cabling to the pump for damage and that it is
clear from possible damage. [_ _]
CAUTION: Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low level
alarm point as the lack of submergence may cause damage to
the pumpset.
8. Start the pump PSSBP1 by pressing the START button.
(a) Record the operating current of the pump in the Work
Done area of the job sheet. (FLC 170A.).
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
and abnormal noises.
(c) Observe the level controller readout for variations, with
respect to the pump operations. [_ _]
(d) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton. Check the
operation of each non-return valve (NRV), as the water
flow stops. The NRV should close with an sharp audible
metallic sound, as well, backflow through the pump should
cease within 30 seconds. If a faulty closure is
suspected, the pump should be re-started, operated
for 2 minutes and the operation of the NRV should then be
monitored again. [_ _]
9. Repeat steps 7 and 8 for PSSBP2.
10. Repeat steps 7 and 8 for PSSBP3.
11. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position. [_ _]
12. Check the operation of the float switches, by removing
circular plate in the wet well roof, then manually trip the
floats by lifting up the High/High float and Low/Low float
respectively with a hook bar and checking that the alarms
are received at the Control Room. [_ _]
13. When this job falls in either January, February or March.
Lift the level controller sensor out of the protective
conduit, then carefully, clean the recess in the sensor base
of all dirt and debris. [_ _]
14. Check the operation of each of the isolating valves, in
turn, by partially closing then fully opening
again. [_ _]

11. Clean lighting diffusers (including emergency and Exit

12. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for

anything abnormal in the Work Done area of the job

representative of outstanding actions. [_ _]
Building (Control Panel) Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance

1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.

monitor any abnormal events. [_ _]

Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of
the job sheet. Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
corrective actions. [_ _]
4. Reference Manual TOJV Pump Station Operation and Maintenance
Manuals - M-STG-ME-20001. Volume 3.
5. WARNING: BOTH THE WET WELL AND THE VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED
CONFINED SPACES AND MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED
SPACE CONDITIONS.
Refer to Work Instruction, Confined Space Entry
TMI-3012-SA-0015.
6. At the Local Control Panel
(a) Check the switchboard, situated beside the pump station,
for local alarm conditions. [_ _]
(b) Carry out visual inspections both internally and
externally of the control panel for vandalism,
damage, corrosion, insect infestation, moisture ingress,

for general cleanliness and debris. Clean if
required. [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external condition of the pipework and
valves for evidence corrosion and leaks. [_ _]
8. Switch the pump AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position. [_ _]
(a) Check the position of the pump non-return valve
counterweight before starting the pump. [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running or
vibration and abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Check that the cabling to the pump for damage and that it

CAUTION: Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low level

issuing from the outlet pipe into the river. [_ _]
(e) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton. Check

water flow stops. Indicators to the correct operation

of the NRV should then be monitored again. If a faulty
closure is still suspected, report for corrective
maintenance. [_ _]
(f ) Visually check the operation of the flap valve on the
riverbank. The valve should operate freely and shut
tight to prevent backflow of any water from the
river. [_ _]
10. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position. [_ _]

06 M Inspection of personnel safety equipment

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Collect and or access all safety equipment.
2. Inspection of Harnesses / lanyards / slings and webbing type
equipment.
(a) Lay harness / lanyard / slings on a flat surface.
(b) Visually check each harness / lanyard / slings for defects.
(i) Check the full extent of the webbing for cuts, burns,
excessive abrasion, chemical
damage, worn or crushed fibres.
(ii) Visually check all sewn joints and the stitching for damage
or any evidence of the joint
effectiveness being reduced.
(iii) Hold the webbing in one hand and with the other hand
feelingthe total length of the
webbing, feeling for worn, crushed fibres or any imbedded
foreign objects.
(iv) Hold the webbing with hands 200mm to 300mm apart bend into a
U"" in both directions
this tensioning will highlight any problem areas. Look for
sharp or imbedded objects
or objects stuck to the webbing.
(v) Check all buckles, metal adjusters, metal keepers, oval links
and any other sundry
hardware attached to the harnesses / lanyards are all in
perfect working condition and
have no distortion, rust, cracks or missing components.
(vi) The items deemed to be unsafe for use shall have the old
inspection label removed
and a CAUTION LABEL affixed then, their repair arranged or
their disposal.
(vi) For items that are found to be of undamaged, remove old
inspection label and install
new label indicating a successful inspection.
3. (a) For the various singular items of safety hardware which
includesbuckles, metal
adjusters, metal keepers, oval links and any other sundry
hardware are all in perfect
working condition and have no distortion, rust, cracks or
missing components.

removed and a
CAUTION LABEL affixed then their repair arranged or their
disposal.
(c) Remove old label and install new label indicating a successful
inspection.
4. Record the result of each inspection for all inspected on form
SAFETYEQUIPMENT
INSPECTION REPORT - TMF-3012-OP-0274.
5. Return all tested items to their place of storage on completion.
6. If required raise a new job sheet for repair, disposal and or
re-purchase. Charging the
costs to the appropriate stores item number for the item found to be
damaged. "

02 W Record Piezometer Readings BT water table pressures

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control prior to commencing the work.
2. Lane closures to access the Burnley tunnel shall be as per
Work Instruction, Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 25 or 26.
3. Reference documents:
(a) Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0031.
(b) Melbourne CityLink Project, Southern Link, Operations and
Maintenance Manual Tunnel Drainage Stage 2. R-STG-EN-006
and Transfield Obayashi JV,
(c) Operations & Maintenance Tanked Tunnel Drainage Works
Report PSM407.R34 December 2000 R-SDG-TU-134.
(d) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture, Burnley Tunnel Long
Term Monitoring of Twin Anchored Slabs. Report
PSM407.R30 September 2000, R-SDG-TU-130.
(e) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture Extensometer and
Piezometer Readings Procedures Report PSM500.R11 June
2001 R-SDG-TU-211 Rev A.
4. Location:
Eighty-six piezometers are located along the length of the
tanked section of the Burnley Tunnel. Forty-three are
mounted on the south side wall, and Forty-three mounted on
the north side wall. They highest test point is located up
to 3.5m above the road surface on the tunnel walls.
5. Purpose:
The Piezometer test points are used to monitor groundwater
pressures on the outside of the tunnel wall. The pressure
reading is then directly related to the groundwater head.
6. Carry out Piezometer readings:
6.1 (a) Loosen the bolt on one side of the stainless steel cover
and rotate the cover to reveal the quick connect
pressure coupling behind.
(b) Wipe the quick connect pressure coupling clean with a
rag.
(c) A ladder will be required to reach the piezometers in
the central section of the tunnel. A second person may
be required to hold the ladder in place.
6.2 (a) Prior to each reading, Vent the Druck digital pressure
indicator using the tap on the hose of the machine to
allow the pressures within the instrument to equalise.
(b) Connect the Druck digital pressure indicator to the
quick connect coupling. Pull back the sleeve on the
Druck digital pressure indicator connection and then
push the connection of the Druck digital pressure
indicator connection onto the piezometer connection.
6.3 (a) Press the I/O button to switch the unit on.
(b) Ensure the reading is set to Kilopascals (kpa) and set
to zero.
(c) To obtain consistent readings, hold the Druck digital
pressure indicator at the same level as the piezometer
tip during the reading.
(d) Allow the reading to stabilise, and record reading on
form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL - GROUNDWATER PRESSURE
TMF-3012-OP-0229.
Note that some of the readings may stabilise in a few
seconds, although some other readings may require a few
minutes to stabilise.
(e) Vent the Druck digital pressure indicator between
readings.
6.4 Record the results on form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL -
GROUNDWATER PRESSURE"" TMF-3012-OP-0229.
6.5 Replace the stainless steel cover and re-tighten the bolt.
7. Repeat Step 6 for the balance of the piezometer test points.
8. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet & also ,,
inform the Team Leader.
9. Notify the Control room on completion of the Job.
10. Ensure a copy of the completed form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL -
GROUNDWATER PRESSURE TMF-3012-OP-0229 is forwarded to the
Civil Team Leader or his representative for evaluation on
completion of the job. Results that are not in accordance
with baseline values would indicate a change in the state of
the groundwater storage. The operation of the Groundwater
recharge systems should be checked for correct operation.

03 M Inspection of WIM & TCS Systems on the SL Tollway

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane.
2. Set up short term emergency lane closure incorporating,
symbolic worker, lateral shift, vehicle arrow board and cones
as per Work Instruction , Traffic Control TMI-3012-OP 0002
and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
3. Reference: Central Weighing Australasia, Roadside Maintenance
Training Manual, Doc. PL-MCL-TM-1631, Rev 0 and for operation
of laptop computer, Weigh-in-Motion & Counting Stations,
Operator's Manual for WIMS Front End Computer,
Doc. PL-MCL-TM-1630, Rev A, Section 3 Telecom- DOS
operator's Manual . (Status Information 6.1.2 page 145)
4. At SL WIM/TCS Systems 04A control cabinet, check the
following;
(a) Internal and external condition of the cabinet. [_ _]
(b) Check wiring for tightness and for any evidence of
overheating. [_ _]
(c) Check that the Tx and Rx LEDs (on the modem) flash at
least each minute. [_ _]
(d) Check that the battery charger LED is ON. [_ _]
(e) Using a vacuum cleaner, clean the cabinet
interior. [_ _]
5. Use laptop computer to carry out the following:
(a) Plug the 9 pin serial lead from the computer to the
controller input/output board.
(b) Switch ON the computer.
(c) Click on Telecom WIMS Icon
(d) Select Comms by pressing the 'C' Key
(e) Select LOGGER/ONLINE, then press Enter.
(f) Check that the laptop computer communicates with the
logger correctly. [_ _]
(g) Confirm the logger parameters, shown in the CURRENT
SITE (MCL) on page no. 1, area match those listed in
the document Site Configuration and Set up Details
(stored cabinet). [_ _]
(h) Press key Page Down to go to screen page 2. [_ _]
(i) Record on the form attached loop frequencies and weigh
responses. [_ _]
(j) Record value of Power Status on page 2 of the
computer screen. The battery should read approx 13
volts. [_ _]
(k) When a truck crosses the sensors check on page 2
(computer screen) that all sensors, in each lane are
operating correctly (an asterisk will appear momentarily
alongside the appropriate loops as the truck crosses).
This check should only be done with trucks and not cars
(weighing sites only), as all sensors may not be displayed
for cars. [_ _]
(l) Select LOGGER/OFFLINE, then press Enter
(m) Select 'Quit', then press Enter
(n) Then select 'Quit' again, press Enter again.
(o) Select 'Yes' to quit Telecom system.
6. Switch computer OFF and then unplug the 9 pin serial
lead. [_ _]
7. From the side of the road, visually check the conditions of
the road sensors, for condition, no (loose bolts) metal
vibration or exposed wires visible. [_ _]
8. Repeat steps 4 to 7 for WIM/TCS System 04B [_ _].
9. Repeat steps 4 to 7 for WIM/TCS System 04C [_ _].
10. Repeat steps 4 to 7 for WIM/TCS System 05A & B [_ _].
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
12. Notify the control room prior to departure."

end-blackening, even when the lamps still operate. Record on

TMF-3012-OP-0246, only those fittings in which the tubes have been
replaced.
FA - 2 x 36w tube
FB -2 x 36w tube (Haz area)
FC - 1 x 18w tube
EM2 - 2 x 36w tube
EM3 - 2 x 36w tube
EM4 - 2 x 18w tube
EX1 - 2 x 10w tube
EX2 - 2 x 10w tube
EX3 - 2 x 10w tube
EX4 - 2 x 10w tube
EX5 - 2 x 10W tube
EXB1 - 1 x 10w tube.
6. Simulate a failure of the monitored power supply for 90
minutes. Monitor the lights and record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
DISCHARGE TEST - SUBSTATION 4 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0246,
only those lights which does not provide suitable area
lighting for the required 90 minutes.
7. Restore the emergency lights and exit signs to normal
condition and then check that the battery charger operation
indicator functions correctly. Record on EMERGENCY LIGHTING
only those light fittings that the battery charger operation
indicator does not function correctly.

emergency lights and exit signs. Record any broken or damaged
diffusers on the form EMERGENCY LIGHTING DISCHARGE TEST -
SUBSTATION 4 AND ENVIRONS TMF-3012-OP-0246 for subsequent
replacement.
9. Ensure the emergency lighting and exit signs operate in the
correct relationship to the normal lighting.

parameters in the Work Done area of the of the job sheet.

ALONE.

1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 3, the ventilation

operations.

on the
stairway adjacent to the south west corner of the Burnley vent
stack.

Portal.

havebeen completed.

carried out on

to be maintained
(preferably a fan located the furthest from the fan to be
maintained).
(a) If the selected fan is not running, then have the TCR start the
selected fan.
(b) Isolate the remaining non-operational axial fans, by switching
the AUTO/OFF/MAN
selector switches to the OFF position. Carry out the
electrical isolation procedures
as defined in the Work Instruction TMI -3012-OP - 0103, Low
Voltage Isolation
Procedures.
7. Electrical checks in Substation No 3
(a) Measure the insulation resistance of the stator windings and
record in the ""Work Done""
section of the Job Sheet. [_ _]
(b) Measure the current of the anti-condensation. Heater current
isapprox. 1 amp.
(c) Visually inspect both internally and externally, the control
panel for damage, corrosion
as well as the ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as
required)
8. (a) Enter the fan room from the entry stairway after equalizing
pressure in airlock.
WARNING: HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION SHOULD BE WORN IN
VENTILATION
FAN CHAMBER
(b) Check CO levels in fan room through doorway before entering and
at intervals during
fan checks.
(c) WARNING: DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1
METRE
OF AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD. Airflow strength 35 km/h.
9. Static Fan Checks for each fan.
(a) Confirm that both the fan and motor are electrically and
mechanically isolated prior to
commencing any work on the fan or the motor.
(b) Enter the fan inlet cowl via the entry cowl safety grill hatch.
(c) Examine the impeller for
(i) Dirt and foreign matter on the blades (clean if required)
[_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade tips [_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade leading edges [_ _]
(iv) Loose bolts and or blade fixings at the hub [_ _]
(d) Examine the electrical cable for security of fixings, damage due
to fraying, scuffing or
similar and for damage at locations where the cables penetrate
panels or
housings. [_ _]
(e) Check any grease discharged from the motor bearings, since the
last lubrication is not
excessive. [_ _]
(f ) Examine the discharged grease for any noticeable colour change.
Ensure that the
grease nipples are clean. [_ _]
(g) Inspect the cable connections to the motor for evidence of
overheating. [_ _]
(h) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the motorwindings
and the
winding heater bridge. Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth. Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
each phase winding and earth. Record results in the Work
Done area of the
Job sheet.
(vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(x) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works. Include the Job Number of the new job in the
Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate. Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.
(i) On leaving the fan inlet cowl grill hatch, replace the hatch
cover immediately. [_ _]
(j) Manually check the operation of the Rotork actuator and
associated linkages that
operate the exit dampers, use the local control panel switch.
(k ) Remove any mechanical interlocks blocking the fan operation.
[__]
10. Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION: ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) When the Static Fan Checks are complete, return to substation
3and remove the
safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then
removethe fan motor isolation
at the MCC.
Note: Ensure that all non-operational fans are isolated, in
accordance
TMI-3012-SA-0103, and that the only fan not
isolated, is the fan to be maintained.
(b) Return the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF position
to the AUTO position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room and have TCR start the fan,
thatis being maintained.
Note: The motor must not be started more that four times in
an hour.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
(e) Lubricate the motor bearings with fresh grease, while the motor
running.
DE = 100 gr / NDE - 120 gr Use Shell Stamina RL2 grease or
equivalent only.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the bearings
using the retrieval
system. Examine the grease for changes of colour. [_ _]
(g) Monitor the fan and motor for abnormal noises. [_ _]
(h) Stop the fan motor using Local EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
11. On completion, collect all materials and leave the fan room after
equalizing the
differential pressures.
12. In Substation No 3
(a) Remove all safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103,
then remove the
motor isolation for all the fans at the MCC. Return all
theREMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switches to the REMOTE position, and the
AUTO/OFF/MAN fan selector
switches to the AUTO position.
(b) Check that one fan is operational and no alarms are present
13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done' sectionof

14. Notify the control room on the completion of the job.

06 M clean of tunnel lighting photometers

At the photometer **COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. This job is to be carried out during a tunnel shut.
3. Clean the external surfaces, including glass window, of
accumulated dirt and dust. Use Rain-x and soft cloth.
4. Visually inspect the mounting components for damage,
corrosion (Remove and repair any corrosion found) and
security of fixings.
5. Visually check the cabling to the photometer for damage or
any required repairs (Repairs as required).
6. Check the general alignment of the Photometer for accuracy.
Methodology for Alignment Check:
**The alignment point needs to be defined by taping the distance
betweenthe walls of the Tunnel entrance to identify the centre, then
taping from the pavement upto 1.5m above. The target needs to be
this point, taking into account that the laser beam would be generated
parallel to the centre of the photometer.
At the photometer, a laser level needs to be placed on top of the
photometer and the unit then needs to be adjusted until the beam hits
the target. The process must be repeated with the laser placed on each
side of the unit, meaning the adjustment on the target**
7. Record any outstanding works required.
8. Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
9. Notify the TCRO on completion of the Job
